editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A MYLD AND IVST DEFENCE OF CERTEYNE ARGVMENTS, AT THE LAST SESSION OF Parliament directed to that mo≈øt Honorable High Court, in behalfe of the Mini≈øters ≈øu≈øpended and deprived &c: for not Sub≈øcribing and Conforming them≈øelues etc. AGAINST AN INTEMPERAT AND VNIVST CONSIDERATIon of them by M. Gabril Powell. The chiefe and generall contents wherof are breefely layd downe immediatly after the Epi≈øtle.

p.hi: Let there be no ≈øtrife I praye thee betweene thee and me, for we be brethren:

q.p: The wordes of his mouth were ≈øofter then butter, yet warre is in his heart: His wordes were more gentle then oyle, yet they were ≈øwords. P≈øal: 55, 21.
Out of one mouth proceedeth ble≈ø≈øing & cur≈øing: my brethren the≈øe things ought not to be ≈øo. Iames 3.10.
My litle children let vs not loue in word neyther in tongue only, but in deed and in truth: 1 Ioh: 3:18:

div.p: Imprinted, 1606.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE AND MOST CHRISTIAN HIGH COVRT OF PARliament which lately was, and ≈øhortly agayne is to be a≈ø≈øembled.
div.p:
RIght Honorable and mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Senat, as at your la≈øt Ses≈øion, there were certayne Arguments directed unto You for the quickening of your godly Zeale to ≈øpeake, not onely boldly, but al≈øo in all humilitie to the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie, for the Mini≈øters ≈øu≈øpended and deprived for not Sub≈øcribing and Conformyng them≈øelues to ≈øome pre≈øent Con≈øtitutions, and as ye did graciou≈øly accept of the ≈øayd Arguments, and mo≈øt worthily acquite your ≈øelues to the utmo≈øt of your powers, touching the matter pleaded for by them: ≈øo now vouch≈øafe (I mo≈øt humblie be≈øeech you) the like favorable acceptance of a ≈øober, mode≈øt, and iu≈øt defence of the ≈øame Arguments again≈øt a late uncharitable, unchri≈øtian, bitter, calumnious, and cavilling an≈øwer, publi≈øhed under the title of A con≈øideration of them by M. Gabril Powel. I am bold in ≈øteed of the author him≈øelfe of the Arguments, to take the defence of them upon me, and to pre≈øent them to your Honors, becau≈øe M. Powel him≈øelfe in his ≈øaid pretended an≈øwer unto them, hath ≈øo often referred the iudgment of the Arguments of his con≈øideration of them, and of the whole cau≈øe, to your mo≈øt graue and gracious company. Yea, there is nothing that I am more willing unto, or which I doe more earne≈øtly de≈øire, then that the cau≈øe betwixt M. Powel and all tho≈øe for whom he pleadeth on the one parte, and the author of the Arguments and me the defendant with all other in who≈øe behalfe we ≈øpeake on the other parte, might be iudiciou≈ø≈øy and equally heard at the barre of your mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Court. But the truth is, becau≈øe
we de≈øire and endeavor this, hinc illae lacrymae. Hence is their chiefe hatred of us, their great contention with us, and their bitter writing again≈øt us. Notwith≈øtanding though now we be uniu≈øtly charged as writing from Cimerian darknes, for concealing our names; yet if publike libertie might be granted to both parts, to ≈øtand before your iudgment ≈øeat, there freely to plead & debate the cau≈øe by the word of God, and that neither the worldly might and pompe of our adver≈øaries, nor our meannes and ba≈øenes might be re≈øpected, but the truth it ≈øelfe ≈øimplie con≈øidered and regarded, we would al≈øo accoumpt it as a ≈øingular mercy of God, and as a ≈øpeciall favor of you towards us in that behalfe.

In the meane time, I doe in all humility referr the ArgumeÃÑts, togeather with the defence of them to your graue and iudicious con≈øideration again≈øt your next meeting in Parliament: not doubting but that the equitie of the cau≈øe, and the innocencie of our ≈øelues will therby be ≈øo apparant unto you, that though before ≈øom perhaps among you, did thinke the one not to be ≈øo iu≈øt, and the other not ≈øo free from all blame, yet when ye ≈øhall agayne a≈ø≈øemble, ye will all with one mouth as one man, both iu≈øtifie the cau≈øe, and al≈øo ≈øpeake more then ever before ye haue don, for favor unto vs, and to our people: betwixt whom the bond before made by the Church, and ≈øealed by the holy Gho≈øt in the effects of our Mini≈øtery, cannot by any Lordly Epi≈øcopall ≈øeverity be iu≈øtly di≈ø≈øolved.

I doe further likewi≈øe humblie craue your Honorable lawfull favor more ≈øpecially towards me (if at any time I ≈øhall be di≈øcovered) again≈øt all tho≈øe that ≈øhall not well brooke the ≈øober and mode≈øt taxing of their corruptions in this defence: e≈øpecially con≈øidering the ≈øame is not done of any contentious minde; but onely in loue of the truth, to ≈øupport it again≈øt tho≈øe that deprave it: and in regard of our owne good names, to mainteyne our owne innocency again≈øt tho≈øe that under the name of brethren, doe mo≈øt unbrotherly di≈øgrace us.

Moreover, if any thing in this defence following, or in the Arguments them≈øelues, by the malice of any ≈øhalbe wre≈øted and perverted, thereby al≈øo to wre≈øt and pervert the law to the danger of the ≈øeverall authors of the one or the other (being found out) may it likewi≈øe plea≈øe you, in all lawfull and righteous manner to put forth your ≈øelues for protection of the ≈øayd authors: as chiefly becau≈øe ≈øuch wre≈øting of words and perverting of iudgment, may procure Gods iudgments again≈øt them≈øelues that ≈øhall ≈øo offend, and again≈øt the whole land; ≈øo likewi≈øe becau≈øe to ≈øpeake in ≈øuch matters and for ≈øuch per≈øons (what≈øoever the an≈øwerer ≈øaith to the contrary) ≈øhall not only bring much peace & comfort to ≈øuch ≈øpeakers them≈øelues, but ≈øhall al≈øo be beneficiall to the whole land, as is ≈øhewed in the Arguments, nothing infringed or weakened, by all M. Powels oppo≈øition unto them.

Yea let this con≈øideration be a third rea≈øon to moue you the rather ≈øo to ≈øpeake, viz. that if one man had the divinity & knowledge in law, as al≈øo all other learning, wit and wi≈ødom of all men, yet could he not ≈øo warily and circum≈øpectly write in all things, but that ≈øome wrangler or other (in≈øtructed and ≈øet a worke by the ≈øerpent, that is more ≈øubtle, not onely then all bea≈øts, but al≈øo then all men now living on the earth) might and would find ≈øome matter or other, wherby to mole≈øt and trouble him.

I had thought much more to haue enlarged this my preface, but the prolixity of the defence it ≈øelfe much exceeded my fir≈øt purpo≈ø, I will here conclude, both humblie and with all thanks to God & to your ≈øelues acknowledging your mo≈øt religious & gracious endeavors at your la≈øt Ses≈øion for the cau≈øe and for the per≈øons pleaded for in the argumeÃÑts; and mo≈øt heartily & in≈øtantly likewi≈øe praying for you & yours as Nehemiah Nehem: 5:19: & 13:4: prayed for him≈øelfe: viz. that God in goodnes would remember you (and yours) according to all that ye haue doone for vs: and that he will never wype out your kindnes that ye haue ≈øhewed on the hou≈øe of your God, and on the officers thereof.

div.head: A BREEFE NOTE OF SOME OF THE CHIEFE generall poynts handled in this defence following.
div.p: THat the author of the Arguments is fal≈øly accu≈øed to impute any di≈ø≈øembling or equivocating to the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øty, but that in all things he hath conceaved and written mo≈øt reverently, Chri≈øtiantly and duetifully of his Maje≈øtie.
2 That he is as vntruely charged with any vndutifull ≈øpeeches again≈øt the Nobility, or any other that haue obeyed his Maje≈øties procedings

3 That the Mini≈øters pleaded for are not refractary, ≈øuper≈øtitious, or ≈øchi≈ømaticall: neyther confronters of the Magi≈øtrat, or troublers of the ≈øtate, but that the≈øe and other the like imputations doe rather belong to their accu≈øers

4 That our Churches of England are in nothing ≈øo glorious ≈øtate as is pretended by M. Powel, and other prelaticall per≈øons but rather in divers re≈øpects, and for divers parts thereof in lamentable condition.

5 That the late proceedings of the Prelats again≈øt ≈øuch Mini≈øters for not ≈øub≈øcribing, conforming etc: & that many of the late Canons or coÃÑ≈øtitutions are contrary to the word of God, & the lawes of this Realme.
6 That the oth likewi≈øe Ex Officio is repugnant to the lawes of this Realme: yea abrogated by them, & only inforced by forreyne Canons.

7 That the obedience & loyaltie of the Mini≈øters for con≈øcience of Gods word not conforming them≈øelues, is as good as of the greate≈øt conformitans, yea that their not conforming theÃÑ≈øelues in that re≈øpect, maketh more then conformity for the good & ≈øafetie of his Maje≈øtie.

8 That the Con≈øiderer of the arguments, in his incon≈øiderat con≈øideration of them, hath mo≈øt unreverently and undutifully cen≈øured the High Court of Parliament, for their late mo≈øt religious indeavors in behalfe of the Mini≈øters pleaded for in the ≈øayd Arguments.
9 That the Mini≈øters ≈øoe deprived, doe not for≈øake their callings.

10 That although the number of the Mini≈øters ≈øo deprived be but ≈ømal in compari≈øon of other, yet the deprivation of them & the lo≈ø≈ø of their Mini≈øtery is dangerous for the whole Church in this kingdome.

11 That the Con≈øiderer of the arguments ofttimes offendeth in thos things which unju≈øtly he objecteth unto the author of the arguments: viz: in ≈øophi≈øtications in generall, and particularly in begging of the que≈øtion: as al≈øo in equivocations, & in vayne repetitions of the ≈øame things for encrea≈øing of his volume: and la≈øtly incontradicting him≈øelfe, yea ≈øometyme in one and the ≈øame place.
12 That he and other the Prelats mo≈øt ≈øtriving for conformity, doe attribut more to conformitie, then to any more materiall & principall duties of the Mini≈øtery expre≈øly commanded by God.

div.head: A DEFENCE OF THE ARGVMENTES Lately directed to the High Court of Parliament for the Mini≈øters ≈øilenced ect, again≈øt the an≈øwer unto them by M. Gabriel Powell.
div.p: All though the late an≈øwer of M. Powell to the Arguments in the title mentioned, for moment of matter be not ≈øuch, that either any di≈øgrace of the ≈øayd Arguments or of the cau≈øe it ≈øelfe, with any wi≈øe and judicious reader, neede to be feared thereby; or that therefore the ≈øaid an≈øwer ≈øhould haue reply thereunto: yet for their ≈øake that are not ≈øo judicious; and that neither the an≈øwerer him≈øelfe, neither any other by our ≈øilence may haue any cau≈øe to in≈øult and triumph, as having wonne ≈øome great field, and gotten ≈øome worthy victory, I haue pre≈øumed to take upon me the replying thereunto, in≈øteed of the author him≈øelfe.

Heerein (notwith≈øtanding the an≈øwerer his ≈øcoffing at our triobular Pamphlets) I will labour as much as I may for brevity, that ≈øo the Chri≈øtian reader may the le≈ø≈øe behindred from his other waighty affayres. For this cau≈øe I nether will reply to the whole an≈øwer, neither will cau≈øe the ≈øayd an≈øwer to be wholly reprinted, but will onely mo≈øt breifly collect ≈øuch things, as may mo≈øt ≈øeeme to requyre reply; but yet with ≈øuch faithfullnes, that the an≈øwerer ≈øhall haue no ju≈øt cau≈øe to complayne of the ≈øayd collections, as unju≈øt, or not agreeyng to his owne words. The marginall notes I will reply unto by them≈øelues, and
that according to the letters prefixed unto them: and the re≈øt that he writeth, in that order they are by him≈øelfe ≈øet downe.

But before I proceede any further, let me admoni≈øh M. Powel of one fault in him, and common to many other of that ≈øide; that is to attribute that to all of vs which is done by any one. I meane in things which they thinke to be blameable. The≈øe Arguments were written by one alone, yet what≈øoever he can by hooke or crooke gather as worthy of rebuke or ≈øhew of rebuke, that he imputeth to all that craue any favour? In good thiÃÑgs they deale not ≈øo, but that which is well ≈øayd or done by one is imputed to one onely, ≈øo that the re≈øt fare not the better thereby. My humble de≈øire therfore is, that how≈øoever thes men deale with vs, yet that other would deale otherwi≈øe. viz. That if there be any thing blamable in the Arguments, or in any other one mans writing of our ≈øide, it may be taken as the fault onely of one, and not imputed to all. E≈øpecially let this be con≈øidered, when there is no fault at all, but onely by ≈øurmi≈øe, and upon uncharitable mi≈øcon≈øtruyng & wre≈øting of a mans words. It was the fault of Saule, for the ≈øuppo≈øed offence of Abimelech, to kill both him, and al≈øo all the re≈øt of the Lords Prei≈øts. It was the ≈øinne of Haman, for the ≈øu≈øpected pride of Mordecai in not bowyng unto him, to hate him & all the Iewes, and to plot and contriue the ruine of them all. So the Apo≈øtle noteth it as a fault of the heathen, that knew not God, and were given over to a reprobate mind, to take all things in the evill part. Rom. 1.24. Let this therefore be the ≈øinne of ≈øuch wicked men, but let all true Chri≈øtians that loue and feare the Lord, be free therof. Now to proceed, I will beginne with the preface.
TOuching the preface there being not much therein which is not afterward mentioned in the re≈øt of the booke, I may the more cur≈øorily pa≈ø≈øe and rune it over.

The fir≈øt poynt here to be ob≈øerved, as al≈øo in the place of ≈øcripture ≈øub≈øcribed to the title Gen. 13.8. Is that he calleth vs brethren, as if he did ≈øo account and regard us. Notwith≈øtandidg whether he doe any otherwi≈øe, or with any other minde ≈øo call us, then only as Ioab called Ama≈øae his brother with his mouth, and yet at the ≈øame in≈øtant killed him with his hand. 2 Sam. 20 9. I leaue it to be judged by his oppo≈øition to our petition, by his mo≈øt unchri≈øtian, & vncharitable raylings, revilyngs, reproches & ≈øcoffs, as al≈øo by his mo≈øt unju≈øt collections; as directly contrary to the words, & much more to the meaning of the author of the ≈øaid Arguments, ≈øo likwi≈øe to all rea≈øon, & common ≈øen≈øe. Sharpnes & bitternes are the common weapons and principall armour of that ≈øide, which is an evidence of the badnes of their cau≈øe, and no le≈ø≈øe te≈øtimony of the goodnes of ours. For truth and righteou≈ønes can ≈øupport them≈øelues without any ≈øuch meanes. Notwith≈øtanding in this kind, this an≈øwerer hath farre exceeded many other, yea, he may well be acknowledged to haue wonne the ≈øpurres from many other. They commonly object this fault unto us, and it may be ≈øome one of his private motion and di≈øpo≈øition, doth a litle ≈øomtyme offend this way, to the greife of the re≈øt that favor the cau≈øe. But if all ≈øpeeches of that kind that haue ever been u≈øed by any of our ≈øide, were gathered into one (truely and without any wre≈øting) they would not a mount to the number proportionably, that is apparant and evident in this an≈øwer.

The which fault is ≈øo much the greater, becau≈øe the arguments
are propounded with all temperance, & without any ju≈øt occa≈øion to provoke him, except it be as a weake ≈øtomake is ≈øicke with the be≈øt and mo≈øt whol≈øome meate. Notwith≈øtandyng I do the le≈ø≈øe marveile hereat, becau≈øe as the more extreame the loue of Amnon was towardes Tamar at the fir≈øt, and the more extreame al≈øo his hatred again≈øt her afterward, 2. Sam. 13.15. So this is often to be ob≈øerved, that ≈øuch as ≈øometime haue been mo≈øt hott in di≈ølike of the corruptions of our Church, they changing their minds and for preferment conformyng them≈øelues, haue become more bitter and heavie adver≈øaryes, then any of tho≈øe that were never other theÃÑ conformable men. But was M. Powel at any time of ≈øuch a minde? Yea certainly within the≈øe few yeares he was ≈øo over ≈øtrong, that he called the Communion booke a Ma≈ø≈ø booke. At another time likewi≈øe being at a Church, and hearing the Latiny, he ro≈øe up ≈øaying, come let us goe, what, ≈øhall we now heare conjuring? So likewi≈øe the time hath been when ≈øome other (now very conformable) haue publikly in pulpit (I will not ≈øay in my hearing) to the di≈øgrace of the Bi≈øhops ≈øayd, If ever the Bi≈øhops doe good in the Parliament hou≈øe let me be damned. Many other the like in≈øtances might be named, But I regard brevity. The≈øe things wilbe ju≈øtified. Did any of vs ever ≈øo be haue our ≈øelues? If we had, we might be ju≈øtly blamed in that behalfe. But I will pre≈ø≈øe this poynt no further. I haue the rather reported this, for the better an≈øwer of the matter of giddines afterward by him objected unto us.
2 The next poynt in the preface, is, that he chargeth us with emulation of forreyne novelty.

An≈ø. Neither noveltie, nor forreyne. We de≈øire nothing, wherein we haue not proved our de≈øires by ≈øuch Arguments
of Gods word (the be≈øt antiquitie, and be≈øides which, the more auncient any thing is, the more rotten is the ≈øame) ≈øuch arguments (I ≈øay) as never haue been yet ≈øufficiently an≈øwered. Touchinge the word forreyne, though indeed the thinges de≈øired by us are in all Churches of other Countryes fully reformed in doctrine with ours, yet tho≈øe Churches being all the ≈øame hou≈øhould of faith that we are, they are not aptly called forreyne. As Engli≈øhmen travelyng in other Countryes and livyng after Engli≈øh fa≈øhion, are not therfore Forreyners in re≈øpect of England whiles they ≈øo travell, but ≈øtill to be accounted of the ≈øame country, ≈øo all Churches and all members of the Church, in what Country ≈øo ever they be, are not to be accounted Forreyners one to another, becau≈øe they are all Citizens of heaven, and we make all one family or body.

Be≈øides, the thinges in controver≈øie which we de≈øire to be removed, may much more ju≈øtly be called both Noviltie & Forreyne, becau≈øe they were not of Apo≈øtolicall in≈øtitution, neyther heard of in the Apo≈øtles time, yea, condemned by generall arguments in the writinges of the Apo≈øtles, as hath been ≈øhewed in divers other bookes written one our ≈øide, not yet an≈øwered: e≈øpecially in the A bridgment made by the Mini≈øters of Lincolne Dioce≈ø≈øe, the Demaunds, and in the 12 Arguments: as al≈øo becau≈øe they are in u≈øe in more Forreyne Popi≈øh Synagogues, then there are reformed Churches in all Europe. La≈øtly, although Communion with the Churches of Chri≈øt in what country ≈øoever, be much more to be re≈øpected, then fellow≈øhip with the ≈øinagogues of Antichri≈øt, yet we do not therefore de≈øire that which we doe, becau≈øe it is in other Churches, but becau≈øe the word requyreth the ≈øame.
div.q: G. PowelThey refu≈øe to conforme them ≈øelues.
div.p: An≈øwer. None of vs haue ever had the booke of Common prayer authorized by Act of Parliament 1 Eliz. And ≈øome of vs haue never had the book now vrged by the Bi≈øhops provided for us, or tendred unto us: How then haue wee refu≈øed to conforme our ≈øelues? Yet we are deprived. By what right and equity I know not.
div.q: The auncient approved Di≈øcipline & Ceremonyes of our Church.
div.p: Not auncient, becau≈øe they haue not warrant from God. Neither ever ≈øo approved, but that from the fir≈øt Preachyng of the Go≈øpell in this kingdome, they haue been by divers godly and learned men oppugned.
div.q: His Highnes ≈øought to reclaime them by ≈øome correction of their ob≈øtinacy, as by ≈øilencyng etc.
div.p: That which his Maje≈øtie permitted on that behalfe, was qualified with gracious provi≈øors; 1. To proceede no otherwi≈øe therein then accordyng to the lawes of God and the land. 2 To execute even that with all mildnes & moderation. And thirdly, to endeavore to per≈øwade by all arguments, rather theÃÑ by cen≈øures: which things becau≈øe they haue not been done, but that in many re≈øpectes the Bi≈øhops and other Prelats haue exceeded their commis≈øion, we doubt not but that if it might plea≈øe ≈øome attending upon his Highnes and in grace with him, in all humble manner to informe him, we doubt not (I ≈øay) but that his Maje≈øtie, accordyng to his mo≈øt chri≈øtian di≈øpo≈øition, would graciou≈øly re≈øpect the humble de≈øires of his ≈øubjects therein. Touchyng the other parte of M. Powels ≈øpeech, it is no ≈ømall abu≈øe of his Maje≈øtie to impute unto him the ≈øeveritie of the Bi≈øhops again≈øt us: whereas in truth what≈øoever his Maje≈øtie doth theriÃÑ, is only through their importunity, and by their accu≈øing us of ≈øchi≈øme, di≈øorder, ≈øedition etc.
div.q: The moderat ≈øeverity of the Bi≈øhops,Gab. Powel is unfitly and unduetifully termed oppre≈ø≈øion, and cruelty.
div.p: Is it moderate ≈øeveritie to turne ≈øo many Mini≈øters as are now ≈øilenced, out of their livyngs? Yea,An≈øw. to provide al≈øo, that they ≈øhall haue no other way or meanes whereby to liue, that ≈øo they, their wiues and children may goe abegging, to the di≈øgrace of the go≈øpell, the di≈øhonor of the land, the greife of the godly, and the joye of the wicked? E≈øpecially, is it moderate ≈øeverity ≈øo to doe for ≈øuch cau≈øes? Did they ever read in any antiquity, ≈øo many of ≈øuch quality, & who≈øe labours God had ≈øo ble≈ø≈øed, to be thru≈øt and ca≈øt out as un≈øavory ≈øalt in the time of the go≈øpell, in a kingdome whereof both King and people doe profe≈ø≈øe the go≈øpell, and in an age, in re≈øpect of the ≈øinnes thereof, requyering ten tymes as many preachers more then their are, if they could be gotten? If the≈øe be the mercyes of the Bi≈øhops, what would be their crueltyes? If this be their moderat ≈øeverity, what would be their extremity if they might be ≈øuffered?

If a Father ≈øhould ca≈øt his ≈øonne out of hou≈øe & home, & utterly di≈øinherit him, becau≈øe he would eat no chee≈øe, were this moderat ≈øeverity? What then may be ≈øayd of them that ca≈øt out other from the inheritaÃÑce of the Lord, who≈øe labours God hath ble≈ø≈øed to the joye of many an elect ≈øoule, & that only for not doyng that, again≈øt which they can yeeld a farre better rea≈øon from God his will revealed in his word, then any man can doe for his not eating of chee≈øe or for any other the like action, from the ≈øecret in≈øtinct of nature?
div.q: G. PowelThe author of the≈øe arguments, is not afrayd; to per≈øwade & provoke your Honorable Court (the≈øe are his owne words) to intercede with his Maje≈øtie, that he would compell the Reverend Prelats to ≈øurcea≈øe their rigorous and cruell dealing.
div.p: The Apo≈øtle biddeth vs to provoke one another to loue & to good works. Heb. 10.24. Therefore why might not the author of the≈øe arguments u≈øe this word unto the Parliament for ≈øo good a worke, as in all the ≈øaid arguments is intended. But for the latter words of M. Powel, to compell the Reverend Prelats to ≈øurcea≈øe their rigorous and cruell dealing etc. Where doth the author u≈øe them? The drifte of all the arguments in≈øinuateth ≈øo much. If it be but in≈øinuation, then all the words before ≈øet downe, are not the expre≈ø≈øe owne words of the author, as M. Powell hath ≈øaid. 2 It may be taken for granted, that the ≈øayd Prelats are ≈øo re≈øolute for mainteyning of their Hierarchie, Di≈øcipline, Ceremonyes, and other conformity, that they will not yeeld one inche, yea not to his Maje≈øtie, exceept they be compelled.
div.q: Gab. PowelThe Prelats haue ≈øoberly and temperatly caryed them≈øelues in their proceedings.
div.p:
An≈øw.We will all with one accord mo≈øt thankfully acknowledg this, when we ≈øhall find it. In the meane tyme, we do acknowledge it comparatiuly true, in re≈øpect of their wils and de≈øires. For by this an≈øwer written by their authority and by divers other tokens, it is apparant that they would gladly provoke us to giue them further advantage again≈øt vs, and al≈øo that for the≈øe cau≈øes they would doe more theÃÑ they doe (yet I ≈øpeake not of all, I doe unfainedly confe≈ø≈ø that their is great difference of affections among≈øt them it re≈øpect of us) they would I ≈øay doe more then they doe If they feared not the people? No, but if his Maje≈øtie, his mo≈øt Honorable coun≈øell would giue them leaue: and if they feared not as much indignation from his Highnes as now they ≈øeeme to be in grace with him; and as much oppo≈øition by the honorable Coun≈øell, as now perhaps they
≈øeeme to haue furtherance by ≈øome of them that do not ≈øo well under≈øtand the cau≈øe.
div.q: G. PowelTheir ob≈øtinat ≈øuper≈øtion hath worthely made them ≈øubject to the proceedings of the Bi≈øhops.
div.p: What? Super≈øtition? And ob≈øtinate ≈øuper≈øtition?An≈øw. We were never before (to my remembrance) charged with ≈øuper≈øtition, much le≈ø≈øe with ob≈øtinat ≈øuper≈øtition: but haue alwayes been accounted great adver≈øaryes to ≈øuper≈øtitioÃÑ. Yea, we hate it with a perfect hatred, yea our ≈øoules abhorre and dete≈øt the lea≈øt ≈øuper≈øtition, much more ob≈øtinat ≈øuper≈øtition, as much as the be≈øt of them doe hate it: yea, much more then ≈øome of them: it is one of our rea≈øons again≈øt ≈øome poynts of conformitie, that we judge them ≈øuper≈øtitious. How then may we be charged with ≈øuper≈øtition? Yea with ob≈øtinat ≈øuper≈øtition? But what if we were ≈øuper≈øtitious? May we therfore be puni≈øhed coÃÑ trary to law, or aboue that that the law requyreth? Were not this to ad tran≈øgres≈øion to tran≈øgres≈øion, and to puni≈øh ≈øinne with ≈øinne? We may not doe evill, that good may come thereof.
div.q: G. PowelThe author cryeth out, as if the go≈øpell by ≈øuch proceedings were bani≈øhed, Gods wor≈øhip prophanely adulterated, to the eternall perill of many thou≈øand ≈øoules.
div.p:
Where is this outcry? It is very low and ≈øoft,An≈øwer. in ≈øome ≈øecret corner, or written in very ≈ømall letters, that no man can ≈øee or heare of it. The author might well cry out, that the go≈øpell is in part bani≈øhed, by the ≈øuppres≈øion of ≈øo many able, godly, faithfull & paynefull mini≈øters; that Gods wor≈øhip is in part corrupted, both in the doctrine, e≈øpecially ≈øithens this late vehement ≈øtrivyng by our Prelats for conformitie (as ≈øhalbe afterwards touched) and al≈øo in the other publike exerci≈øes of religion by mixture of humane inventions, Ceremonyes and Traditions. Yea,
and that heerby we are in danger to haue the candle≈øticke removed, and the kingdome of Heaven taken from us, and given to a Nation more worthy then we, except by repentance & doing our fir≈øt works Revel. 2.5. Yea, making our la≈øt works more then our fir≈øt ver≈ø. 19. We doe in time prevent this judgment.
div.q: G. Powel The Parliament is able to convince him heerin of malepart Sycophancy, and manife≈øt untruth.
div.p: An≈øwer. I would ≈øuch accu≈øers (notwith≈øtanding their ≈øuch threats of the Parliaments kindnes) would ≈øtand with vs, & that we might be admitted to ≈øtand with them at the barre of the Parliament for triall of this accu≈øation, and whether the author of tho≈øe Arguments, or this an≈øwerer haue abu≈øed that mo≈øt worthy Senat.
div.q: G. PowelThis author feareth no rebuke of ≈øhame, for his vncon≈øcionable dealyng.
div.p: An≈øwer.Let this un≈øcon≈øcionable dealing be ≈øhewed in the author: or el≈øe let this an≈øwerer be a≈øhamed.
div.q: G. PowelThis man ≈øpeaketh froÃÑ Cimmerian darknes, by concealing his naÃÑe.
div.p:
An≈øwer.Then al≈øo by the ≈øame rea≈øon many books of the ≈øcripture, the writers whereof haue concealed their names, were written from Cimmerian darknes. The like may be ≈øayd of many other mo≈øt worthy Theologicall bookes, without name of any writer. Much more may the ≈øame be ≈øayd of the booke intitled SCOTTISH GENEVATING & ENGLISH SCOTIZING, and many other ≈øuch di≈øgracefull and ≈øcornefull books publi≈øhed without name of any author, again≈øt the de≈øired reformation, and all the favorers thereof. It is al≈øo the ≈øeveritie of the Prelats that maketh vs the rather to conceale our names. If we had as much liberty to publi≈øh our books for our ≈øelues, as every rayler hath to put forth any thing again≈øt us: Yea, as there is for Printing of many profane, filthy, ≈øcurrilous, la≈øcivious, &
ungodly bookes authori≈øed by ≈øome of them, you ≈øhould quickly ≈øee our names.
div.q: The author is bold to offer his writing even to your Honors,Gab. Powel to provoke you to ≈øupplicat to his excellent Maje≈øtie, in behalfe of their cau≈øe, or el≈øe to determine it of your ≈øelues.
div.p: An≈øw.The author never de≈øired this determynation you ≈øpeake of by the Parliament, as though that would or might be authenticall without his Maje≈øties Royall a≈ø≈øeÃÑt, but onely that his Maje≈øty thereby ≈øeeing the equity of the cau≈øe, and the affection of his people therunto, might al≈øo be the more ea≈øily per≈øwaded to vouch≈øafe his princly favour towards them therein.
div.q: G. PowelI was coÃÑmaunded by ≈øome in authority to peru≈øe and breifely to refute the≈øe Arguments, which at the fir≈øt I was unwillyng to take vpon me.
div.p:
If you be ≈øo ready to be commaunded to write again≈øt ≈øuch a cau≈øe, take heed you be not found a ≈øervant of men. An≈øwer. But if any in authority haue coÃÑmaunded you this worke, did they al≈øo commaund you to rayle and revile your antagoni≈øt (as you call him) in ≈øuch manner as you doe? It is lamentable that any in authority in ≈øuch a Chri≈øtian Church, ≈øhould either commaund any ≈øuch thing, or allowe of it being done. But it is more lamentable to obey. The time was when you did well employ your ≈øelfe again≈øt the Common adver≈øaryes. You did then runne well. What letted you that you did not hold on in that cour≈øe? What hath provoked you to turn your pen from them, and to whet it now the ≈øecond time again≈øt tho≈øe, whom you call and ≈øhould in truth acknowledg your brethren? Doe you feare any violence from the Papi≈øts by holding on again≈øt them, becau≈øe perhaps of ≈øome former experience? Indeede, you may well feare ≈øuch violence from them, and be ≈øecure touchyng all danger from us,
becau≈øe you haue learned from the Apothegme (after mentioned) of D. Elmer late Bishop of London, and much more from all experieÃÑce, that you may ju≈øtly feare your life and cuttyng of your throat in the company of one Papi≈øt, but that no ≈øuch thing is ever to be feared among≈øt ten thow≈øand of (tho≈øe whom it plea≈øed him to call) pre≈øci≈øians.
div.q: G. Powel In divers re≈øpects I feared to plead in ≈øo high a Court, before ≈øuch judges etc. Yet the equity and holines of the cau≈øe moved me etc.
div.p: An≈øwer. Why ≈øhould you feare, being commaunded? Would not your comnaunders beare you out? It may be they will before men, but who ≈øhall plead for you before God, except you repent? Take heed you commend not that to be equall and holy, which agreeth not with the wayes of God.
div.q: G. Powel I pre≈øently re≈øolued to ≈øtand in the gap and breach, between our brethren and vs.
div.p: An≈øwer. This re≈øolution upon bare commaundement of a man, (it may be al≈øo contrary to the likyng of ≈øome to whom you are more bound) was too pre≈øent to be ≈øound. How haue you ≈øtod in the gap & breach? By treading it down to make it lower that wild bea≈øts, or at the lea≈øt ≈øtrang cattell may the more ea≈øily break in to devoure the Lords vine, and to eate up the Lords people as it were bread.
div.q: G. Powel Albeit I knew my brethrens affections to be ≈øomewhat unkind, and their pens foule and ≈øhamefull.
div.p: An≈øwer. Whereby knew you their unkindnes and foulnes towards you? Indeed they haue ≈øeene and dayly doe ≈øee your unkindnes towards them: yea towards the Lord, in oppos≈øing your ≈øelfe to the Lords cau≈øe, and to them in ≈øeeking therof, and that in this bitter manner: yea for the foulnes of your pen you might ju≈øtly feare the like mea≈øure from them againe to you. But God forbid that for that we ≈øhould ≈øinne again≈øt God, and cea≈øe praying for you.
div.q: G. PowelSeeing it lyeth not in our powers to make them mode≈øt & peacable, and that we are called to ≈øerue God and his Church, which we are bound to doe in good and evill report.
div.p: An≈øwer.You ≈øhould fir≈øt haue proved us immode≈øt and unpeaceable, before you had u≈øed the≈øe wordes. God giue tho≈øe graces to you and us. The ≈øerving of God and of his Church, is not in rayling & reprochfull ≈øpeaches, in ≈øharpnes and bitternes, in untrue and unju≈øt collections directly contrary to the words of our brethren. But what meaÃÑe you by good and evell report? If as patients, it is well: if as agents it is not ≈øo. But though by your booke I haue little cau≈øe, yet I will take you in the better ≈øence.
div.q: G. Powel I pray our heavenly Father to forgiue them any injury etc.
div.p: An≈øwer. Before prayers you ≈øhould lay a≈øide all wrath of heart, and bitternes of word. Math. 5.22. 1 Tim. 2.8. Pray al≈øo ≈øor the forgivnes of the wrongs you doe to vs, both in this booke, and al≈øo in your latine treati≈øe De adiaphoris.
div.q: I haue not with drawne my ≈øelfe from this worke,Gab. Powel no not for the e≈øtimatioÃÑ & reverence I haue of the graue judgments of your honors.
div.p: If you had duely reverenced their Honors,An≈øw. you would haue feared the offering vnto them ≈øuch a pre≈øent of raylings, vnju≈øt collections etc. As if they had been voyd of judgement, not able to di≈øcerne of ≈øuch accu≈øations.
div.q: G. Powel I mayntaine here the glory of God, and honor of our Prelats.
div.p:
An≈øwer. As our Saviour ≈øaid, They ≈øhall excommunicate you, yea, the time ≈øhall come, that who≈øoever killeth you, ≈øhall thinke that he doth God ≈øervice. Ioh. 16.2. So this an≈øwerer thinketh that he glorifieth God by rayling on his cau≈øe & ≈øervaÃÑts. As for the Honor of our Prelats, you ≈øhould fir≈øt haue been on a ≈øure ground for the lawfulnes thereof, before you had taken upon you (like a champion) the defence thereof. 2. Even a good cau≈øe is rather overthrowne then vpheld by ≈øuch meanes of ≈øcoffing and rayling, as in this
this booke you haue v≈øed. Thus much for the an≈øwer to the Preface of M. Powels.

div.head: THE NEXT THING TO BE CONSIDERED is his marginall Notes vpon the preface of the author.
div.p: The fir≈øt note with (a) I pa≈ø≈øe by.
div.q: G. Powelb This preten≈øe unto the Chri≈øtian reader, is becau≈øe they would not ≈øeeme to be petitioners unto the Parliament.
div.p: An≈øwer.What a ≈øtrange collection is this? Haue we expre≈øly directed all the ≈øaid argumeÃÑts vnto the Parliament hou≈øe, and yet would we not ≈øeeme to be petitioners unto theÃÑ? Nay rather ≈øith this an≈øwerer thus carpeth at the≈øe words the Chri≈øtian reader, M. Powell maketh the Parliament no chri≈øtian a≈ø≈øembly. gatthering from the humble petition of the Author of tho≈øe Argumentes to the Chri≈øtian Reader etc. that he would not ≈øeeme to be Petitioner to the Parliment, may not this be better gathered that the an≈øwerer di≈øtingui≈øheth the chri≈øtian readers from the Parliament, and the Parliament from them, and ≈øo maketh the Parliament no chri≈øtian a≈ø≈øembly? But why did the author u≈øe tho≈øe wordes, the chri≈øtian reader? The rea≈øon ≈øeemeth double: 1 becau≈øe he did ≈øo account of every one in the Parliament hou≈øe: 2 becau≈øe he thought that tho≈øe arguments might come to the handes of other Chri≈øtian readers, then onely of Parliament men.

div.p:
An≈øwer. This etc. After the word cro≈ø≈øe, is well added. For otherwi≈øe although we hold tho≈øe things to be matters of religion, yet never any of us did affirme all religion to coÃÑ ≈øi≈øt in theÃÑ. without this etc. therfore, this is an unchri≈øtian ≈ølaunder, and to ≈øpeake according to the an≈øwerers learning in Ari≈øtotles Eleuchs, a fallacy ab eo quod e≈øt ≈øecundum quid, ad id quod e≈øt ≈øimpliciter. The adage in the end of this
note is too homely for that Honorable Court to whom the an≈øwerer ≈øpeaketh, as being taken from ≈øwyne, which for ≈øome cau≈øes (not fit to be written) being ≈øometimes ≈øhorne, make a great cry, & yeld litle wooll. And though the an≈øwerer by this adage ≈øeeme to e≈øteeme us no better then ≈øwyne, (as al≈øo in his other booke De adiaphoris it plea≈øeth him to compare us to Apes) yet indeed may he well ≈øay that the mo≈øt of us haue but litle wooll on our backes, we haue been ≈øo long and often ≈øhorne & ≈øhaven, that we hage nothing left but our very skine: Yet it may be that ≈øome of our adver≈øaryes hope for wooll and fat from our livings.
div.q: G. Poweld As if his Maje≈øtie would be di≈øplea≈øed if any promoted a religious or hone≈øt cau≈øe. A malepart and pre≈øumptuous (if not a di≈øloyall) cen≈øure.
div.p:
Is this man in his right minde,An≈øw. that he maketh ≈øuch collections? The author per≈øwadeth all men from all ≈øuch un-chri≈øtian and di≈øloyall ≈øu≈øpitions of his Maje≈øtie, how then may this note be applyed unto him.contradiction in the an≈øwerer. In the la≈øt Argument (or rather conclu≈øion of all the arguments) where the author ≈øpeaketh of ≈øome that are alwayes accu≈øing and di≈øgracing the mini≈øters (pleaded for with Nobles and Princes,) the an≈øwerer maketh this marginall note, An vniu≈øt calumny. Whether it be ≈øo or no let all men iudge, as by his whole an≈øwer, ≈øo particularly by this note, and them that follow, yea by his whole an≈øwer to all the preface before the arguments. But to returne, ≈øith ≈øometymes ≈øome feare that even of Chri≈øtian Princes which they nether need nor ought to feare, what mallepartnes, pre≈øumption, or di≈øloyaltie was there in the author to prevent ≈øuch feare. Doth not the Apo≈øtle often times Rom. 7.7. and 9.14. and Galt. 3.21. and often el≈øe
where, prevent objections that might, but needed not be made? Shall he therfore be charged with malepert pre≈øumption again≈øt God and his trueth?
div.q: G. Powele I knowe not wherto all his whole Paragraph tendeth, if the Suppliants deeme not his Maie≈øty to haue for≈øaken his fir≈øt loue, and to haue revolted from religion, at lea≈øt in ≈øhew for a time. (f) A malitious, uncharitable and unchri≈øtian allegation to be applyed unto the whole State (that loyally obey his Maie≈øtie) e≈øpecially to his Nobles and ≈øervants.
div.p: An≈øwerO uncharitable collections. Let the reader by them judge whither this man doe not accu≈øe vs, and provoke (what he can) our gracious Prince, his Nobles and all other again≈øt us: Yea, directly contrary to the words of the author, who laboreth by the whole Paragraph ≈øpoken of by the an≈øwerer, to per≈øwade all men to conceaue well & Honorably of his Maje≈øtie, according to many former mo≈øt worthy te≈øtimonies of his Princely piety and religion. And albeit all in the ≈øayd Paragraph be ≈øpoken onely to that purpo≈øe, yet the an≈øwerer wre≈øteth the ≈øame as intended al≈øo again≈øt the whole State, e≈øpecially again≈øt his Maje≈øtie, Nobles and ≈øervants. But he that iudgeth righteou≈øly, to whom we commend the cau≈øe and our ≈øelues, ≈øhall one day make our righteou≈ønes knowne.

div.q: G. Powel h No bolder & ≈øecurer cen≈øurers of all ≈øorts & degres of men, under the cope of heaven, then the≈øe ≈øingular & ≈øelfe conceited refractaryes.

An≈øwer. Yes, this notary is a more bold and ≈øecure cen≈øurer, in
as much as in his notes before he hath cen≈øured the author of the arguments, and all other de≈øiering that which he de≈øireth, (of what ≈øorte and degree ≈øoever) for that that is not expre≈ø≈øed, neither intended, nor any wayes to be ju≈øtly gathered from his words. When this cen≈øuring he ≈øpeaketh of, is proved by any of us, let the partie again≈øt whom it is proved beare the blame thereof. The k. is an≈øwered before.
div.q: G. Powell Is a triobular pamphlet ≈øuch an huge quantity or volume? It may ≈øeeme the pen man of this ≈øupplication was the worthy author of the late two leaved libels.
div.p:
Seeing words (as this an≈øwerer ≈øaith in his conclu≈øion) ought to be numbred to ≈øo great States, An≈øwer. why ≈øhould re≈øpect of brevity be thus ≈øcornfully objected to the author? E≈øpecially con≈øidering the other manifold & waighty affayres of that Honorable a≈ø≈øembly, unto whom the ≈øayd Arguments were directed. If the Arguments were a triobular pamphlet, what would the an≈øwere haue been without them: e≈øpecially without all his cavils, reproches, vnju≈øt colections, vayne repetitions, and that fal≈øe ground that alwayes he buildeth upon, viz. his ≈øuppo≈øition that we are ≈øchi≈ømaticks? The an≈øwerer his former booke al≈øo De adiaphoris, what were it with a le≈ø≈øe margine, without the great multiplicity of ≈øections, and if every bird had her owne feather. The two leaved libells wherof he ≈øpeaketh, are perhaps the more offen≈øiue vnto him, becau≈øe ≈øome of them doe attribute more authority to his Maje≈øtie, then they would haue us to doe, or then the prelats doe, that
the challenge ≈øo much to them≈øelues.
div.q: G. Powel l Such pre≈øumptuous and ≈øelfe conceyted Elihues, are the≈øe male content Mini≈øters, who take upon them to in≈øtruct ≈øuch, as be wi≈øer then them≈øelues. Vide Gregorium in hunc locum.
div.p: An≈øwer. What a thing is this? For want of matter again≈øt the author, this an≈øwerer falleth out with the worthy Elihu, as a pre≈øumptuous and ≈øelfe conceited man, who≈øe wi≈øedome notwith≈øtanding, mode≈øtie, and ≈øingular humilitie are evident in holy ≈øcripture, by his ≈øilence till other (more auncient then him≈øelfe) had ≈øpoken all they could, as al≈øo by his pleading the cau≈øe of God him≈øelfe, when all the re≈øt there pre≈øent had geiven over the ≈øame, (in which re≈øpect al≈øo all in the≈øe dayes that plead for God again≈øt the oppo≈øitions of tho≈øe that would be accounted the onely wi≈øe and learned men, are likewi≈øe reproched as pre≈øumptuous and ≈øelfe conceited) and la≈øtly by the elegancy & eloquence of his ≈øpeeches, and by the profound and divine matter therin conteyned. Finally are humble petitioners, that bow them≈øelues to the ground, before them to whom they doe petition, are ≈øuch petitioners (I ≈øay) before heaven and earth to be proclaimed pre≈øumptuous and ≈øelfe conceited in≈øtructers? Is this the man that er≈øt now blamed other as bold and ≈øecure cen≈øurers?

div.head: A REPLY TO THE FVRTHER ANSWER OF the preface to the Arguments.
div.q: G. PowelSome haue fooli≈øhly made a breach and divi≈øion among≈øt us about cro≈ø≈øe and ≈øurplice etc.
div.p:
Wi≈øedome con≈øi≈øteth in under≈øtanding what the will of the Lord is, Ephe. 5.17. And in a con≈øcience of keeping Gods commaundements and ob≈øerving his word. An≈øwer Deut. 4.6. The which to reject is the greate≈øt folly Ierem. 8.9. We haue made no breach or divi≈øion at all: But as Io≈øeph for telling his divine dreames, was hated of his brethren, and at
the la≈øt ≈øold a way to ≈øtrangers by them≈øelues: and as the blinde man Iohn 9. for confes≈øing Chri≈øt, and ≈øtoutly ≈øtanding in that confes≈øion, was throwne out of the Iewi≈øh Synagogue by the Phari≈øes, ≈øo (to u≈øe the words of this an≈øwerer) we are violently and unju≈øtly broken of and divided, and thru≈øt out of the mini≈øtery by other, and yet charged that we haue made a foli≈øh breach and divi≈øion.
div.q: G. Powel And therefore I cannot allow the opinion of ≈øuch as giue out,An≈øwer.Yet we doe all as hartily and faithfully loue and affect our Prince and King (yea of what≈øoever religion) and are as ready and willing to defend his per≈øon & honor, again≈øt all adver≈øaryes etc. that the≈øe our factious brethren are as dangerous enimyes vnto the ≈øtate as the papi≈øts etc.
div.p: Neither you nor any other, haue ever yet had, or ever (I hope) ≈øhall haue cau≈øe ju≈øtly to ≈øpeake, write, or thinke otherwi≈øe concernyng either our loue & loyalty towards our Soveraigne, or our duety to any of his governors: yea though we ≈øhould cunningly be ≈øolicited to ≈øome vndutifull practi≈øes, as ≈øome not many yeares ≈øince were, in the dayes of late Q. Elizab. of mo≈øt Honorable memory, who were ≈øo farr from enterteyning any ≈øuch motions, as that mo≈øt dutifully, they di≈øcovered the ≈øame to other in higher authority. Though (I ≈øay) we ≈øhould be cunningly ≈øolicited to any undutifull practi≈øes or to the approbation of any ≈øuch practi≈øe, yet I tru≈øt that never any of vs ≈øhall be found ≈øo to offend again≈øt his Maje≈øties meane≈øt and lowe≈øt officers.
div.q: G. PowelD. Elmer late B. of London gravely ≈øayd, If I were in the company but of one Papi≈øt, I might ju≈øtly feare the lo≈ø≈øe of my life, but being among≈øt ten thou≈øand Preci≈øians, well might I be afrayd of my Bi≈øhopricke, but never of my throate: the one would cut my coate, and the other my throate.
div.p:
The Preci≈øians (as it plea≈øeth B. Elmer to call them) never de≈øired the Bi≈øhopprickes of any of their adver≈øaryes,An≈øwer but onely that they would giue glory to him that ≈øitteth vpon
the Throne, and ca≈øt their miters at the feete of the Lambe, acknowledging him worthy of all rule and Dominion, & contenting them≈øelues with the places and Honors commended in the ≈øcriptures: according to an other apothegmaticall exhortation of the ≈øayd Bi≈øhop, both made openly at Paules cro≈ø≈øe, and al≈øo printed (before him≈øelfe was ≈øo advanced in the world) viz. that Bi≈øhops and other Prelats should come downe from their thow≈øands, and content them≈øelues with an hundred, vntill which aba≈øing of them≈øelues, and re≈øignyng that which uniu≈øtly they hold, reigning as Lords & Kings over the Lords inheritance, neither the Church of God in generall, neither our Soveraigne in speciall, shall haue ≈øo much ≈øervice, and good by their ≈øervice, neither them≈øelues ≈øo much peace and comforte of con≈øcience, as otherwi≈øe would be.
div.q: G. PowelThough they be free from ≈øu≈øpition of trea≈øon and rebellion, yet it cannot be denyed, but that pre≈øumptuou≈øly and willfully, they contend with the Magi≈øtrat, impugning his authority in things indiffereÃÑt.
div.p:
Cannot that be denyed, which never was, neither ever can be proved again≈øt us?An≈øwer. 1 We deny that it is the Magi≈øtrats meere plea≈øure that we ≈øhould conforme, otherwi≈øe then by mi≈ø information of our adver≈øaryes again≈øt us, as David upon the like mi≈ø information of Ziba again≈øt Mephibosheth, gaue all to Ziba that had been Mephibosheths 2 Sam. 16.2. Yea, they doe not only giue all the mi≈ø informations them-≈øelues again≈øt us which they can jmagine, or wherwith they are informed by other, but al≈øo they labour what they can to keep the Magi≈øtrats from all right information in our behalfe by any other: yea they indeavour their vtmo≈øt to keep both Parliament and all other, from mediation for us. 2 Though we yeeld not in all thinges required of us, yet it is not pre≈øumptuou≈øly and wilfully, but in all humility & mode≈øty: we contend not
by the ≈øword nor any violence, but onely by word, yea, pleading the word of God for our cau≈øe. Our contentioÃÑ al≈øo is in a patient ≈øuffering, with a duetifull cleering of our innocency again≈øt the fal≈øe imputations wherewith we are burdened. The things in que≈øtion haue been ≈øaid, but never ≈øub≈øtantially proved to be indifferent in ≈øuch ≈øorte, and to ≈øuch v≈øes as now they are urged. Our adver≈øaries haue ≈øo long ≈øtriveÃÑ to maintayne the things (which they call indifferent) for ≈øuch u≈øes as to which they are not indifferent, that they haue made religion it ≈øelfe an in different thing to many men. In things truely indifferent, it is already ju≈øtified, and ≈øhalbe further ju≈øtified (if neede requyer) that we attribute no le≈ø≈øe to the magi≈øtrat, then our adver≈øaryes doe. Let them name in what ≈øen≈øe and degree the Papi≈øts deny the Soveraignty of Princes in any thinge, and I doubt not, but that it may be proved that them≈øelues (holding their owne principles) doe deny the ≈øame, in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe and degree.
div.q: G. PowelAll of them make a faction and ≈øchi≈øme in the Church for carnall re≈øpects: ≈øome becau≈øe they know not otherwi≈øe how to be mainteyned: ≈øome to gratifie their benefactors and Patrons and to plea≈øe their frends: ≈øome for di≈øcontentment and want of preferment: ≈øome for giddines of innovation etc.
div.p:
What? all M. Powell? How doe you forget your ≈øelfe?An≈øwer. You ≈øhould haue left this generall judgment of all, to the generall judge of all. There is none of the≈øe of whom you ≈øpeake, but for the world and outward things they might liue better conformyng then not coÃÑforming them≈øelues. What benefit haue any by gratifying their Patrons? Will their Patrons giue them better mayntenance otherwi≈øe? Nay ≈øome Patrons are their adver≈øaryes, and are gratified by them that put ≈øuch Mini≈øters out, that ≈øo they may pre≈øent againe etc. Some ≈øo di≈øplea≈øe their frends heerby
that by their di≈øplea≈øure they loo≈øe more in one day then they get all their life by any Eccle≈øia≈øticall living. Some al≈øo by di≈øplea≈øing their frends doe not only lo≈øe temporall benefits for them and theirs, but doe al≈øo hinder them≈øelues of as great Eccle≈øia≈øticall promotion, as many or the mo≈øt of the conformable ≈øort doe ateyne unto. Some by their troubles for this cau≈øe, having had good patrimonyes: haue con≈øumed & wa≈øted them ≈øo, that in their age (when they need mo≈øt comfort) they liue in penury and want, and at their death leaue not ≈øo much to their wiues & many children, as was left to them≈øelues alone. Some by want for this cau≈øe, are forced to take their children of very great hope and forwardnes for learnyng froÃÑ the ≈øchoole, and to make them apprenti≈øes to their owne great greife, and in time to the detriment of the Church. Agayne, this imputation of carnall re≈øpects unto us (≈øuch as you reckon) is contrary to your often imputation of ≈øuper≈øtition unto vs. For what is ≈øuper≈øtition, but to make that ≈øinne that is not ≈øinne; and ≈øo to feare ≈øinnyng again≈øt God, as that we doe not that which lawfully we may do: or one the contrary to make that good, holy, and nece≈ø≈øary, that is nether good, holy, nor nece≈ø≈øary, and ≈øo to think him≈øelfe bound to doe that, which well he might leaue undone? If then we be ≈øuper≈øtitious, and doe that which we doe in fearing to ≈øinne again≈øt God, how can ≈øuch carnall re≈øpects as before are particularized, be imputed vnto us? But the truth is, that the≈øe carnall re≈øpects doe belong rather to conformiry, for which many will doe any thing rather then they will loo≈øe their livyngs. Of how many al≈øo of them may it be ≈øayd that they ≈øeeke their owne, and not that which is Ie≈øus Chri≈øts? Philip. 2.21. Yea, that their belly is their God, their glory their ≈øhame, and that they mind earthly
things? Philip. 3.19. that al≈øo with Diotrephes, that loue to haue the preheminence? 3. Ioh. 9. How many of that ≈øide haue receaved 500. or 600. pounds from their people, ≈øince their la≈øt Sermon, yea, ≈øince their la≈øt pre≈øence among≈øt them? Yea, are their not ≈øome that buy & ≈øell benefices, as men buye and ≈øell hor≈øes? Truely there are ≈øoÃÑe that being not old meÃÑ haue in their dayes pa≈ø≈øed through many benefices, and tho≈øe of very good worth. To whoÃÑ then doth this imputation of carnall re≈øpectes belong. Cea≈øe therefore, cea≈øe M. Powell to charge us with that again≈øt which there are ≈øo many rea≈øons. Yea, wherein all the world can convince you.
div.q: G. PowelThey haue altered the ≈øtate of the que≈øtion. For the que≈øtion being about ≈øub≈øcription, Ceremonyes, Conformitie etc. (which are but thinges indifferent and of ≈ømall moment) they make it the cau≈øe of God, the mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell, the ≈øalvation of the people, the mayne cau≈øe of the land.
div.p:
How doe we alter the ≈øtate of the qve≈øtion? Doe we mince that which ≈øomtyme we held?An≈øwer Doe we goe from any thing which before we maynteyned? What ever was in controver≈øie betwixt you and us, that is not comprehended under ≈øub≈øcription, or ≈øome other of the particulars by you here mencioned? It is meere folly ≈øo often to repeate the indifferency of the≈øe thinges, that hath never been neither can be proved by you. For as much al≈øo as for not ≈øub≈øcribyng, and for not conforming to Ceremonyes etc. Many more are thru≈øt out of the mini≈øtery then for any other matter of ten tymes greater moment, may it not be truely called the cau≈øe of God? E≈øpecially it being in ≈øo many bookes proved that they are unlawfull & contrary to the word of God? Yea, ≈øith for the≈øe thinges the word is re≈øtrayned, may we not ≈øay that the ≈øalvation of the people dependeth therevpon? And con≈øequently that it
is the mayne cau≈øe of the land? What is greater then ≈øalvation? Your ≈øelfe grant that we are Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, in grace and favour with God. It followeth therefore that our cau≈øe is the cau≈øe of God. Luc. 10.16. Yea, of the land al≈øo, becau≈øe be≈øids ≈øalvation many other benefits doe depend upon the mini≈øtery of the word, and many evills vpon the re≈øtraint thereof. Prov. 29.18. For this cau≈øe the Apo≈øtle joyneth the≈øe two togeather in the Iewes, that they were contrary (or adver≈øaryes) to all men, and forbad them to preach to the Gentles. 1. The≈ø≈øalonians 2. ver. 15.16. Touching your often objection of our ≈øu≈øpen≈øion and deprivation for not conformyng our ≈øelues, con≈øider this one thing M. Powell, and con≈øider it ≈øeriou≈øly, viz. that wheÃÑ as Iohn and ≈øome other Di≈øciples tooke upon them to forbid one ca≈øting out Devills, (that had before done it in the name of Chri≈øt) and that only becau≈øe he would not joyne with them and follow them to Chri≈øt: and that afterward wheÃÑ they made relation unto Chri≈øt, of that which they had done, and of the rea≈øon why they had done it (as though they had done ≈øome great ≈øervice, as many thinke they doe now great ≈øervice in forbidding us to preach) con≈øider (I ≈øay agayne) that our Saviour was ≈øo far from approving that which they had done, that he rather reproved it ≈øaying, Forbid him not. Mar. 9.38.39. Whether was a ju≈øter cau≈øe of ≈øu≈øpention, not to joyne with ≈øuch worthy Di≈øciples of our Saviour, and that in following them, and goeing with them to our Saviour him≈øelfe, or not to joyne with the Bi≈øhops, & to conforme our ≈øelues unto them in tho≈øe things, wherein we are per≈øwaded we ≈øhould ≈øinne again≈øt Chri≈øt, and in parte goe away from him? For we follow not Chri≈øt, neither walke with him any longer, then we doe ob≈øerue his word. Further al≈øo
con≈øider whether is a greater, or at the lea≈øt a better and more nece≈ø≈øary worke, to ca≈øt out Devills from their po≈ø≈øes≈øion which they had of the bodyes of men, or to ca≈øt them out from the ≈øpirituall po≈ø≈øes≈øion they haue of the ≈øoul of men, which eiection is wrought by the preaching the go≈øpell Acts 26.18.
div.q: G. PowelThey make this ≈øuch a cau≈øe, as if all religion depended on refu≈øing of a cro≈øe and furplice etc.
div.p: No, no.An≈øwer. All religion and piety doth not depend on the≈øe thinges. Yet religion is the le≈ø≈øe, and doth the more decay, the more that the preaching of the go≈øpell, for thes thinges is re≈øtrayned. The increa≈øe of ≈øinne and iniquity in tho≈øe places already where ≈øuch Mini≈øters are put out, doth too much te≈øtifie this thing. Heere againe is his former fallacy, as eo quod e≈øt ≈øecundum quid, ad id quod e≈øt ≈øimpliciter. We ≈øay, that ≈øome religion dependeth on refu≈ø≈øing of a cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øurplice ete. Hence he concludeth, that all religion dependeth etc. Further, whether we make all religion to depend on refus≈øing a cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øurplice etc. or no, it ≈øemeth that the Bi≈øhops make all religion (or the mo≈øt) to depend on cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øurplice, etc. For if a man yeeld to the≈øe things, he may pa≈ø≈øe away with any other matter vncontrolled: but if he ≈øtands in the≈øe things, then he is unworthy the mini≈øtery, what≈øoever guiftes he haue, how godly ≈øoever he be, and what good ≈øo ever he haue done, or might doe by his continuance. Is it not ≈øo?
div.q: G. PowelThey boldly, pre≈øumptuou≈øly, and unduetifully cen≈øure his Maje≈øtie for coldnes in religion, for lo≈øing his fir≈øt loue, deepe di≈ø≈øembling, ≈øeeming to pretend one thing and to intend another as if he had been trayned up in the Ie≈øuits ≈øchooles to equivocat: which fault I would ≈øome of their faction did ≈øo litle practi≈øe, as his Maje≈øtie abhorres it.
div.p:
Wheris there any ≈øuch cen≈øure of his Maje≈øtie for coldnes An≈øwer.
in religion, for lo≈øing his fir≈øt loue, and for deepe di≈ø≈øembling? Nay, doth not the author expre≈øly labour the quit contrary, profes≈øing that he wrote that which he did to this very end, that men might not iudge Chri≈øtian Princes vpon outward apperences, yea adding ≈øuppo≈øed apparences? Yea, wi≈øhyng al≈øo le≈ø≈øe cen≈øuring of them, and were praying for them? Is there not by all authors a difference made betwixt Simulare and di ‚Ä¢ ≈øimulare, that the one may be u≈øed in godly policy and chri≈øtian wi≈ødome, but that the other is alwayes of the fle≈øh fle≈øhly? In allegation of examples, every particular is not nicely and ≈øtrictly to be re≈øpected, but that poynt onely is to be con≈øidered for which they are produced, and wherto they be applyed. Otherwi≈øe, from the application of Davids eating of the ≈øhewe bread, vnto the Di≈øciples plucking the eares of corne to eat. Math. 12.3. A maÃÑ may gather that becau≈øe David u≈øed lying as a meanes to obtayne the ≈øheew bread at the Prei≈øts handes, therefore al≈øo it is lawfull for us by lying to obteyne ≈øome thing in our neces≈øity. By the ≈øame rea≈øon al≈øo, becau≈øe the midwiues of Egypt are commended to feare the Lord etc. and to haue ≈øpared the male children of the I≈øraelits, the ≈øame fault of lying may be ju≈øtified, becau≈øe they being examined by Pharoh of that their doeing, excu≈øed them≈øelues by a lye. The like may be ≈øaide of Rahab, commended for her faith in ≈øavyng the I≈øraelits ≈øpyes, Heb. 11.31. Though ≈øhe defended her ≈øelfe from the inqui≈øitors of the King of Iericho by a lye. Io≈ø. 2.4.

If the example of Con≈øtantius and Iehu, may for ≈øome things be excepted again≈øt, yet it might haue been con≈øidred, that the author to expre≈ø≈øe his generall meanyng the better, did mention al≈øo the example of Io≈øeph, and of our Saviour Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, again≈øt whom there can be no exception.
And now to clere his meanyng the better, let the example of Salomon in that wherein he is ≈øo highly commended, be al≈øo remembred: who to try whither of the two weomen were the mother of the living child, commaunded the lyving child to be divided in twane, and the one halfe to be given to the one woman, the other halfe to the other woman. 1 Kings 3.25. Here is a manife≈øt preten≈øe of that which was not inteÃÑded. Let the an≈øwerer therfore learne, that there is great difference betwixt pretending onely for triall of the affections of other, and deepe di≈ø≈øembling or Ie≈øuitecall equivocating, for the hiding or maynteyning of ≈øome impiety and wickednes. I doubt not therefore, but I may ju≈øtifie the author from all ≈øuch thinges, as by allegation of the examples of Con≈øtantius & Iehu, are mo≈øt uncharitably imputed unto him: yea, that al≈øo I may truely affirme his meanyng in them to haue been, onely to ≈øhew that he conceaved of his Maje≈øties meanyng, that which he was per≈øwaded to be be≈øt. Therfore farr was he from all undutifull conceits again≈øt his Maje≈øtie.

It is al≈øo to be ob≈øerved, that he doth not ab≈øolutly ≈øay this or that to be his Maje≈øties meanyng, but onely that it might be like to the meanyng of Con≈øtantius, Iehu, Io≈øeph, and our Saviour: for ought that any man el≈øe did knowe. If it be otherwi≈øe, Gods will be done: and I hope that what≈øoever ≈øome doe imagine of ≈øuch as are ≈øilenced and deprived, that upon ≈øight of his Maje≈øties full re≈øolution for the countenancyng and authorizyng of the Bi≈øhops to hold on their cour≈øe again≈øt us, then many will yeeld etc. yet it ≈øhall well appere that we haue not depended upon any other then upon God alone: and that that which we haue done, is not done vpon any vayne hope or expectation, but in con≈øcience of that word which is
our onely rule and canon whereby to liue, and whereby to dy. Touching the an≈øwerers wi≈øh that ≈øome of our faction (as he unbrotherly ≈øpeaketh) did ≈øo litle practi≈øe equiuocating as his Maie≈øty abhorres it, either let him name ≈øuch (if he know any) and let them beare their iniquity, or el≈øe let him ≈øpare ≈øuch wi≈øhes, as whereby he implieth a ≈øecret accu≈øation.
div.q: G. Powel Whereas his Highnes heart is evidently di≈øcerned to be fully ≈øea≈øoned with true piety etc.
div.p: An≈øwer Though flatery be odious, and the wages therof fearfull, yet if his Maje≈øtie or any other doe well con≈øider the be≈øt fruites of a true heart, our loue and loyalty towards his Maje≈øtie ≈øhould be ≈øound as good, as the be≈øt Prelate in the land.
div.q: G. PowelIt ≈øufficeth me to haue detected the licence of their raving peÃÑnes, the re≈øtraint of which fury, ≈øpecially belongeth to your Honorable & judicious Court.
div.p: An≈øwer.O M. Powell you doe to much forget mode≈øty. Whither pen raveth mo≈øt, yours or the authors, or whither he or you, (I will not ≈øay yee though you write by authoritie of ≈øome other) be in mo≈øt fury, let that Honorable and judicious Court judge. Yea, if it might plea≈øe his Maje≈øtie to vouch≈øafe the reading of the wrightings, and in his Princely wi≈øedome to con≈øider the dealing on both ≈øides, we would not feare his Royall judgment concerning our cau≈øe or our ≈øelues. We feare the judgment of one Lordly Bi≈øhop ten times more, then the judgment of ten ≈øuch religious Princes. For we a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues of more equitie from his Maje≈øtie, then we doe from all Lordly Bi≈øhops in the land.
div.q:
G. Powel.Which your Honors will the rather performe, con≈øidering what unchri≈øtian conceits they haue of this Honorable a≈ø≈øembly, and of all other his Maje≈øties loving ≈øubjectes, who loyally obey him and ≈øerue God, according to the religion e≈øtabli≈øhed: re≈øembling them to Con≈øtantius
his Nobles. Who became Idolaters and Athei≈øtes upon his commaundement.
div.p:
As before we haue ≈øeene how untruely the an≈øwerer maketh this note vpon the authors conclu≈øion,An≈øwer. with the letter e an vniu≈øt calumni pag 77. in as much as he hath accu≈øed the author before of bold, pre≈øumptuous, and unduetifull cen≈øuring of his Maie≈øtie etc. thereby to provoke his Maje≈øties heavie indignation again≈øt us all,Contrariety ≈øo now contrary to the ≈øame note, he accu≈øeth us al≈øo before the Nobles, yea, before all the ≈øtates of the whole kingdome. Doeht this man ≈øpare us, as he profe≈ø≈øeth to doe in his ≈øecond note upon the 4 argument? Touching the matter here objected, it is partly an≈øwered before. The authors intent and purpo≈øe was only to per≈øwade all his Maje≈øties chri≈øtian ≈øubjectes to thinke Honorably of his Highnes, and not to judge him by outward ≈øuppo≈øed apparences. Therwas nothing to in≈øinuate any ≈øuch unchri≈øtian cen≈øure of this Honorable a≈ø≈øembly and of other loving ≈øubjectes as this wranglinge an≈øwerer would wre≈øt from the authors words. The matters in que≈øtion concerne onely or ≈øpecially the mini≈øters of the word. The things al≈øo commaunded by his Maje≈øtie are nothing like to the thinges commaunded by Con≈øtantius. How injurous therefore it is, to conclude the ≈øame ≈øinne to be of them that obey his Maje≈øtie in the thinges now commaunded, that was in tho≈øe that obeyed Con≈øtantius, I leaue to the judgment of all rea≈øonable men. The fallacies of this collection, in re≈øpect of the difference both of thinges and al≈øo of per≈øons commaunded, I leaue to the ≈øentence of them that are as skilfull in Ari≈øtotle his Elenchs, as M. Powell ≈øeemeth to be. The childi≈øh accu≈øation of the author from the 8 Argument (heere in≈øerted either of mallice, or to encrea≈øe his
volume) ≈øhall be di≈øcovered in the defence of that 8 Argument.
Concernyng the Arguments them≈øelues, may it plea≈øe the Chri≈øtian reader fir≈øt of all to take a generall veiwe of the generall fraudes of the an≈øwerer in his an≈øwer vnto them.

His fir≈øt generall fraude is, that he ≈øetteth upon the≈øe Arguments, as though in them the mayne cau≈øe betwixt, the Prelats and vs were handled. Whereas the purpo≈øe of the author was not to informe the mindes and judgmeÃÑts of the Parliament, but, taking that to be already done by other books written in that behalfe, & the rather becau≈øe he did already ≈øee them to deale in the cau≈øe; he labored altogether, to quicken their affections, and to whet and encrea≈øe their zeale to be the more earne≈øt in that cau≈øe, of the equity and ≈øinceritie whereof, by former bookes touching their iudgments they were abundantlie informed and per≈øwaded. And heerin he had the more rea≈øon to provoke their godlie zeale, in re≈øpect of the manifold & mightie adver≈øaries the cau≈øe had, and becau≈øe he knew that the ≈øayd adver≈øaryes wovld make ≈øtrong oppo≈øition therevnto and labor what they might to hinder the ≈øame. 2 Becau≈øe the mayne controver≈øie betwixt the Prelats and vs is not handled in the≈øe Arguments, therefore he in≈øulteth mightily, and often (almo≈øt in every page) he objecteth petitionem principii & begging of the que≈øtion vnto us, as though becau≈øe the controver≈øie were not handled in the ≈øayd arguments, therefore it were not handled el≈øe where. But ≈øith it is handled by other who≈øe books & rea≈øons are not yet an≈øwered, neither ever will be ≈øub≈øtantially, therefore this is but a vayne boa≈øting.

His thyrd generall fraud is, that him≈øelfe committeth
the ≈øame fault in all his an≈øwer, that he objecteth to the author of the arguments. For whereas the ≈øaid author vpon ≈øufficient proofe made of the cau≈øe by other bookes, doeth make this the generall conclu≈øion of all the arguments, that it would plea≈øe the whole State graciou≈øly to releeue the mini≈øters oppre≈ø≈øed for that cau≈øe etc: this an≈øwerer maketh this his conclu≈øion, that it would plea≈øe the State to releeue the refractary and ≈øchi≈ømaticall Mini≈øters. So never prooving us, neither any other having ever proved us to be refractary, ≈øchi≈ømaticall etc. (except every Bi≈øhop be a Pythagoras, and doe alwayes ≈øpeake oracles, which they ≈øeeldome doe) yet he taketh it for granted that we are ≈øuch. Huic areno≈øo fundamento tota ≈øtrues et moles ≈øequentis Praelatici re≈øpon≈øi innititur. Vpon this ≈øandie foundation the whole frame and lumpe of all the Prelaticall an≈øwer following doth relye.

div.head: M. POWEL TO THE TITLE OF THE Arguments.
div.q: G. PowelAll the Arguments following be common (excepting one or two) and may be urged for popery or any other here≈øy etc.
div.p: Are Popi≈øh or other herericall Prei≈øts, mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, An≈øwer. in grace and favor with Chri≈øt etc. Doe the Angels ≈øo long after, and reioyce in their Mini≈øtery as in ours? Doe they as truely interprete the my≈øteries of God to eternall life, as Io≈øeph interpreted dreames for this life? May they as truely be commeÃÑ ded for the ≈øpirituall deliverance of many ≈øoules, as Ionathan did worke the bodily deliverance of the I≈øraelits? etc. The like may be ≈øayd of the other arguments. How then are they ≈øo common as the an≈øwerer chargeth them to be? This beginnyng ≈øheweth, what we are to looke for in the re≈øt of the an≈øwer.

argument.p: The Mini≈øters ≈øupplicated for, are evident to be the true Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt. 1 By the ≈øpeciall hatred of all wicked men again≈øt them: Iohn 15.19. 2 By their godly life. 3 By their gifts and by the bles≈øing of God upon their labours. Rom. 10.15. 1 Cor. 9.2. 2 Cor. 3.2. 3. Therefore the State ought to releeue theÃÑ being now oppre≈ø≈øed: becau≈øe that which is done for them or denyed unto them, is done for Chri≈øt, or denyed unto Chri≈øt. Exod. 16 2. 1 Sam. 8.7. Luc. 10.16. Math. 25.40 Gal. 3.25. Ephe. 5.30.

div.head: THE MARGINALL NOTES OF M. POWEL upon the former Argument.
div.q: a Gab. PowelThat is but ju≈øtly omitted that makes nothing to the purpo≈øe.
div.p: An≈øw.The word go≈øpell ≈øignifiyng the preaching of the go≈øpell, the furtherance or hinderance therof maketh to purpo≈øe in this matter, or el≈øe nothing doth.
div.q: G. Powel b There be other Mini≈øters of the go≈øpell.
div.p: An≈øwer. I acknowledge it with all thankes to God: and what≈øoever difference of judgment or practi≈øe there be, betwixt them and us in the pre≈øent controver≈øie, yet I loue and reverence them for their giftes and paynes. But what then? Though there were ten times as many more, and every one as ≈øufficient as the be≈øt, yet the≈øe tymes requyre all. Num. 11.29. 2 Tim. 4.1. 2 Tim. 3.1.
The note with c I pa≈ø≈øe by. When they ≈øhew our proofes not to proue our intent, we will either ≈øtrenghten them, or bring better.
div.q: G. Poweld Palpable ignorance. Many lay men, I are hated of the world. 2 lead an unblamable life. 3 haue ≈øufficient gifts, ergo They are Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt.
div.p:
Double Sophi≈øtry. 1 Whereas the author ≈øaith, tho≈øe Mini≈øters that are ≈øo hated of the world etc:An≈øwer. are the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, this an≈øwerer ≈øaith, they (not tho≈øe Mini≈øters) that are ≈øo qualified etc. 2 He leaveth altogether out the la≈øt poynt taken from the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of their Mini≈øtery
who≈øe arte it is ≈øo to clip words, I neede not to note.
div.q: G. Powele They haue ill neighbours, that commend them≈øelues. But I could wi≈øh they were ≈øuch indeed albeit they are generally noted to be great teachers and practi≈øers of v≈øury.
div.p: Wee haue ≈øuch ill neightours that as by their dayly fal≈øe accu≈øations and ≈ølaunders again≈øt us,Reply. doe urge us to pleade our owne innocency, as Mo≈øes, Samuell, Ieremy, Paule and Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, having the like neighbovrs were vrged to ju≈øtifie them≈øelues. U≈øury cannot be ≈øo truely proved to be taught and practi≈øed by us, as all men ≈øee many conformitans to be u≈øurers, Symoni≈øts, non re≈øidents, game≈øters, potcompanions etc. Yea, and to defend al≈øo ≈øome of the≈øe things.
div.q: G. Powel f Why doe you not name them?
div.p: Reply. It is needles. The namyng al≈øo of ≈øuch Prelats as haue commended tho≈øe whom they haue deprived, may perhaps purcha≈øe them as much ill will and hatred with their greater Prelats, as Nicodemus and ≈øome other had envy with the Phari≈øes, for ≈øpeaking any good word in behalfe of Chri≈øt.
div.q: g All this evidence can make but a conjecture, and that ≈øcar≈øe probable, ≈øeeing many heretikes, papi≈øts etc.Gab. Powel Haue ≈øuffered more then all this comes to, for their here≈øies and ≈øuper≈øtition.
div.p: Thus may the ≈øuffering of all Martyrs be eluded.Reply. For heretikes have ≈øuffered as much. etc. But marke heere his cunnyng. The author ≈øpeaketh of ≈øuffering wrongs, indignities etc. M. Powel ≈øpeaketh of ≈øuffering more, leaving out the ≈øub≈øtantiue of the comparatiue adjectiue more.Sophi≈øtry If he doe under≈øtand the former ≈øub≈øtantiue wrongs etc: then heretikes, Papi≈øts ≈øuffer not more. For they are worthy of what≈øoever they ≈øuffer. If he vnder≈øtand an other ≈øub≈øtantiue, then he doth ≈øophi≈øticate, and equivocat.
div.q:
h As we envy not their giftes, ≈øo we commend their paynes: and
wi≈øh they had not put their hands to the plough and looked backe.
div.p: Reply.Such good words are litle worth, where there is ≈øuch actuall unmercifulnes. Iames 2.16. We looke not backe, but they that call them≈øelues our Fathers, haue beaten & driven us from the plough, except we would wound our ≈øoules by ≈øinnyng again≈øt Chri≈øt.
div.q: i Gab. PowelIt ≈øeemes they favor the doctrine de opere operantis: e≈øpecially waighing the latter part of this Phari≈øaicall compari≈øon.
div.p: Reply.You know the contrary. Paule may as well be ≈øaid to hold this doctrine as we: becau≈øe he ≈øpake much more of his labors & of the bles≈øing of God upon them, then we haue done or can doe. 2 Cor. 11.23 The Phari≈øaicall compari≈øon I leaue to them, that take upon them Phari≈øaicall authority.
div.q: G. Powel a They commend them≈øelues to di≈øgrace other. A lying and malicious cen≈øure.
div.p: Reply. To plead for ≈øufficient Mini≈øters that haue done good is not to di≈øgrace other, but to haue all Churches the better provided for. Touching the ignorance, prophanes, irreligion, contention etc: of many places where there are conformable Mini≈øters either ignorant or idle, or ≈øcandolous, I would there were not too lamentable experience thereof. Wherfore Sir, put up agayne your lying and malitious cen≈øure into your owne ≈øheath.
div.q: G. Powel b It is not their calling, but innovation & ≈øchi≈øme that is blamed.
div.p: Reply. This is a je≈øt, like as if a man ≈øhould fall upon another & beate him that had an ague, and ≈øay, he beate not him, but his ague. Of innovation and ≈øchi≈øme el≈øe where.
(c) and (d) I pa≈ø≈øe by as nothing worth.
div.q: G. Powele As if the kingdome of heaven con≈øi≈øted in meat, drinke, or other outward things. Gro≈ø≈øe impudency, or blind ignorance.
div.p:
Reply.1 The kingdome of heaven con≈øi≈øteth as well in the abu≈øe of outward thinges, as in other matters. 2 The Prelats mo≈øt offend in that which is heere objected: in that they put men from preaching the kingdome of heaven, that will not yeld to theire outward things. To reproche
vs with gro≈øe impudency or blind ignorance be≈øeemeth not M. Powell, especially he ≈øuppo≈øing tho≈øe arguments to be written by con≈øent of all of our ≈øide: whereof ≈øome were preachers before he was borne,
div.q: G. Powelf They ≈øpare ≈øpeech for Chri≈øt. Wherfore? Becau≈øe the godly haue put on the Lord Ie≈øus. A ridiculous conclu≈øion.
div.p: A litle thing will make him laugh,Reply. that will laugh at this conclu≈øion. They that haue put on Chri≈øt, are al≈øo his meÃÑ bers, fle≈øh of his fle≈øh etc: as likewi≈øe is expre≈ø≈øed in the argument at large, but ≈øophi≈øtically omitted by the an≈øwerer: who were be≈øt to take heed he clip not the Kings coyne, as he clippeth mens words. If the godly be Chri≈øts members, doe not they ≈øpare ≈øpeech for Chri≈øt, that ≈øpare ≈øpech for the godly. Call not therefore ≈øuch conclu≈øions ridiculous, but make you graver if you can. The la≈øt note where, when, by whom, being rediculous, I di≈ømi≈ø≈øe with this merry an≈øwer, that the predicament quando is before vbi, and ≈øo is the an≈øwer of the Bedles que≈øtions in Cambridge. Solent quaeri que≈øtiones, quando, vbi, ≈øub quo?

div.head: THE FVRTHER ANSWER OF M. POWEL to the fir≈øt Argument.
div.q: G. Powel.VVe grant the refractary Mini≈øters to be indeed the mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, neither is their calling brought into que≈øtion: yea we hope they are ≈øent by God, and in grace and favor with God: yet all their giftes and ≈øanctification being but in parte, they may be over ≈øeene in ≈øome thinges.
div.p: Heere is a manife≈øt contrariety. He that is refractary cannot be ≈øuch a Mini≈øter of Chri≈øt.Reply. He that is in grace & favor with God, ought not to be di≈øgraced and mole≈øted by men. The later parte of the an≈øwer we never denyed. But are not the gifts and ≈øanctification of the Prelats al≈øo in part? May they not be, yea are they not in ≈øome things over≈øeene?
div.q: G. PowelIt is true al≈øo properly in matters that belonging unto their mini≈øtery, not to ≈øpeake for them etc. is to ≈øpare ≈øpeech for God and Chri≈øt Ie≈øus. But ≈øuch are not the things in que≈øtion, viz. Cro≈ø≈øe ≈øurplice, etc: which are laudable ceremoyes, commaunded for order and decency.
div.p:
Reply.1 As it is the duety of all to ≈øpeake for common Chri≈øtians not onely in matters properly belonging to chri≈øtianity, but al≈øo in matters of their outward e≈øtate, peace, liberty, liffe, and things belonging to their life etc: ≈øo it is the duety of all Chri≈øtians, not to ≈øpeake onely for Mini≈øters in matters only properly, and nece≈ø≈øarily concerning their mini≈øtery, but al≈øo in other matters. The liberty al≈øo of preaching nece≈ø≈øarily (though not properly) concerneth the mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell (preachyng being the mo≈øt principall parte of the ≈øayd mini≈øtery) ≈øo al≈øo to preach without givyng offence to the weake, and with out di≈øgrace to their mini≈øtery. For what hope can there be of comfortable ≈øucce≈ø≈øe where the mini≈øtery is joyned with offence or di≈øgrace? The≈øe thinges are nece≈ø≈øary though not proper: wherein the an≈øwerer committeth a great error, in confounding that that is nece≈ø≈øary, with that that is proper. For many things may be nece≈ø≈øary for every calling, which are not proper.
