Further for the whole mini≈øtery to be performed in all purity and ≈øincerity, (as nigh as is pos≈øible) according to Gods word and practi≈øe of the Apo≈øtles, without inventions of men etc: this (I ≈øay) is al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary (not proper) to the mini≈øtery, becau≈øe by inventions of men, the mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell is corrupted & weakened, even as mixture of water with wine ≈øo weakeneth the wine, that in time al≈øo it doth corrupt and decay. The≈øe thinges are ≈øupplicated for to the Parliament: If Cro≈ø≈øe and ≈øurplice be laudable Ceremonyes, then when or where, the Sacraments are celebrated without them, there wanteth ≈øome laudable ceremonies.
This is ab≈øurd and jmpious. What would further follow heerof I need not to write, we may here al≈øo noate his cuÃÑ nyng, in that he ≈øaith not that the≈øe thinges are for order and decency: but commaunded for order and decency. Many men weare long hayre, and commaund their ≈øonnes to doe the like for order and decencyes ≈øake. In like re≈øpect many husbands command their wiues to paynt their faces, thus and thus to attire them≈øelues: Are the≈øe things therfore orderly and decent?

argument.p: By the mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell the Angels of heaven receaue divine revelation to their further ioye etc. Exod. 25.20. 1 Pet. 1.12. Ephe≈ø. 3.10. Ergo To ≈øpeake for the mini≈øtery and mini≈øters of the go≈øpel, is to ≈øpeake for Angels etc.

div.head: The marginall notes.
div.p: The fir≈øt with (a) ≈øhalbe an≈øwerd afterward.
div.q: G. Powelb What a con≈øequence is this? The Angels de≈øire to ≈øee into the ≈øecrets of our redemption, ergo. The mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell is prepared for them.
div.p: The≈øe words into which things the Angels de≈øire to behold, Reply. 1 Pet. 1.12. mu≈øt of neces≈øity haue relation to the thinges before ≈øaid to be ≈øhewed by them that had preached the go≈øpell. For there is no other antecedent to the relatiue, into which. Therefore the con≈øequence is not to be ≈øo ≈øcorned by any that knoweth a con≈øequence. Heere al≈øo the an≈øwerer abu≈øeth his reader, by wrangling with the conclu≈øion and leaving out the principall confirmation thereof, Ephe≈ø. 3.10. Where it is expre≈øly ≈øayd, that Paule had receaved the mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell, to the intent that unto Principalityes and powers in the heavenly places now (not before in that manner) might be knowne by the Church (let that be al≈øo noted) the manifold wi≈ødome of God.

The other two notes touching ≈øchi≈øme and contention haue been an≈øwered, and ≈øhall afterwards be an≈øwered more fully: yet here I ad, that he doth unju≈øtly heere ≈øay, their contention. For we contend not with them, but they with vs. We ≈øeeke to take nothing from them: they ≈øeeke and take all from us. Abraham for peace with Lot (his yonger, and nepheu) was coÃÑtent to part from his owne right: but the≈øe are ≈øuch holdfa≈øts of their rites and ceremonies, that for peace with us, they will not part with an inch, though they get nothing by the whole. No marveill: for they will not parte with that which is the right onely of Chri≈øt. Let it be therefore here noted, how unfitly in the title pag, the an≈øwerer hath prefixed the ≈øentence of Abraham Gen: 13.18. Let there be no contention etc.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 2 Argument.
div.q: G. PowelThis Argument is ambiguous and ≈øavors of a paradox. For how will they under≈øtand it? That Angels ≈øhould be mini≈øters of the go≈øpell? Impos≈øible. Or that they ≈øhould be converted thereby etc? Ab≈øurd: they never ≈øinned: or that they might learne to knowe the wi≈ødome of God? So they doe by all other creaturs, and actions of God:
div.p:
Reply.No paradox at all. Neither had the an≈øwerer any cau≈øe to make the two fir≈øt que≈øtions, if he had con≈øidered the places alleadged. That which he oppo≈øeth to the third again≈øt knowledge of the wi≈ødome of God by the go≈øpell etc: may as well be oppo≈øed to mens knowledge of the wi≈ødome of God by his word. For they are al≈øo taught the wi≈ødome of God by his creatures and works. p≈øa. 19.1 Rom. 1.1920. The further meanyng of this argument, in any ≈øpeciall manner differing from other, I leaue to the author him≈øelfe: who is able (no doubt) to defend his meanyng, or ready to yeeld better rea≈øon to the contrary. But be it, that he had no other meanyng in this poynt then other men haue, yet the common doctrin of the ≈øcriptures
touching Angels in this behalfe, maketh the argument good. For the Angels of them≈øelues, know not who be elect, and who be reprobat. This knowledge before calling is proper to the Lord. 2 Tim. 2.19. The election of men is made knowne to the Angels, by their calling and conver≈øion, wherein it is ≈øayd the Angels rejoyce Luc. 15.7. & 10. And ≈øo accordingly they glorifie God, in glorifiyng of whom con≈øi≈øteth their happines. The more therefore the word is preached, and men converted thereby, the more the Angels reioyce, and glorifie God: the le≈ø≈øe the word is preached, the le≈ø≈øe they rejoyce: yea, they may be ≈øayd in ≈øome ≈øort the more to mourne. In this re≈øpect therfore, the go≈øpell may be ≈øaid to be for the Angels. So this great paradox is unfolded. The ≈øub≈øtance of the ≈øecond parte of this an≈øwer to this 2 Argument hath been an≈øwered before. Whereas he chargeth us to for≈øake our mini≈øtery for a fewe pety accidentall circum≈øtances; therein he di≈øcovereth the nakednes of the Prelats, in inflicting ≈øo materiall and ≈øub≈øtantiall puni≈øhment, for a few pety accidentall circuÃÑ ≈øtances. For ju≈øtice requyreth a proportion betwixt the offence and the puni≈øhment. But we acknowledg no offence. For we may not purcha≈øe liberty of doing the greate≈øt good, with committing the lea≈øt evill. He that ≈øaith doe good, fir≈øt ≈øaith, e≈øchew evill. p≈øal. 34.14. The≈øe thinges being al≈øo proved evill in other bookes, they are not to be accounted pety and accidentall circum≈øtances. The lea≈øt ≈øinne again≈øt the great God, is to be accounted a great matter.

In his third an≈øwer he proclameth agayne, but proveth not our error and faction. If we erre or be factious, let us in that re≈øpect be puni≈øhed (≈øo notwith≈øtaÃÑding that the people be not puni≈øhed with us) and let us be holpen
as we are Mini≈øters.
div.q: G. PowelIt doth not follow, that if the wi≈øe and judicious Parliament, ≈øhould iu≈øtly refu≈øe to deale in the cau≈øe of Schi≈ømaticall Mini≈øters, further theÃÑ only to admoni≈øh them to de≈øi≈øt from their ≈øingularity, etc: therefore they ≈øhould provoke God and Angels: Yea, if they ≈øhould take parte with Schi≈ømatikes, and intercede for them, to deteyne them and the people ≈øtill in faction, theÃÑ they ≈øhould provoke God, etc. p≈øa: 50: 1718
div.p: Reply.Indeede now you ≈øpeake ≈øure: and if alwayes you ≈øpeak ≈øo, you ≈øhall not be trapt. If the Parliament iu≈øtly refu≈øe etc. and if we be ≈øchi≈ømatiks and ≈øingular etc. then all is well on your ≈øide: But when will you proue us ≈øuch? As I ≈øhall anone proue the contrary, ≈øo in the meane tyme for ≈øingularity, it belongeth not to us, but to the Prelats, that are ≈øingular by them≈øelues, differing from the word, and from more Churches reformed then we; both in judgment & al≈øo in practi≈øe. But to returne to your other words, thus I rea≈øon from them again≈øt you. The wi≈øe and iudicious Parliament will not intermedle in the quarrell of Sdhi≈ømaticall mini≈øters further then onely to admoni≈øh them to de≈øi≈øt from their ≈øingularity etc: all the≈øe are your owne words.

But the Parliament hath further intermedled for vs etc. ergo. We are not ≈øchi≈ømaticall. Either therefore recant your commendation of the Parliament, or el≈øe revoke yous reprochfull accu≈øing vs to be ≈øchi≈ømatikes. Vtrum horum mauis accipe. I ≈øuppo≈øe you will not charge the Parliament, with any thing contrary to the commendation you haue before geiven of them; and which all wi≈øe and judicious men will acknowledge to be due vnto them. Therfore I hope you will de nobis palinodiam canere, and never heerafter charge vs as you haue done.

Here is one thing more to be noated as ≈øome what cro≈ø≈øing my former ≈øuppo≈øall, for not revoking his former coÃÑ mendation of the Parliament, yea, & making me to feare
that he will rather impute folly to them (according to the manner of ≈øome other Prelats) then revoke his reproches again≈øt vs. What is this that is to be noted? viz. That to proue, if they ≈øhould take parte with vs, then they ≈øhould provoke God and the whole ho≈øt of heaven again≈øt us, that (I ≈øay) to proue this, he applyeth unto them, p≈øal. 50.17.18. Whereby he in≈øinuateth, that they having interceded for us, doe therefore hate to be reformed, haue ca≈øt Gods word behind them, haue runne with theeues, and taken part with adulterers. For the≈øe are the expre≈ø≈øe words of the p≈øalme, which he applyeth to the Parliament for dealing in our behalfe: ≈øo indeede accu≈øing us as the principall offenders in tho≈øe ≈øinnes, that are mencioned in that p≈øalme, but yet making the Parliament al≈øo acce≈ø≈øary with us in them.

argument.p: It was a fault in Pharaoh his butler, that he did no ≈øooner remember to ≈øpeake to Pharoah for the libertie of Io≈øeph, and for his relea≈øe from his affliction. Gen. 40.14. & 23. Seeing Io≈øeph had interpreted his dreame of reconciliation to the grace of Pharaoh, and to his former place of earthly honorable ≈øervice in the hou≈øe of Pharao. Ergo

p.hi: The Parliament ought ≈øo to remember the interpretation of the my≈øteries of God his favor and heavenly kingdome by the mini≈øters now ≈øilenced: etc. That they doe what lawfully they may, to relea≈øe them of their troubles.

div.head: 1 Marginall notes.
div.q:
G. Powela This and mo≈øt of the arguments following are grounded upon a fal≈øe principle, viz: that the refractary Mini≈øters quarrell again≈øt the Church of England, is the mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell, the ≈øalvation of the people etc: wheras indeed all the contention is about cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øurplice, and ≈øome other indifferent Ceremonyes. and actions in the Church. And all the≈øe arguments doe ≈øpecially make again≈øt them, ≈øeeing they be onely di≈øturbers of the ≈øincere profes≈øion of the go≈øpell, and worke
of the mini≈øtery: yea ≈øeeing they for≈øake their calling, and moue ≈øo great contention.
div.p: And agayne.
div.q: G. Powel b would God they were halfe ≈øo diligent in a good cau≈øe, as they are importunat to ≈øow ≈øchi≈øme and ≈øedition among brethren. But they de≈øerue ≈ømall commendation etc.
div.p:
Reply.One reply ≈øhall ≈øerue to both the≈øe notes. E≈øpecially becau≈øe (as it is noted before) all the an≈øwer is grounded upon a fal≈øe principle, that we are ≈øchi≈ømatiks etc. and ≈øo worthy of all that hath been done unto us. To in≈øi≈øt therefore upon this poynt, I ≈øay fir≈øt of all, that this accu≈øation of vs to be ≈øuch, is a mo≈øt beggerly begging of the que≈øtion, mo≈øt unju≈øt, untrue, and uncharitable, never yet proved, neither able to be proved, vntill they proue the matters in controver≈øie, to be meerely indifferent to ≈øuch u≈øes, as whereto they are imployed & urged by them, yea, good and laudable Ceremonies, matters of decency, and order in the Church: yea, that we al≈øo refu≈øe to conforme our ≈øelues unto them, more of ≈øtomacke, then of con≈øcience. Much le≈ø≈øe can they ju≈øtifie their proceedings again≈øt & and puni≈øhing of us: yea not onely of us, but al≈øo of our people (a thing mo≈øt unrighteous and odious to God & men) in ≈øuch manner as they haue done, e≈øpecially more for the≈øe things (which them≈øelues call indifferent, ≈ømall, pettie, accidentall, circum≈øtantiall) then they doe other, for things expre≈øly forbidden by God him≈øelfe, & a thou≈øand tymes more offen≈øiue to other, and more reprochful and di≈øgracefull to our Church, profes≈øion, and kingdom then the≈øe things. Yea it is to be ob≈øerved, that notwith≈øtanding all the≈øe proceedinges again≈øt us, all our bookes written again≈øt the ceremonyes, (onely to ≈øhew the righteou≈ønes of our cau≈øe) and all their writtyngs again≈øt us,
none of them haue ever yet, either in open con≈øi≈øtory, or in privat conference (that I haue heard of) or in publike writing, made any one, (no not one) demon≈øtratiue rea≈øon, nece≈ø≈øarily concluding the lawfulnes, and the good and nece≈ø≈øary u≈øe, of the things they ≈øo heavily impo≈øe vppon us. Some indeed haue written again≈øt ≈øome of our arguments, but no otherwi≈øe, then the witt of man may cavill again≈øt any principle of religion, though never ≈øo ≈øub≈øtantially proved by the be≈øt divine upon the earth.

But to returne to the poynt, there is nothing in the≈øe two notes and in the re≈øt of the booke objected again≈øt vs, where with our auncients and betters,Our betters heretofore charged as we are now. haue not been charged in former tymes. Elia was charged with troubling I≈øraell. 1 King. 18.17. Michaiah might haue been charged with ≈øingularity and ≈øchi≈øme, for di≈ø≈øenting from all the 400 Prophets in Ahabs time. 1 King 22. Ieremy was accu≈øed by the Prei≈øts and Prophets of his tyme, to haue ≈øpoken again≈øt the ≈øtate of the City, and to be therefore worthy to dyc. Ierem. 26.11. Amos was charged by Amazia the prei≈øt, with ≈øuch con≈øpiracy again≈øt the King, that the land was not able to beare all his words. Amos 7.10. All the Iewes was generally accu≈øed by Haman to Aha≈øhuero≈øh, not to haue ob≈øerved the Kings lawes. E≈øter 3.8. Ezra and the Iewes with him, were accu≈øed by Rehum, Shimshay, and other beyond the river to Artashasht the King, as rebellious and wicked for building of Ieru≈øalem: Yea, they were not only ≈øo accu≈øed for the time pre≈øent, but al≈øo for the time to come, (as we are afterward in the 16 Argument in the marginall note with (r) that if they were ≈øuffered to proceed in building of the City, they would not pay toll, nor tribute: nor cu≈øtome, yea, Ezra and his companions were not onely charged to be ≈øuch, but the whole City of Ieru≈øalem for former
tymes was al≈øo charged to haue been a rebellious & noy≈øom City vnto Kings and Provinces, that the inhabitants therof had moved ≈øedition of old time, & that for that cau≈øe, that Citie had been de≈øtroyed. Therefore al≈øo the ≈øayd Rehum and Shimshay and their companions, pretended regard of the Kings Honor, in writing ≈øo again≈øt Ezra and the re≈øt of the Iewes, Ezra 4.12. etc. The enimyes of Daniell framed the like accu≈øation of him to Darius, Daniell 6. Our Saviour him≈øelfe was bla≈øphemed by the name of a ≈øeducer & deceiver of the people. Ioh. 7.12. Yea oft tymes as a bla≈øphemer, profaner of the Saboth, a frend to publicans and ≈øinners. Paule was accu≈øed to haue taught men again≈øt the law and the Temple. Acts 21.28. and to be a pe≈øtilent fellow, a mover of ≈øedicion. Acts 24.5. yea to be an heretike ver≈øe 14.

Such al≈øo haue been the accu≈øations of all Martyrs by the common adver≈øaries the Papi≈øtes. It is therefore the more to be marveilled at, that our Prelats (profes≈øing, and ≈øometime preaching the go≈øpell) doe accu≈øe vs in like manner. Yea, charge us to di≈øturbe the ≈øincere profes≈øion of the go≈øpell, and worke of the mini≈øtery, and yet alleadge no rea≈øon heerof: or at lea≈øt no other rea≈øon then ≈øuch as for which all or the mo≈øt part of tho≈øe before named, were ≈øo charged as we haue heard. For be≈øides traditions of men, antiquity (not proved, at lea≈øt not true antiquity) the commaundements of Princes (procured by them≈øelues, uncharitably mi≈øinformyng ≈øuch princes) be≈øids thes things (I ≈øay) what el≈øe haue they ≈øaid, doe they ≈øay, or can they ≈øay?The Mini≈øters not yelding to conformitie, are no ≈øchimatickes.

Doe we vary from the ≈øincere doctrine of the ≈øcriptures? Nay, rather many of them doe much more ≈øwarue from the ≈øame: e≈øpecially ≈øithens their late ≈øtrong patronizing and urging of the≈øe things: yea, they haue fallen froÃÑ
that that heertofore hath been con≈øtantly, and generally held by our Church now teaching the≈øe thinges, which haue been accounted and are in truth, popi≈øh, or Lutheran errors: viz: touching generall grace, & the death of Chri≈øt for every particular per≈øon: again≈øt perticular election & reprobation: for images in Churches,Exceter both for remembrance of hi≈øtory and al≈øo for devotion: touching the maÃÑ ner of Chri≈øts pre≈øence in the ≈øupper of the Lord: That the Pope is not the Antichri≈øt, which is the next ≈øtep to ≈øay, that he is Chri≈øts vicar, & wherby they hinder (what they may) the zeale of Chri≈øtian Princes from executing that again≈øt him in generall, and again≈øt his members in perticular, which the word partly foretelleth, and partely commaundeth to be done: concernnyng al≈øo the neces≈øity of Bapti≈øme: touching auricular confes≈øion: for ignorance (according to the popi≈øh ≈øaying, that ignorance is the mother of devotion) that it is not nece≈ø≈øary for the people to haue much knowledge, and that therefore not much preaching, but that it is ≈øufficieÃÑt, if they can ≈øay the Lords prayer, the ten coÃÑmaundements, and the articles of faith: which is directly contrary to the ≈øcriptures. Ioh. 6.69. Ephe 4.13. Philip. 1.9. & 3.7.8. Colo≈ø. 3.16. Ephe≈ø. 5.17. 2 Pet. 3.18. Who can lay any ≈øuch poyntes to us, or to any of vs? This poynt is not lightly to be regarded: yea, it is of great moment. For the Apo≈øtle de≈øcribeth ≈øchi≈ømatikes, not to be ≈øuch, as make divi≈øion onely, but he addeth, contrary to the doctrine which they had learned. Rom. 16.17. Yea in the very next ver≈øe he de≈øcribeth them further, ≈øaying, They that are ≈øuch ≈øerue not the Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, but their owne bellyes, and with faire ≈øpeeches, and flattering, diceaue the hearts of the ≈øimple. Doe we ≈øo? Nay rather we labour onely for the ordinances, which the Apo≈øtle hath taught vs. In this re≈øpect
we ≈øerue not our owne bellyes, but rather for tho≈øe ordinances ≈øake, and to ≈øerue the Lord Ie≈øus by them, and according unto them, we depriue our owne bellyes of that which otherwi≈øe they might haue; neither doe we v≈øe faire ≈øpeeches, and flattering, but by playne dealing for tho≈øe ordinances of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, we procure the di≈øplea≈øure of all men again≈øt us. As therefore this place maketh for vs, and evidently ≈øheweth vs to be no ≈øchi≈ømatikes, ≈øo likewi≈øe it doth as plainely proue them to be ≈øchi≈ømatikes that make divi≈øion for humane inventions, either in doctrine, or otherwi≈øe in practi≈øe in the wor≈øhip of God, contrary to tho≈øe things which they haue learned from the Apo≈øtle; who al≈øo therein, ≈øerue not the Lord Ie≈øus, but their owne bellyes, v≈øing faire wordes and flattering in that behalfe to deceiue not onely the ≈øimple, but al≈øo if it be pos≈øible, them that are wi≈øe.

Agayne haue we made any departure from the Church? We are deprived of our Mini≈øtery, and ≈øo thru≈øt out of our lyvinges, perforce again≈øt our wills, as any man leaveth that which is violently taken away: but though we be thus put from our mini≈øtery and lyvinges by our Prelats, yet we do not for≈øake the coÃÑmunion of the Church. The cau≈øe al≈øo why we are put out, is not for re≈øpect of our ≈øelues, but for feare of ≈øinnyng again≈øt God, and of aggravating the burden of our owne con≈øcience therby. We di≈øturb not the ≈øincere profes≈øion of the go≈øpell, and worke of the mini≈øtery, but in all humilitie, and with the wordes of ≈øobriety, we condemne the corruptions of our profes≈øion and of the mini≈øtery, mo≈øt duetifully and by all lawfull meanes (and no other) de≈øiring both to be reformed, according to Gods word. So in like manner we de≈øire to be ea≈øed of tho≈øe cloggs, which hinder both us in the
worke of the mini≈øtery, and al≈øo the people ≈øo, that they neither doe, neither can ≈øo edifie them≈øelues in their mo≈øt holy faith, as otherwi≈øe they and we would doe. On the contrary, the Prelats ≈øtoutly mayntaine and ≈øupport the ≈øayd corruptions, and in loue of them (or rather of ≈øome other matter depending upon them) they hate and mole≈øt us.

Agayne haue we loytred in the worke of the mini≈øtery? Haue we heaped benefice upon benefice? Haue we eateÃÑ and drunke, and beaten our fellow ≈øervants? Haue we ≈øought our owne, & not that which is Ie≈øus Chri≈øts? Phil. 2.21. Haue we made our bellyes our God? Haue we minded earthly things? philip. 3.19. I ≈øpeake not the≈øe things boa≈øtingly (as before we haue been charged) but onely to purge our ≈øelues of tho≈øe crimes, which the former two notes did ca≈øt upon us, and to proue that we haue not been di≈øturbers but furtheres of the ≈øincere profes≈øion of the go≈øpell, and worke of the Mini≈øtery. Therfore let them that do ≈øo vntruely accu≈øe us, take heed that he (who≈øe checke no flee≈øh ≈øhall be able to indure) doe not charge them, rather to haue taken away the key of knowledge, and to haue shut vp the Kingdome of heaven before men, not goeyng in them≈øelues, neither ≈øuffering them that would enter, to come in. Mat. 23.13. whereas al≈øo the word Schi≈øme in the Greeke language ≈øignifieth a renting, and the word ≈øedition in the latine tongue ≈øignifieth ≈øeor≈øim ire, to goe a≈øide or, a going a ≈øide: as we haue proved that in the≈øe ≈øignifications, we cannot be ju≈øtly charged with them, ≈øo let them that doe charge vs in this behalfe ≈øee and con≈øider well, whether them≈øelues may not more truely be ≈øayde to haue rent them≈øelues, and to haue gone a ≈øide, fir≈øt from the word (the rule of all Churches) in the poyntes of doctrine before
mentioned, and in ≈øome other, as al≈øo in the ob≈øerving & maynteyning of humaine Ceremonyes in the wor≈øhip of God: 2 From other Churches of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus: both the auncient Apo≈øtolicall Churches, and al≈øo the pre≈øent Churches reformed in other CouÃÑtryes: nether of which either held or doe hold ≈øuch poynts of doctrine as before I haue named: or haue or doe ob≈øerue & maintayne ≈øuch humaine Ceremonyes in the wor≈øhip of God, as are here in que≈øtion. We beyng charged with here≈øye & ≈øchi≈øme by the Papi≈øts for renouncyng the doctrine and communion of the pre≈øent Romi≈øh Synagogue, doe truely returne the ≈øame charge upon the papi≈øts touching heri≈øie and ≈øchi≈øme, becau≈øe they haue fallen away from the doctrine and auncient ≈øimplicitie in the wor≈øhip of God, that at the beginnynge was in the Auncient Romane Church, and in other true Churches, planted by the Apo≈øtles. In like mannner therefore let our accu≈øers in the feare of God con≈øider, whither the blame of ≈øchi≈øme doe not for the cau≈øes before expre≈ø≈øed, more aptly belonge unto them, then to vs etc.
Let me yet al≈øo (though ≈øomewhat perhaps out of place) ad one rea≈øon more, to proue the Mini≈øters pleaded for, not to be Schi≈ømatikes.

All Schi≈ømatikes are abomination to the Lord: The Mini≈øters pleaded for: are not abomination to the Lord, but in grace and favour with him, Ergo: The Mini≈øters pleaded for, are no Schi≈ømatikes. The propo≈øition or fir≈øt parte of the Argument, is Salomons, who among the ≈øixe thinges which the Lord hateth, and the ≈øeven which the ≈øoule of the Lord abhorreth, he reckoneth him that ray≈øeth up contention among brethren. The a≈ø≈øumptioÃÑ or ≈øecond part of the former Argument is granted by the an≈øwerer
an≈øwerer him≈øelfe in his an≈øwer to the fir≈øt Argument: yea it is manife≈øt by the good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of their mini≈øtery from God in the ≈øayd Argument mentioned. Yea, and that this argument from the bles≈øing of God upon their mini≈øtery, is of force, and much to be re≈øpected, appereth by the words of the blind man reported with commendation by S. Iohn. This is a mervelous thing that ye know not whence he is, and yet he hath opened myne eyes. Now we know that God heareth not ≈øinners; but if any man be a wor≈øhipper of God, and doth his will, him heareth he. And ver≈øe 33. If this maÃÑ were not of God, he could haue done nothing. Was this argumeÃÑt good from the opennyng of the eyes of the body of one that was borne bodily blind, and is it not much ≈øtronger: from the openyng of the eyes of the minde of many that are borne ≈øpiritually blind?

The further an≈øwer of M. Powel to this third Argument conteyneth nothing, but that which is partely an≈øwered before, and partly to be an≈øwered afterward. Therefore I pa≈ø≈øe the ≈øame by and come to the 4 argument.

argument.p: The I≈øraelits ≈øo re≈øpected a bodily deliverance wrought by Ionathan for them, that they ≈øaved him from danger of death. Ergo Much more ought this Chri≈øtian high Court of Parliament, (being not a company of rude ≈øouldiers, but the cheife flower of this Realme, and repre≈øenting the whole Realme) ≈øo to re≈øpect the ≈øpirituall deliverance of them≈øelues and of many other, wrought by the Mini≈øters now ≈øilenced etc. That they ≈øpeake what lawfully they may for all lawfull releefe of them again≈øt their troubles.

div.head: The marginall notes.
div.q: G. Powel.a Ionathans ca≈øe and the Schi≈ømaticall Mini≈øters is altogether unlike. And the urging of this zeale, having not the like cau≈øe, ≈øeemes to be dangerous. But I ≈øpare my brethren.
div.p: The author urgeth not this argument from Ionathan as from a like example, but from a compari≈øon a minore ad maius, from the le≈ø≈øe to the greater. Therefore though there be not the like cau≈øe, yet there being greater, viz. From con≈øideration of a ≈øpirituall deliverance there is no danger therin. The author by this example moveth only the Parliament to be zealous for the ≈øaide Mini≈øters, Is there danger now in the zeale, of ≈øo wi≈øe & judicious an a≈ø≈øembly? It is al≈øo acknowledged by the an≈øwerer afterward, that the I≈øraelits did ju≈øtly re≈øcue Ionathan. Is there any danger then by an example of them that did ju≈øtly, to provoke the wi≈øe Parliament, to pleade with a wi≈øe and religious Prince for the Mini≈øters. Wherin then doth this an≈øwerer ≈øpare vs, that ≈øeeketh every corner, to find ≈øomething for which he might (if he could) hang us?
div.q: G. Powelb The greater is their ≈øinne, who≈øe ≈øuper≈øtition, and wilfull ob≈øtinacy hath re≈øtrained their libertie, and made them un≈øerviceable in the Church.
div.p: Reply.Is it not a ≈øtrange thing (I had almo≈øt ≈øaide, ≈øinne) that it ≈øhould be accounted ≈øinne, ≈øuper≈øtition, and wilfull ob≈øtinacy, yea, ≈øuch as makes men vn≈øerviceable in the Church, (in feare of ≈øinnyng again≈øt God) ≈øoberly to refrayne from humane Ceremonyes, and yet ≈øwearing, ≈øwaggering, rioting, gamyng, dronkennes, whoredome, adultry, (even in the ≈øight of the world) ≈øhould not make men un≈øerviceable etc? That ≈øuch things are, in many ≈øuffred and countenaunced in the mini≈øtry, is knowne to many of the Parliament hou≈øe. If his Chri≈øtian Maje≈øtie were al≈øo rightly informed thereof, I doubt not but that thinges would be otherwi≈øe ordered.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 4 Argument.
div.q: The Mini≈øters did but their duety etc.
div.p: If men ≈øhould alwayes be ≈øo an≈øwered, when in their neces≈øities they ≈øhould require ≈øome help and comfort, in regard of ≈øome former kindnes; would not men coÃÑdemne ≈øuch an≈øwerers of great ingratitude & in humanitie? viz. Thus to be an≈øwered, that which you haue done was but your duety?
div.q: G. Powel Ionathans example is unlike unto the ≈øuppliants. For Saule in hypocri≈øy had made a ra≈øh vowe etc. But the actions of our Soveraigne are not ≈øo exorbitant, etc: but advi≈øed and ju≈øt etc.
div.p: See how wi≈øe the children of this world are in their kind?Reply. The author altogether wi≈øely and purpo≈øely (as it ≈øeemeth) concealed the name of Saule in the argument; that he might rea≈øon from the compari≈øon of the worke onely of Ionathan in a bodily deliverance, for the better regard of the Mini≈øters now ≈øilenced etc. In re≈øpect of the ≈øpirituall deliverance of the people by them. This (I ≈øay) he doth without any mention at all of Saule, that ≈øo the worke might be generally and ≈øimply re≈øpected in it ≈øelfe; without any perticular eye unto Saule, out of who≈øe haÃÑds the people delivered Ionathan. He re≈øpected their thankefulnes in delivering Ionathan from death, without re≈øpect of the per≈øon that would haue put him to death.

Agayne, I know not why the an≈øwerer ≈øhould thinke the author to meane rather our gracious King as an≈øwerable to Saule, then the Prelats, the cheife and principall actors, in all wrongs and injuries done unto the Mini≈øters pleaded for: except that either he had rather impute all hard dealing to his Maje≈øtie than to the Prelats: or that hereby he would provoke the more wrath, again≈øt the author and all by him ≈øupplicated for, whom before notwith≈øtanding he ≈øeemed greatly to ≈øpare. Further if the I≈øraelits ju≈øtly re≈øcued Ionathan as the an≈øwerer confe≈ø≈øeth they did iu≈øtly) much more iu≈øt is it, that many mini≈øters
≈øhould be releeved in their troubles. If yet they pre≈ø≈øe the author further for meanyng Saule, and comparing our King unto him (as Saule was the Lords annoynted) what is the danger, wherein the an≈øwerer before ≈øhould bragge of ≈øparing his brethren? Can he gather any undutifulnes towards his Maje≈øtie? Or can he imagine, the author to haue intended any forcible meanes to be u≈øed by the Parliament, that ≈øitting to make lawes again≈øt force and violence towardes any ≈øubject, mu≈øt therefore much more them≈øelues be farre from offering any force and violence towards their Soveraigne? Doe the words in the Argument (to be Zealous and earne≈øt) import any ≈øuch matter? Force and violence of any, e≈øpecially of ≈øubjects again≈øt their Princes, is rather of Popi≈øh fury and madnes, then of any Chri≈øtian zeale and earne≈øtnes. Be≈øides, the often mo≈øt Honorable mention of his Maje≈øtie in the Arguments, and his expre≈ø≈øe pres≈øing the Parliament to doe all in humility & mode≈øtie, (in the next argument) yea, that they ≈øhould not onely u≈øe boldnes, but chri≈øtian boldnes, yea, that they ≈øhould put forth all their giftes and graces, of knowledge, Zeale, compas≈øion, mode≈øty and humility: yea, finally, that in the preface he petitioneth, nothing by him written, to be under≈øtood of any other meanes, then good, hone≈øt, lawfull, peaceable, and agreable to every mans calling; All the≈øe things doe abundantly cleere the author from all undnetifull intent and meanyng again≈øt his Maje≈øtie. That the I≈øraelits did not in ≈øuch humility ≈øpeake for Ionathan to Saule as they ≈øhould haue done, in regard that Saule was the Lords annoynted; this is not ≈øo much to be re≈øpected, as the con≈øideration and rea≈øon, why they re≈øcued Ionathan. Neither is the Argument, by that wherein they fayled any weakened, but rather the more ≈øtrenghtened. For
if they ≈øo re≈øpected a bodily deliverance wrought by Ionathan, that they pa≈ø≈øed the bounds of their duty; ≈øhould not the regard of a ≈øpirituall deliverance, moue ≈øuch a chri≈øtian a≈ø≈øembly to ≈øpeake what lawfully they may, with all mode≈øty and humility.

argument.p: Nehemiah ≈øpake to an heathen King for the materiall Ieru≈øalem. So did He≈øter to the like King for her people, and that not without great danger to her ≈øelfe. Io≈øeph al≈øo of Arimathea and Nicodemus, (both timorous men) ≈øpake boldly to Pilate, (an heathen al≈øo) for the body of Chri≈øt beyng dead, that they might honorably bury it: yea this they two did, when all the Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt had for≈øaken him, as al≈øo when his enimyes had prevailed again≈øt him. Yet all the≈øe had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in that for which they ≈øpake. Ergo Much more ought this High Court of Parliament, to ≈øpeake to a Chri≈øtian and religious King, for the building of the ≈øpirituall Ieru≈øalem, for the ≈øpirituall ≈øtate and furthering of the ≈øoules of many depending upon the Mini≈øters now mole≈øted, and for whole Chri≈øt Ie≈øus now living and raignyng.

div.head: Marginall notes.
div.q: G. Powel a Impertinent example.
div.p: Reply. G. PowelThis note is impertinent, as ≈øhall appeare by his an≈øwer afterward, and the reply therunto.
div.q: b A foule beggyng of the que≈øtion, as if the ≈øchi≈øme of a few, were ≈øo ju≈øt and important a matter, as the delivery of the whole Church, from intended certeyne de≈øtruction.Reply.
div.p: The ≈øub≈øtance of this note (touching ≈øchi≈øme) being like the ≈øong of the Aprill bird that hath but one note, I haue often an≈øwered. Though we were ≈øuch Schi≈ømatiks as the an≈øwerer chargeth us to be, yet we ought to haue that benefite of law which Paule claimed even in Nero his time, and was not denyed it. Acts 25.12.
div.q: G. Powelc The≈øe pure Angels of light thinke all the world in darknes, be≈øides them≈øelues.
div.p: The≈øe ≈øcoffes can hardly come from a pure mind, but doe rather be≈øeeme prophane Angels of darknes, then the children of light:Reply. much le≈ø≈øe the Preachers of holines. Whether we that are depriued and ≈øilenced, are fitter for the worke of the mini≈øtery, then 5000. in the land that ≈øtand for mini≈øters, and receaue the wages of Mini≈øters; I will not ≈øay, let the whole High Court of Parliament iudge, but, let many of the Prelats and other conformitans judg.
div.q: G. Poweld An impudent untruth of a fal≈øe Prophet. They made them≈øelues uncapable of any place in the mini≈øtery.
div.p:
Reply.Let all tho≈øe that charge us with impudency, and making our ≈øelues uncapable of the mini≈øtery, take heed that one day, they be not a≈øhamed before the Sonne of God at his coÃÑ myng: and that then al≈øo the Sonne of God be not a ≈øhamed of them, before his Father and his holy Angels, and ≈øo pronouÃÑce them uncapable of the kingdome of heaven; yea, lea≈øt al≈øo the ma≈øter of ≈øuch a ≈øervant come in an houre, that he is not ware of, cut him of, and giue him his portion with hypocrites. Mat. 24.50.51. Michael the Archangell dur≈øt not blame the Devill with cur≈øed ≈øpeaking, but ≈øayd, the Lord rebuke thee. Iud. 9. You know what is written by an orator, of an orator. Ex eius ore, verba magno impetu atque ae≈øtu erumpebant, non ≈øecus ac feruentes aque ebulliunt et exiliunt. That which is ≈øayd of his words, may be ≈øayd of the reproches, raylings, ≈øcoffings etc: of this notary. But are we fal≈øe Prophets? Fal≈øe Prophets runne before they are ≈øent. They ≈øpeake out of their owne hearts, they follow their owne ≈øpirit, and haue ≈øeene nothing. Eze 13.2.3. Ierem. 14.14. They flatter, & heale the hurt of Gods people with ≈øweete wordes, ≈øaying, Peace, peace, where there is no peace. Ierem. 8.11. They are hypocrits, pretending great
holines, commyng in ≈øheeps apparell, but being inwardly ravenyng wolues. Math. 7.15. They are covetous and cruell like a roaring Lion, ravenyng the pray, devouring ≈øoules; taking riches and preciouss things etc: Ezech. 22.25. They are proud and ambitious, loving the pray≈øe of men, more then the pray≈øe of God.

Can we be charged with the≈øe thinges? Hath not the Lord ≈øent us? Doe we ≈øpeake any thing but that the Lord hath put into our mouthes? Our flattery con≈øi≈øteth in playne reprehending of ≈øinne, and denouncyng the judgment of God again≈øt the ≈øame. Our covetou≈ønes is in≈øpendyng all we haue, and leaving nothing to our po≈øteritie. Our cruelty is in ≈øuffering the manifold injuryes that are done unto us. Our hypocri≈øie is in a care of keeping a good con≈øcience. Our ambition is in the aba≈øing of our ≈øelues, beneath the parentage and education of many of us: and in bearing the ≈øcornes & reproches of the world, yea, in beyng accoumpted the skumme of the world and contemned by ≈øome, that haue been glad of the cru≈øtes that haue come from ≈øome of our tables. Why then doth this Notary call the author of tho≈øe Arguments, or any other by him pleaded for in his Arguments, by this odious name of a fal≈øe Prophet? If the Lord rebuke him for ≈øo calling us, I pray that it may not be in anger. Touching our in capacitie of any place in the mini≈øtery, wherfore are we ≈øo incapable? What be our errours in doctrine? What are our vices in life? Is conformity the cheife and mo≈øt cardinall virtue? Is it the ≈øoule of a mini≈øter, tota in toto, et tota in qualibet parte? Mu≈øt all learnyng, all piety, all gravity, all ≈øoundnes giue place to conformity? So it ≈øeemeth. For learned men, godly men, graue men, and ≈øound Divines (I ≈øpeake not of my ≈øelfe, I confe≈ø≈øe my
≈øelfe the meane≈øt of many hundreds) ≈øuch men (I ≈øay) are thru≈øt out, and ignorant men, wicked men, young men, corrupt and Popi≈øh men, are put into the ≈øervice of the Church. May we not ≈øay, Plead thou our cau≈øe O Lord etc? p≈øal. 35.1. Yea rather may we not ≈øay, Ari≈øe O Lord, maynteyne thine owne cau≈øe: remember thy dayly reproches by the foo: man. p≈øal. 74.22.
div.q: G. Powele They meane their Pre≈øbyterie.
div.p: Reply.This is but a ≈øcoff and mocke. But though we be mocked, yet let this mocker remember, that God is not mocked. The author ≈øpeaketh expre≈øly of the mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell which is for in≈øtruction, this Notary ≈øaith, he meaneth thereby, their Presbytery, which is for goverment. But more of this afterward.
div.q: G. Powelf Note this, They would haue all the Bi≈øhops removed & deprived.
div.p: Doe you gather this, becau≈øe mention is made of removyng of the lets and impediments of the ≈øincere mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell? Reply. Then it ≈øeemeth that either you would haue a ≈øharpe phi≈øitian for the ca≈øting of waters, ≈øith you can ≈øee ≈øuch invi≈øible things in a mans words, or el≈øe that your owne con≈øcience told you that the Bi≈øhops are great lets and impediments to the ≈øincere mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell. If you be of that minde and ≈øhew the ≈øame, it wilbe no ≈ømall let and impediment to your owne preferment with the Bi≈øhops, If you be not, then ≈øurely this your note is not worth the noting.
div.q: G. Powelg If we profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt and maintayne his go≈øpell, what doe they plead for then? VVherefore haue they denyed it all this while, pretending they labour for nothing but the go≈øpell, & the mini≈øtery therof?
div.p:
What an untruth is this? Where haue we denyed Chri≈øt here to be profe≈ø≈øed,Reply. and his go≈øpell maynteyned? But though we profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt & maynteyne his go≈øpell, yet we plead, 1 for the better continuance of the go≈øpell
where already it is: 2 That ≈øo it may the better be where it is not: 3 That it may be more glorified, and the better flori≈øh and fructifie in all places: all which thinges cannot be, if the proceedinges begunne be not ≈øtayd and mitigated. 4 May not a kingdome in generall profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt and maynteyne his go≈øpell, and yet haue ≈øome ≈øuperfluityes, which ob≈øcure Chri≈øt and hinder his go≈øpell; as al≈øo want ≈øome thinges belonging to Chri≈øt and his go≈øpell, which may make Chri≈øt more glorious, and further his Go≈øpell?
div.q: G. Powel.h Lo: now the Di≈øciplinariay ataxie, for which the ≈øuppliants plead ≈øo much, is whole Chri≈øt Ie≈øus. Intollerable bla≈øphemie.
div.p:
So cryed the High Prei≈øt,Reply. when Chri≈øt confe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe to be the Sonne of the livyng God. Math. 27.65. If it had plea≈øed you notwith≈øtanding, you might in charitie haue otherwi≈øe vnder≈øtood the authors words. But let the meanyng be as you take it: haue you caught him in any trap? Nothing le≈ø≈øe. For what el≈øe can be gathered, but that in the profes≈øion of the go≈øpell here in England, there are defects and wants? That the Church of Chri≈øt among vs, is in ≈øome ≈øort defectiue? And although we haue Chri≈øt in his word and Sacraments, and in other exerci≈øes of religion, yet we haue not whole Chri≈øt, in that we haue not all his ordinances? And that therefore ≈øome thing more ought to be added, that Chri≈øt may raigne more fully & ab≈øolutely over us? Neither is there any ≈øuch ataxie in the Di≈øcipline by the≈øe wordes ≈øignified. For we de≈øire nothing but the order, wherin the Apo≈øtle reioyced. Colo≈ø. 2.5. Whereof al≈øo we haue the rudera, and (as it were) the ≈øtumps yet remaynyng, in our Pari≈øhionall Church-wardens and ≈øidemen: though intituled with other names, and wanting that ordination and authority, which with
the Pa≈øtors within there owne Pari≈øhes, Elders ought to haue. This Di≈øcipline (if we might haue equall hearing) we could ca≈øily free from all ≈øuch imputations, as wherby it is commonly di≈øgraced by the adver≈øaryes therof with Princes and Nobles. Yea we could plainely and truely ≈øhew the ≈øame to be nothing prejuditiall, but very helpfull both to all Royall authority, and al≈øo to Nobility: yea better agreeyng with the one and the other, then all other inventions of men for Eccle≈øia≈øticall goverment what≈øoever. Touching the intollerable bla≈øphemie, imputed in the end of this note to the author of the ArgumeÃÑts by way of an exclamation, it lyeth upon them, that feare not openly to deny Chri≈øt Ie≈øus to be law giver and King of his Church. How it can be ca≈øt upon us, for de≈øiryng whole Chri≈øt Ie≈øus (I meane all his ordinances) I can not di≈øcerne.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the Fith Argument.
div.q: G. PowelZeale and courage for defence of Gods truth and Church is commendable: but it were ra≈øhnes and foole hardines: for any to adventure hazard and danger, by intermedling in a frivolous quarrell, and in a cau≈øe not ju≈øtifiable.
div.p:
Reply.Now you pay home indeede. If Cardinall Wol≈øey were livyng, he could ≈øpeake no more imperiou≈øly. For except by a frivolous quarrell, and a cau≈øe not iu≈øtifiable, you meane not the cau≈øe of the Mini≈øters; you ≈øpeake nothing to the purpo≈øe. If you meane that (as needes you mu≈øt) then doe you not ≈øpeake to vs poore Mini≈øters alone, but al≈øo to the Parliament, and to all other (Noble men or gentlemen) that haue intermedled,M Powels cen≈øure of the Parliament hou≈øe. or ≈øhall intermedle in our cau≈øe. Yea, them you doe not cunnyngly, but openly & playnly, charge all ≈øuch with ra≈øhnes and foolehardines. If you had been a man that in heart had not cared for the oppo≈øition of any, yet this ≈øpeech would ≈øcar≈øe haue be≈øeemed
your per≈øon. One of us for halfe ≈øo much again≈øt the meane≈øt Prelat, yea again≈øt the ba≈øe≈øt Chancellor, ≈øhould haue payd full ≈øweetly. But your ≈øide ≈øeeme to haue privilege of ≈øpeake and writing what you plea≈øe again≈øt any, yea again≈øt many: yea again≈øt the High Court of Parliament. Yea, again≈øt whole Churches and kingdoms For the re≈øt if we cannot make our cau≈øe good and ju≈øtifie the ≈øame, ≈øo that all your ≈øide ≈øhall not be able ≈øub≈øtantially to an≈øwer, without ≈øcoffing, rayling, wrangling and ≈øophi≈øticating, then let our quarrell be accounted frivolous, and our cau≈øe not ju≈øtifiable.
div.q: G. PowelThere are great ods betweene the≈øe examples propo≈øed, and the refractarie mini≈øters ca≈øe.
div.p: There ≈øhould be ≈øuch ods.Reply. For the author rea≈øoneth not √° ≈øimilibus or paribus, from likes or equalls, but from the le≈ø≈øe to the greater.
div.q: G. PowelIn the tyme of Nehemiah, the Iewes by long captivity, were in great affliction, the walls of Ieru≈øalem broken downe etc. But our Church hath long flori≈øhed, is glorious ≈øtill, and more and more increa≈øeth.
div.p:
I will not ≈øay your wordes are like to his wordes that boa≈øted ≈øaying, I am rich and increa≈øed with goods, Reply. Revel. 3.17 and haue neede of nothing: but this I ≈øay, that all beyng granted that you ≈øay, doth not hinder but further the cau≈øe. The more the Church flori≈øheth, the more ea≈øie it is to grant that, which the Arguments pleade for. Mini≈øters al≈øo of the word, are as nece≈ø≈øary for the pre≈øerving and increa≈øing of the glorie of Churches, as for the procuring therof at the fir≈øt. But alas I would God our Church did ≈øo flori≈øh as you pretend. Indeed it hath many rich mercyes, God be ble≈ø≈øed for them; but he that ≈øeeth not what the Church wanteth, doth not rightly acknowledge that which it hath. Is this the glory of a Church for Prelates to flori≈øh
and flant it out gallantly: and for their men to ruffle it out lu≈øtily? Nay rather, this is the glory of the world, and better be≈øeeming the Courts of Princes, and hou≈øes of Noble men, then the calling of orthodox Bi≈øhops, who ≈øhould as well in their life as in their doctrine, preach humilitie, mode≈øtie, and contempt of the world. The more glorious that Prelats are outwardly, the le≈ø≈øe glorious (for the mo≈øt part) they are inwardly. Yea it is to be ob≈øerved, that the more the outward glory of Churchmen (as they are called) hath increa≈øed, the more hath true & inward glory decayed. The more al≈øo, that the inward and true bewty of the Church hath decayed, the more hath the outward ≈øtate and pompe of the officers thereof increa≈øed. When were the Prei≈øts of the law, of greater outward authority, and tooke more upon theÃÑ, then when the church of the Iewes touching true beuty, was in wor≈øt ca≈øe? Serch the ≈øcriptures for they beare witnes heerof. Yea, were there ever ≈øo many degrees of dignitie in the Church, and doe we ever reade of ≈øo great ≈øtate and pompe of the Prei≈øtes in the former tymes, as there was of the Prei≈øts, Scribes & Phari≈øes at the fir≈øt commyng of Chri≈øt? And were ever things in ≈øo bad ca≈øe before, as theÃÑ they were? So al≈øo ≈øinc that, the more that truth of doctrine, and puritie of Di≈øcipline decayed in the Church, after the golden and mo≈øt glorious age of the Apo≈øtles, the more did the Church grow unto, and ≈øwell in outward riches, pomp and glory. Experience al≈øo teacheth, that the more glorious Prelats are in their outward ≈øtate, the le≈ø≈øe benefite the re≈øt of the Church hath by them; becau≈øe they take the le≈ø≈ø paynes; at the lea≈øt, ≈øuch paynes, as are mo≈øt agreable to the true Epi≈øcopall and mini≈øteriall calling, de≈øcribed in holy ≈øcripture. Wherein then is the true glory of the Church? 1 in
≈øuch mini≈øters of the word and other officers; as Chri≈øt hath commended. 2 In the performance of ≈øuch dutyes by them, as he requyreth, that is in preaching the word faithfully, in admini≈øtring the Sacraments ≈øincerely, in praying zealou≈øly and aptly according to the neces≈øityes of the Church, and in executyng Di≈øcipline wi≈øely, and ju≈øtly: 3 In the effects of the former two, viz: in true knowledge, faith, loue, zeale, humility, patience, temperance, righteou≈ønes, peace, etc. Touching the≈øe thinges, the more we want ≈øom of tho≈øe officers that Chri≈øt hath coÃÑmended by his Apo≈øtles to the Church, and the more negligent tho≈øe that we haue are in their duties, the more lamentable it is to ≈øee the carved pillers of the temple broken downe, and the faithfull workmen in Gods hou≈øe to be ca≈øt out, by who≈øe labors it had been before built & brought to ≈øome good bewty. Touching the la≈øt, what chri≈øtian heart is ≈øo ≈øtony, that it doth not mourne? What eye ≈øo drye, that it doth not ≈øhead teares, yea rather, gu≈øh out with teares, to con≈øider and behold, the me≈øery of our ≈øuppo≈øed glorious Church, by the ≈øpirituall nakednes, blindnes & poverty therof? I meane the great ignorance, the ≈øuperficiall wor≈øhip of God, the fearfull bla≈øphemies and ≈øwaringes in hou≈øes, and ≈øtreates, ≈øo al≈øo the direfull cur≈øings, the open contempt of the word & Sacraments, the wicked profanations of the Lords dayes, the di≈øhonor of ≈øuperiours, the pride, the cruelty, the fornications, adultryes, and other uncleanne≈ø≈øes, the dronkennes, the covetou≈ønes, the u≈øuryes, and other the like abominations, almo≈øt as grevous as either heertofore in the tyme, or now in the places of Popery, when, and where, there was no preaching at all of the go≈øpell? O M. Powel, and yee my Reverend Fathers, and brethren in the mini≈øtery (even of
the conformable ≈øorte, flatter not your ≈øelues in this behalfe, but behold and pity the wofull and lamentable ≈øtat of our Church in the≈øe things.

But to returne, heerin you erre not a litle, in that you confound the ≈øtate of the Church, and of the common wealth of the Iewes. The Common wealth was indeed at that time, in much mi≈øery. But was the Church al≈øo among≈øt them, for ≈øuch thinges as wheerin cheifely con≈øi≈øteth mi≈øery, in as bad condition? Had they not tho≈øe officers that God had pre≈øcribed? Were the Prei≈øts and Levits either ≈øo ignorant, or ≈øo idle, or ≈øo ≈øcandolous, as many called Mini≈øters among≈øt us? Were the faithfull and paynfull Prei≈øts and Levites, ≈øo urged to the ob≈øervation of mens traditions and Ceremonyes in the wor≈øhip of God, and otherwi≈øe ≈øo mole≈øted, as now many godly mini≈øters are? Were the people ≈øo blind, ≈øo irreligious, ≈øo unrighteous as now they are? Were the godly forced to heare dumme dogges, or corrupt teachers? Or re≈øtrayned from hearing of tho≈øe that preached whol≈øome doctrine, or urged to communicate with the Prei≈øtes in humaine Ceremonyes, to the greife of their ≈øoules, and wounding of their con≈øciences, as many now are? The Lord giue you all ≈øuch con≈øideration of the≈øe thinges, that yee may not ≈øo much labour for outward pompe, preferments, honors, dignityes etc. As for the true felicitie of our Engli≈øh Ieru≈øalem and Sion, that God may build up the walles therof, and ≈øtill loue, and delight therin.
div.q: G. PowelAs Nehemiah having by prayer and fa≈øting, found favour with an heathen King for the building of Ieru≈øalem, was re≈øi≈øted and hindred, by Sanballat, Tobiah, Ge≈øhem etc. So worthy Nehemiah in the beginning of our religious Soveraignes reigne, finding grace for the continuance of the pro≈øperous e≈øtate of our Church, begunne in the dayes of our ble≈ø≈øed Queene, ≈øo many Sanballats, Tobiahs and Ge≈øhems, as there be refractary mini≈øters and Papi≈øts, deryding and de≈øpi≈øyng us, labor to hinder our mini≈øtery etc.
div.p: The ods that before he ≈øpake of,Reply. now he maketh likes. Is this to di≈øpute ad idem, and to the purpo≈øe?

Touching his worthy Nehemiah (whom he compareth to auncient good Nehemiah,) let this be ob≈øerved, that although he ≈øpeake of the prayer and fa≈øting of the auncient Nehemiah, yet he ≈øpeaketh not of any prayer and fa≈øting of his newe Nehemiah. What may be ≈øu≈øpected or noted heerin, I leaue to the con≈øideration of the wi≈øe and judicious reader, that remembreth what oppo≈øition many of the Prelats haue alwayes made to true fa≈øting, and that al≈øo knoweth what be the thinges which men may ≈øafely commeÃÑd in prayer unto God, e≈øpecially, for which they may humble them≈øelues extraordinary in fa≈øting before God. Touching the Tobiahs, Sanballats, and Ge≈øhems, (whom fayne he would haue to be tho≈øe that he calles refractary mini≈øters, as well as the Papi≈øts,) let him not deceaue him≈øelfe heerin. For the wi≈øe & Chri≈øtian readers, are able to di≈øcerne, theÃÑ to be mo≈øt worthy of the≈øe naÃÑes, that ≈øtriue mo≈øt for mens precepts, that ≈øtudy more to plea≈øe men then God, that preach not them≈øelues, and hinder them that would: who≈øe cheefe worke, is not to encrea≈øe God his kingdome, but to uphold their owne, fearing nothing more then the downefall therof: which al≈øo feed not the Lords people, with the bread of eternall life, but their owne bodyes with the meate that peri≈øheth and with all carnall delights: who care not to enrich the Lords people, with durable riches, that ≈øhall not be taken away, but plod day and night to enrich them≈øelues in this world, and to build great hou≈øe for their po≈øteritie. Such are indeed the Sanballats, Tobiahs, and Ge≈øhems, that doe
mo≈øt oppugne the ≈øpirituall building of the ≈øpirituall Ieru≈øalem. Now although this an≈øwerer, & other not much vnlike tho≈øe before de≈øcribed, for a tyme reproch and ≈øcorne vs, by ≈øuch odious names and compari≈øons; yea, plough upon our backes and make long furrowes, yet the righteous Lord, in the end ≈øhall plead our cau≈øe again≈øt them, and bring forth our righteou≈ønes even as the mornyng Sunne; it may be in this world, that even tho≈øe that haue been through their raylings, and ≈øugge≈øtions again≈øt us, hardly per≈øwaded of us, may at the la≈øt ≈øee and acknowledge our innocency: if not, yet in the world to come, when the longer the equity of our cau≈øe hath been ob≈øcured and di≈øgraced, the more glorious it ≈øhalbe made, when ≈øome of our adver≈øaries (without repentance in the meane time) ≈øhall be throwne into the place, where is weeping and gna≈øhing of teeth:p≈øal. 129.4, and where to be indeed, is more then only to dreame thereof. Yea, the ≈øame righteous Lord ≈øhall (certaynely one day) cut the cords of the wicked. They that hate Sion, ≈øhall be a≈øhamed, and turned backward.
div.q: G. PowelWee ≈øtill thinking mo≈øt of the≈øe men to ≈øinne of ignorance, cea≈øe not to pray unto God, O Lord open the eyes of the≈øe men, and lay not this ≈øinne to their charge.
div.p:
See how this man tumbleth up and downe, and how he contradicteth him≈øelfe.Reply. Hath he not before expre≈øly charged all of us, contradiction. to doe that which we doe for carnall re≈øpectes? Hath he not al≈øo in the ≈øame place (I meane in his preface) as expre≈øly ≈øayd, (≈øpeaking not particularly of ≈øome of us, but indefinitly of all) that it cannot be denyed, but that pre≈øumptuou≈øly; and wilfully, we contend with the Magi≈øtrate, impugnyng his authority. etc. How often el≈øe wher al≈øo doth he object unto us, wilfullnes, ob≈øtinacy etc? Yea in the very next Argument, the note with (d) chargeth us with
wilfulnes and ≈øuper≈øtitious ob≈øtinacy: yet here, he ≈øayth that mo≈øt of us ≈øinne of ignorance. If al≈øo he and other prayed in truth, that God would open our eyes, then let theÃÑ not plucke our tongues out of our heads: and ≈øo thir≈øt for our bloud, as many ≈øpeeches in this an≈øwer ≈øeeme to bewray then to doe.
div.q: G. PowelIn E≈øters time, all the Iewes were in danger to haue been ≈øwalowed up by Haman, if Queene He≈øter had not interceded. I hope the SupplicaÃÑts thinke not our Church to be ≈øo de≈øperat, neither outwardly nor ≈øpiritually.
div.p:
The whole Church of one place,Reply. and a whole kingdome, may fare the wor≈øe for the ≈øinne of ≈øome one: yea, ≈øomtims long after the death of him,Io≈øh. 7:11. 2 Sam. 21. by whom that ≈øinne was committed. All I≈øraell for the cruelty of Saule towards the Gibeonits (who yet were not I≈øraelits) were puni≈øhed, even in their bodily ≈øtates, long after the death of Saule. May we then feare nothing to our whole Church and kingdom, for the hard dealing of the Prelats, towards the ≈øoules of many thow≈øands of our owne Nation? Let no man deceaue us with vayne words. Ble≈ø≈øed is the man that feareth alwayes. There is danger in ≈øecurity,Ephe≈ø. 5.6 Pro. 28.14. there is much ≈øafety in a godly feare. As for the ≈øpirituall danger of the Church, it appeareth by the decay of the ≈øpirituall bewty, and by the encrea≈øe of the ≈øpirituall deformitie, that is of ignorance & of impiety, in tho≈øe places already, which are depriued of their good Mini≈øters. How will the≈øe thinges increa≈øe in continuance of time? Yet it may be, that as the more the Aegyptians by oppres≈øion laboured to ≈øuppre≈ø≈ø the I≈øraelits, the more they multiplyed: ≈øo the more that Prelats ≈øhall oppre≈ø≈øe and ≈øilence us, the more God ≈øhall change the mindes of the conformitans them≈øelues, to di≈ølike tho≈øe thinges, which yet a litle they yeeld unto. If they ≈øhall hold their peace, yet God ≈øhall open
the mouthes of children to giue him pray≈øe, and to beare witnes unto his truth: If they al≈øo be ≈øilent, the Lord can make even the ≈øtones to crye.
div.q: G. PowelThe examples of Io≈øeph and Nicodemus, are altogether impertinent. For neither had Pilat any rea≈øon, to deny the buriall of Chri≈øts body: neyther is the mini≈øters reque≈øt, concernyng cro≈ø≈øe and ≈øurplice, of ≈øuch importance as the buriall of Chri≈øts body: for it is not true that they contend about whole Chri≈øt.
div.p: Reply.The Argument ≈øpeaketh of the honorable buriall of Chri≈øts body, the an≈øwerer onely of the buriall, leaving out honorable; Is not this ≈øophi≈øtry? Though perhaps Pilate had no rea≈øon, to deny the buriall of Chri≈øt; yet Chri≈øt beyng put to death (in part) for ≈øuppo≈øed trea≈øon,Sophi≈øtry: he had carnall rea≈øon, to deny honorable buriall: the more becau≈øe of the ≈øpite and mallice of the Scribes and Phari≈øes again≈øt Chri≈øt.Iohn 19.12 For as before, when they ≈øayd, he that maketh him≈øelfe a King, ≈øpeaketh again≈øt Ce≈øar, he made the more ha≈øt to judgment again≈øt him, ≈øo he had cau≈øe in feare of their like hatred and mallice, to be the ≈ølower in granting his body to them to be buryed, who he knew in re≈øpect of their honorable per≈øons and places, would bury it in the mo≈øt honorable manner they could. As Pilat had cau≈øe to feare the mallice of the Scribes and Phari≈øes heerin, ≈øo al≈øo and much more, had Io≈øeph & Nicodemus cau≈øe to feare the ≈øame, by performyng the lea≈øt honorable ≈øervice vnto Chri≈øt: e≈øpecially Nicodemus, being one of the ≈øame coate might feare it. If the Mini≈øters reque≈øt concerning Cro≈ø≈ø and Surplice, be not of ≈øuch importance, as the buryall of Chri≈øts body, this weakeneth not, but addeth ≈øtrenght to the Argument. For the le≈ø≈øe it is, the more ea≈øily it may be granted, and the more ea≈øily it may be granted, the more boldly it may be ≈øued for.

argument.p: If God re≈øpected the teares of reprobate Hagar, in want of water of this life for I≈øhmaell: and of the women, cruelly u≈øed by their husbands. Gen. 21.16 Malachi 2:13:14: Mat: 15:22. If Chri≈øt al≈øo pitied many in their bodily mi≈øeryes, yea ≈øome, that being heathen, were in that re≈øpect litle better then doggs; then much more this Honorable Court, ought to pity the mone and lamentation of many Congregations, deprived of their faithfull Pa≈øtors, for want of the water and bread of eternall life, which ≈øometime the ≈øayd Pa≈øtors, were wont to giue unto them.
But the fir≈øt is true, Ergo. The ≈øecond ought to be performed; & con≈øequently, the Honorable High Court of Parliament, ought to ≈øpeake for tho≈øe Mini≈øters and people, that doe ≈øo mourne.

div.head: Marginall notes.
div.q: G. Powela The refractarie mini≈øters, ought to haue had compas≈øion on their ≈øheepe, and not de≈øperatly to haue for≈øaken them for cro≈ø≈øe & ≈øurplice.
div.p: We mu≈øt ≈øo haue compas≈øion one our ≈øheepe,Reply. that we wound not our owne ≈øoules. We mu≈øt (as hath been ≈øayde) e≈øchew evill, and doe good: not commit evill, to doe good. As gold may be bought to deere, ≈øo may the good of our people. That which is heere ≈øaid again≈øt us touching cro≈ø≈øe and ≈øurplice, may al≈øo be ≈øayd touching images, if we were commaunded to wor≈øhip them, Our yeelding al≈øo would be ≈øo offen≈øiue, that we ≈øhould not doe that good, that we intend by yeelding. We may al≈øo feare the hardenyng of our heartes by yeelding, as well as we ≈øee the hearts of other by litle ≈øinnes, to be hardned for greater.
The note with (b) is often an≈øerwred.
div.q: G. Powel as that Chri≈øt him≈øelfe te≈øtified of her, that he had not found ≈øo great faith in I≈øraell. Read the place.Reply.c Ab≈øurd. The woman was ≈øuch,
div.p:
Ab≈øurd. Our Saviour ≈øpeaketh not that of that womaÃÑ,Math: 8, 10 but of the Centurion. Though the Notary were an Archbit≈øhop, yet I might intreat him, better to read the place.
But Chri≈øt ≈øayd,Mat. 15.28. O woman, great is thy faith? What then? Though as ≈øhee was elect, ≈øhe was al≈øo ble≈ø≈øed: yet as ≈øhe was out of the vi≈øible Church, the words of our Saviour might be ≈øpoken of her. Neither doth the author ≈øay, that ≈øhe was a dogge: but that ≈øhe was litle better then a dogg, & in that re≈øpect, that is, as ≈øhe was a Cananit, & none of the children of I≈øraell. Is ther no difference betwixt the≈øe words, & to ≈øay plainly, that ≈øhe was a dog? Yet the words of our Saviour are playne. It is not meete to take the childrens bread, & to ca≈øt it to dogs, or whelps. Therfore this note reproveth our Saviour,Sophi≈øtrie. and not the author of the Arguments.

The two next ≈øcoffing notes with (d) and (e) haue been often an≈øwered. We leaue not our flockes in the playne field, but are driven from them by force, becau≈øe we will not di≈øplea≈øe God, to plea≈øe the Prelats.
div.q: G. Powelf Onely Chri≈øt is the husband of his ≈øpou≈øe. Heere the ≈øupplicants bla≈øphemou≈øly papize. For I thinke they meane not this literally. If they doe, they are ≈øurely very hone≈øt men in the meane time:
div.p:
Reply. A man ≈øhould fir≈øt ca≈øt out the beame that is in his owne eye, before he find fault with a mote in another mans eye. Math: 7, 5 As Chri≈øt is the onely Archbi≈øhop of the Church, ≈øo I acknowledg him al≈øo the onely husband of his ≈øpou≈øe. For the one title, is as proper unto Chri≈øt, as the other. But heere the Notary falleth agayne, over head and eares, into the ≈øame ≈øophi≈øtry, that in the former note with (c) he did. The author ≈øayth, that ≈øuch Mini≈øters had performed the duety as it were of husbands;Sophi≈øtry the notary cryeth out bla≈øphemy, as if he had ≈øimply called them, the husbands of the churches. The author therfore, did not bla≈øphemou≈øly papize. But let other take heed of like papizing, that u≈øurpe ≈øuch names and authority, as are proper onely to Chri≈øt; and neither are, nor can be maynteyned by any other Arguments,
then ≈øuch as wherby the Papall dignity of the Antichri≈øt of Rome is ≈øupported. The latter part of the note is to loth≈øome for any Chri≈øtian tongue to reade, or cha≈øt eares to heare: therfore I ca≈øt it out on the dunghill, as vnworthy of any an≈øwer.
div.q: G. Powelg A lying hyperbole:
div.p: Then belike the Prophet Malachi, Reply (upon alleaging of who≈øe words this note is grounded) u≈øed a lying hyperbole. Mala: 2.13:14 God that putteth up all the teares of his children into his bottle, knoweth and beholdeth this, and will one day,Rom 12, 15 Iob. 30, 25 Amos 6, 6 wype a way the≈øe, and all other teares from their eyes: when they that in the meane time ≈øcorne ≈øuch teares of the godly (≈øo farr are they from mournyng with them that mourne, and being ≈øory for the afflictions of Io≈øeph) ≈øhall except they repent) haue more, then their bellyes full of weeping and waylyng, and gna≈øhing of teeth.
div.q: G. Powel.h If the refractary Mini≈øters be ≈øo unkind, and hard hearted, that they will haue no pity upon them, then may they be otherwi≈øe releeved well inough:
div.p:
The Lord that ≈øearcheth the heartes of all men,Reply. knoweth the affections of ≈øome of the Mini≈øters now deprived, to be ≈øuch towards their people, that if they might ≈øtay with their people with comfortable conditions, they had rather ≈øtay, (though their maintenance be but ≈ømall) then accept of a thow≈øand pound by the yeare el≈øe where with as good conditioÃÑs. Therfore hardnes of heart is not to be objected vnto them. Touching the re≈øt of this note, it is ≈øtrange, that in the que≈øtion of depriving ignorant Mini≈øters, according to the law & ≈øtatute in that behalfe, this hath ben the principall objection, where, or how, wil you haue their places ≈øupplyed? Much like to the que≈øtion of the Di≈øciples, whence ≈øhould we get ≈øo much bread in the wildernes, as should ≈øuffice ≈øo great a multitude? Now the
que≈øtion being of our deprivation again≈øt law, and the paucity of ≈øufficient Mini≈øters being objected, reply is made, There is ≈øtore, the Churches may be releeved otherwi≈øe. But let them be fir≈øt releeved, that haue ignorant Mini≈øters, not knowing the principles of religion them≈øelues, much le≈ø≈øe able to teach other.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 6. Argument.
div.q: G. PowelIf ≈øuch congregations doe ≈øo mourne, then the more hard hearts haue tho≈øe cruel tyrants rather then ≈øheepherds, that without pity, de≈øperatly for≈øake them, for litle or no cau≈øe:
div.p: Reply.The ≈øub≈øtance of the≈øe wordes being the ≈øame with the former note, is an≈øwered before: yet here I ad, 1 that it is more cruelty for the Prelats, for litle or no cau≈øe to depriue ≈øuch Pa≈øtors. 2 that this an≈øwerer ≈øeemeth ≈øtill to account, ≈øinnyng again≈øt God to be litle or nothing. 3. that a theefe by the like rea≈øon, may complayne of the hardnes of his heart, that had rather lo≈øe his Pur≈øe, then haue his throate cut.
div.q: G. PowelTho≈øe Congregations may cea≈øe mournyng, and comfort them≈øelues, becau≈øe there is ≈øtore inough of able Mini≈øters, and they ≈øhall haue tho≈øe, that will not run away from them:
div.p:
Take away tautologyes and other ≈øuperfluityes, and this an≈øwere it ≈øelfe would ≈øcar≈øe haue been an obular or two farthing pamphlet.Reply. The fir≈øt part of this an≈øwer, hath been removed before. Tho≈øe that will not runne away, where are they to be found? What net may one haue to ketch them, what keepe to hold them? For doe not the Formali≈øts dayly run away from their people? Doe they not take another lyving, and keep the former al≈øo, leaving one to ≈øome journyman, fit for all companyes? Yea, both Ma≈øter & man, oftentymes leave both flocks to the Wolfe, yea, I knowe ≈øome that for ≈øake their owne charges, and are curats el≈øe where under other. And to whome doe
≈øome of them leaue their owne? To one, that all the week long goeth to hedging, ditchyng, thro≈øhyng, and other day labor for his livyng: who on the Lordes day, is at Church, with a white Surplice to read ≈øervice. In harve≈øt al≈øo they take harve≈øt worke, as ordinarily as other harve≈øt men. I haue ≈øeene it, not long ≈øince with my eyes. Some al≈øo within a fortnight after they are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a living, of good worth, let it out for divers yeares, and ≈øo take their leaue of the people, to ≈øerue a cure under another. O mi≈øerable condition of ≈øuch a people. Who≈øe heart melteth not to think of ≈øuch wretched watchmen? What liklyhod therfore is there, that the Congregations deprived of their godly, loving & paynefull Pa≈øtors, ≈øhall haue other as faithfull, that will not run away from them? Touching the an≈øwer to the con≈øequence of the former Argument, that the Pa≈øtors ≈øhould rather returne to their people and comfort them, obeying the whol≈øome ordinances of the Church etc: I an≈øwer that we will ≈øo doe, when ≈øuch ordlnances are proved by Gods word to be whol≈øome.

argument.p: All true Mini≈øters, 2 king. 2, 12 & 13.14 Prov. 3.16 p≈øal. 45.12 1 Sam. 4, 21 Ephe≈ø. 6.5 I≈øai. 2:4 and 65:25: 2 chron, 14:14, 17.10:27.6, are as the Chariots and hor≈ømen of tho≈øe kingdomes where they are. In the Mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell, and ≈øincere worship of God therin commended, con≈øi≈øteth the glory of Kings and kingdomes. So al≈øo the peace: yea al≈øo their whole outward pro≈øperity. And the contempt of the go≈øpell and of the ≈øincere worship of God, procureth all outwarde calamityes of Kings and Kingdomes. Ergo
As men wilbe faithfull to Kings and Kingdomes, ≈øo they mu≈øt maynteyne the ≈øincere Mini≈øtery and Mini≈øters of the go≈øpell, and therfore ≈øpeake for them.

div.head: The Marginall Notes.
div.q: G. Powela Is a handfull of refractary mini≈øters, the ≈øafety of the whole land:
div.p: 1 Co≈ømographers in ≈øome Maps de≈øcribe a bird called a Ruc, of ≈øuch bignes, that ≈øhe taketh vp an Elephant with her talants very high into the ayre,Reply. and then letteth him fall to be broken and brui≈øed, for her to feed on. It ≈øeemeth, this Notary hath an hand as large as the foote or tallants of this bird, ≈øith he maketh but an handfull of all the Mini≈øters ≈øu≈øpended, deprived, or like ≈øo to be, for the≈øe matters now in que≈øtion. Secondly, As the lo≈ø≈ø of one of his Maje≈øties ≈øhipps Royall, or of one of his ≈øtronge≈øt holdes, or of one of his mo≈øt worthy warriors, may be ≈øayde to weaken the whole Kingdome, e≈øpecially in the time of great warre: and as the cutting in ≈øunder of one principall po≈øt, or beame or piller of an hou≈øe, doth weaken the whole hou≈øe; ≈øo, and much more is the lo≈ø≈øe & cutting of of ≈øo many worthy mini≈øters of the go≈øpell, the weakenyng of the whole land. For is not Satan, and are not Papi≈øts, and all the re≈øt of Satans army, ≈øo much the more ≈øtrenghtned?2 king. 2, 15 and 9.1. Elia was but one, and accounted (as we are) a troubler of I≈øraell: and left Elisha behind him: and yet the Argument telleth you; how they were accouÃÑ ted, though in their tyme there were many other Prophets. O therefore, that the meane≈øt able and godly Mini≈øter, might not be lightly regarded, in the≈øe la≈øt and dangerous tymes. How≈øoever they are e≈øteemed of by the world, yet they are of more price, then great riches.
div.q: G. Powelb As if God never had defended any Pagan, in ca≈øe of innocency and ju≈øtice etc:

c Outward pro≈øperity con≈øi≈øteth in pure wor≈øhip: They ≈øpeake ≈øo profoundly, as an intelligent and ≈øen≈øible man, cannot under≈øtand them: As if the ungodly flori≈øhed not ofttymes, as a greene bay tree: and the outward pro≈øpeity of the Per≈øians and Romanes, did not ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe the meane e≈øtate of the Iewes, the true Church of God:
div.p:
ReplyIf there had been no name ≈øet to this booke, the≈øe two
notes, and many other the like, might haue brought it in ≈øu≈øpition to haue been penned by ≈øome profe≈ø≈øed Athei≈øt. For (who almo≈øt but ≈ømelling of religion,) would haue objected ≈øuch things? Yea, who that had but ta≈øted of logike, would haue denyed the conclu≈øion, not regarding the proofes and premi≈øes? The wicked doe indeed, ≈øome times in joye outward pro≈øperity, either to molifie their owne hearts, or to harden them the more to be the fitter for Gods judgmentes, or to be ≈øcourges of God unto other: or to make them the more in excu≈øable: yet they haue no a≈ø≈øurance, either of gettyng, or of holdyng ≈øuch pro≈øperity. Neyther can they haue any more comfort thereby: then the godly may haue di≈øcomforte by their afflictions: becau≈øe indeed they haue no intre≈øt thervnto from God. It is al≈øo a ≈øhamefull untruth, that the Per≈øians, Romans, or any other, in outward pro≈øperity excelled the Iewes, ≈øo long as the Iewes regarded the word, honored the Prophets and other Mini≈øters thereof, and maynteyned the pure wor≈øhip of God. All that while, they were even in outward things the glory of all the world. What people ever had the like victoryes? What Nation for all pro≈øperity was comparable to I≈øraell in the dayes of Salomon, and to the Iewes afterward,p≈øal: 48:2:87:2: & 12: LameÃÑt. 1:1 and 2:1: in the time of many other Kings? Of what Citie are ≈øo glorious things ever written as of Ieru≈øalem? Read the places in the margine. Indeed after that they contemned the word of the Lord, abu≈øed his prophets, and neglected God his wor≈øhip (and that e≈øpecially through the fault of their Prei≈øts etc.) then the Lord for≈øaking them, made their enimyes the cheife etc.Lament: 1:5
The other notes upon this Argument, I pa≈ø≈øe by, as either an≈øwered before, or being of no moment.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 7 Argument.
div.q: G. PowelVVhat can a ≈øen≈øible man make of this enthymem? The refractary mini≈øters are the ≈øafety of the whole land, Ergo, the Court of Parliament mu≈øt ≈øpeake for the go≈øpell.
div.p: Reply.The title refractary omitted, he is a ≈øen≈øles man, that can make nothing of that enthymem: e≈øpecially the≈øe mini≈øters pleaded for, being proved true and faithfull. For though the go≈øpell and Mini≈øters thereof be di≈øtinct, yet he that ≈øpeaketh for one, ≈øpeaketh for both, and he that ≈øpeaketh for both, ≈øpeaketh for the land, the ≈øafety wherof dependeth upon both. But marke heere agayne, the an≈øwerers ≈øophi≈øtry;Sophi≈øtry: For wheras the author ≈øaith, that the Parliament is to ≈øpeake for the go≈øpell & Mini≈øtery thereof, the an≈øwerer taketh the word go≈øpell, and altogeather leaveth out, the other words, and the mini≈øtery thereof.
div.q: G. PowelThere are thow≈øandes of faithfull Mini≈øters be≈øids them in this kingdome, that are Charets and hor≈øemen etc. Mini≈øters are therfore termed Charets and hor≈øemen, becau≈øe they are Gods in≈øtruments for gathering of the Saincts, Ergo: The antecedent is improbable, if not fal≈øe: Againe, the≈øe men refu≈øe their Mini≈øtery, wherfore they cannot be called charets: yea ≈øo farre are they from being the ≈øafety, that would God they were not the ≈øores of the Church, and ≈øowers of ≈øedition. I meane ≈øchi≈øme and faction:
div.p: Reply.As there are ≈øome other faithfull Mini≈øters, ≈øo there are not many thou≈øands that are able, much le≈ø≈øe faithfull be≈øides us. Generally throughout the land, there are Sixe reading mini≈øters, for one preacher, at the lea≈øt by practis. For there are ≈øome that are licen≈øed to preach, that never did, are, or were able to preach. Many al≈øo that can preach ≈øeledome doe Preach. Some al≈øo that doe preach, (and that often) doe it ≈øo Popi≈øhly or otherwi≈øe ≈øo corruptly: ≈øo fooli≈øhly and ridiculou≈øly, to make ≈øporte rather then to edifie: ≈øo vaynly and unprofitably, that it were better to hold their peace then ≈øo to preach.

That Mini≈øters are called charets and hor≈ømen for gathering
the Saints, (viz: out of the power and holdes of the Devill) may be the truth in part: but yet, they being (in the places alleaged) called the charets and hor≈ømen of I≈ørael, not of the Saints, (and mo≈øt of the I≈øraelits being then wicked) and the≈øe titles being acknowledged of Eli≈øha by a wicked King, that re≈øpected not the gathering of the Saints, but the outward defence of his kingdome, by the prayers and preaching of Eli≈øha: it cannot be the whole truth. That we are ≈øuch ≈øores as the an≈øwerer ≈øpeaketh of, is not proved. Indeed ≈øome conformitans ≈øo account us, becau≈øe we rub their ≈øores ≈øo much, and de≈øire ≈øo earne≈øtly the healing of them, that ≈øo their ≈øoules may be the better ≈øaved. We are al≈øo eye-≈øores to them: but ≈øure I am, that we are not ≈øo to the godly, many of who≈øe ≈øores, God hath cured by us, and to whom our mini≈øtery hath been the ≈øavor of life, unto life. Other thinges in this argument, haue received their reply.

p.hi: The proceedings of the Bi≈øhops & other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudges, again≈øt the Mini≈øters in ≈øilencing and depriving of them, is again≈øt the law, Ergo.
This High Court of Parliament, being the chiefe≈øt Court of iu≈øtice in all this kingdome, ought to releeue them.

div.head: The marginall notes upon the 8 Argument.
div.p: The fir≈øt 3 notes I pa≈ø≈øe by; as note-les.
div.q: G. Poweld Object again≈øt the≈øe, and you ≈øhall be an≈øwered:
div.p: How ≈øhall we be an≈øwered? With words, and raylings,Reply. as before, not otherwi≈øe. To the oth Ex Officio, and to the Canons afterward.
div.q: G. Powela The≈øe men would bring in all by popular triall:
div.p:
Nay rather,Reply. would not the Prelats be glad to haue all per≈øons and all cau≈øes ≈øubject to them≈øelues? But more to
this afterward.
div.q: G. Powelb A ≈øen≈øles ≈øentence: How can a man in matters of eternall life, be ca≈øt out of his freehold:
div.p: ReplyA ≈øimple cavill, from the mi≈øplacing of a comma. The Notary might well haue perceived, that the≈øe wordes, (in matters of eternall life,) were to be joyned with the words goyng before, ambas≈øadors of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, not with the words following, ≈øhould be ca≈øt out of their freehold. This I ≈øay he might well haue perceived, becau≈øe there had been no ≈øpeech of our freehold of eternall life, but only of this life.
div.q: G. Powel.c The Eccle≈øia≈øticall judge may proceed Ex officio: (d) directly again≈øt the ≈øtatute, 1 Elizab: cap: 2
div.p: Reply.The≈øe two notes being in the margine contiguoe, and touching one another, I joyne together in my reply; the rather becau≈øe (d) the letter of the ≈øecond note, and the mention of the ≈øtatute in the end of the ≈øayd ≈øecond note omitted, they may both in better ≈øen≈øe and truth, be read thus togeather, Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudges may proceed ex officio, directly again≈øt the ≈øtatute. For touching the former note with (c) let the be≈øt Civilian ≈øhew (if he can) by what other law, the Eccle≈øia≈øticall judge may proceed ex officio, then by the Canon law aboli≈øhed by ≈øtatute. The ≈øecond note with (d) ≈øhall be ≈øatisfied afterward.
The note with (e) of begging the que≈øtion, is now too ≈øtale.
div.q: G. Powelf As if God and his Sonne Chri≈øt Ie≈øus were not pre≈øident of the religious a≈ø≈øembly already: An unchri≈øtian ≈øugge≈øtion:
div.p:
ReplyWhen the Prophet exhorteth the Church, to open her dores for the King of glory to come in: p≈øal. 24, 7:9 Cant: 5:2: did he ≈øignifie that the Church had not before interteyned the King of glory? When Chri≈øt ≈øaith, Open unto me my ≈øi≈øter etc. doth he meaÃÑe that his ≈øi≈øter had him not at all before? Chri≈øt dayly knocketh
by his word and Sacraments,Revel. 3.20 at the heartes of all the faithfull to be let in. Are they therfore altogether without Chri≈øt? Allthough therfore Chri≈øt be already pre≈øident in the Parliament, yet by the propounding of any good cau≈øe, he de≈øireth to be further interteyned among≈øt them. This the author hath acknowledged, by calling theÃÑ often a Chri≈øtian a≈ø≈øembly: by commending their Chri≈øtian zeale again≈øt the Papi≈øts etc. But this is the an≈øwerers ≈øophi≈øtry before noted,Sophi≈øtry: to rea≈øon from the waÃÑt of a thing in part, to the want thereof altogether. Therefore this is an vnchri≈øtian and ≈øimple collection.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 8 Argument.
div.q: G. PowelI am con≈øtrayned to dance as the ≈øuppliants Pipe: They lead, and I followe.
div.p: Nay we haue piped unto you, and yee haue not danced. Reply. We haue mourned unto you, and yee haue not lamented. Mat, 11.19 Neither to evident Argumentes out of holy ≈øcripture, will you ≈øubmit your human ordinances, or your ≈øelues: neither by any gentle and humble petitions, will yee Prelats come to any brotherly peace. Mildnes doth as much provoke you as bitternes. M. Nichols of Kent, writyng mo≈øt mildly and humbly, was rewarded ≈øeverely, with ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, deprivation, degradation. Our mo≈øt humble petition to the Convocation, at the fir≈øt Ses≈øion of this Parliament, received a mo≈øt rough an≈øwer. We ≈øeeke peace, and when we ≈øpeake thereof, ye are bent to warre. p≈øal. 120 7. Iob. 31:8. As though yee ≈øate in heavenly places, we haue been unto you more vile then the earth. I complaiÃÑe not thus of all the Prelats. I know that ≈øome are wi≈øer, milder, kinder, and more curteous theÃÑ other. As the bramble tooke more upon it, then the Oliue tree, Iudg. 8.15 the vine or the fig tree, ≈øo ≈øometyme it is among Prelats.
div.q: G. PowelHitherto they prayed your Honors but to ≈øpeake for them etc. Now they urge you to determyne, and actually to decree ≈øomething in their behalfe:
div.p: We neither prayed nor urged any thing to be doone, but with all humility and loyalty:G. Powel hoping that his mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øty vpon the ≈øight of the rea≈øons, why they had decreed or determined any thing (≈øo farre as they might among them≈øelues) would likewi≈øe in his Princely and chri≈øtian regard, haue vouchafed his Royall a≈ø≈øent to their ≈øuch decrees and determinations: which although it haue not plea≈øed his Highnes yet to doe, yet we hope that heerafter upon further coÃÑ≈øideration, ≈øome other may find further grace with his Maje≈øtie in the like behalfe.
div.q: G. PowelTo the con≈øequence of the former Argument: The con≈øequence hath 2 parts, whereof the fir≈øt is granted, but that the deprived and ≈øu≈øpended mini≈øters ought to be re≈øtored is denyed, becau≈øe they haue not ju≈øtified their cau≈øe, and declared that they are vnju≈øtly oppre≈ø≈øed, nor can ever doe:
div.p:
