Reply.Touching the former an≈øwer, may it plea≈øe the reader, fir≈øt to remember, that all the authors ≈øpeech of the proceedings of the Bi≈øhops again≈øt Mini≈øters ≈øu≈øpended etc: is only to be under≈øtood of ≈øuch Mini≈øters, as whom they ≈øu≈øpend and depriue, onely for ≈øuch cau≈øes as are mentioned in the title of the Argumentes, not of other whom they ≈øu≈øpend or depriue for any ju≈øt cau≈øe. Now to proceede, that ≈øuch Mini≈øters haue not yet in law (whereof the pre≈øent que≈øtion is) ju≈øtified there cau≈øe, and declared that they are unju≈øtly oppre≈ø≈øed, nor can ever doe, is not for want of matter of ju≈øtification, or for want of the truth of unju≈øt oppres≈øion (I meane only by the Prelats) but becau≈øe they haue not been admitted, to pro≈øecute the iu≈øtice of the land, nor to call in que≈øtion the proceedings of their ordinaryes: who haue been hitherto both Agents and Iudges; both accu≈øers and advocats in their owne ca≈øes again≈øt them. And e≈øpecially becau≈øe upon
preten≈øe of a Canon lately made, (repugnant to the lawes, ≈øtatutes; and cu≈øtomes of the Realme) they be not ≈øuffered by the Archbi≈øhops Iudge ad quem, to plead and to pro≈øecute their appeales, and to declare their innocency according to the auncient laudable, and common u≈øage and iu≈øtice of the land: unto which grevance al≈øo many more exorbitant inju≈øtices (by the Prelats) heereafter mentioned may be added. Let the an≈øwerer therfore vnder≈øtand, that ≈øom Ordinaryes in their publike ≈øenteÃÑces,The Bi≈øhop of Lincolne again≈øt the the Mini≈øters of Leice≈øter≈øhire. haue mo≈øt uniu≈øtly charged ≈øome Mini≈øters, with denyall of the oth to the Kings ≈øupremacy: which notwith≈øtanding, divers tymes before, they had willingly ≈øworne vnto, and which at the very in≈øtance of pronouncyng the ≈øentence, they offred before their Ordinary to ≈øweare unto agayne. And not onely thus le≈øingly, (to make the Per≈øons of the ≈øayd Mini≈øters more odious to our mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, his State, and all his people) in their publike ≈øentences of deprivation, have ≈øom Ordinaryes traduced the good name and e≈øtimation of the Mini≈øters, but al≈øo without any other ≈øpeciall crime worthy deprivation meÃÑtioned in their ≈øentences, haue they ≈øtu≈ø≈øed their ≈øentences full, only with generall wordes of generall crimes, contrary to the right forme of judgment. For by right forme of judgment, the Ordinaryes ought not to haue impeached the Mini≈øters, becau≈øe of generall crymes, but they ought to haue ≈øayd, and put in certeyne, in what thinges, and in what manner the ≈øayd mini≈øters haue done any thing worthy puni≈øhment of deprivation.

An other grevance & unju≈øt oppres≈øion (by the ≈øayd Prelats) of the ≈øayd ≈øilenced mini≈øters, is, that upon ≈øentence of deprivation and appeales of the Mini≈øters, the Ordinaryes haue given notice to the Patron of the voydance
of the Church, and upon new pre≈øentation of the Patron, haue not onely in≈øtituted new clarkes; but al≈øo (to avoyd the po≈ø≈øes≈øion of the Mini≈øter deprived and appealing) haue ≈øugge≈øted and intimated by their certificatory writ, under their publike ≈øeale unto the King, into his Court of Chancery, that the po≈ø≈øes≈øion of the church was kept per vim laicam, Old natura brevium fol 33. Que breife ne ≈øer grant, avant que leve≈øque de tiel lieu eit certifie en le ChaÃÑ cerie per ≈øoÃÑ breit de tiel re≈øi≈øtance. & withall haue prayed the Kings writ de la vi laica removenda. By vertue of which writ (upon their ≈øugge≈øtion & intimation) granted, (for without their ≈øugge≈øtion and intimation it would not be granted) the party appellant, before the appeale fini≈øhed, hath ben removed out of his po≈ø≈øes≈øion by the Shiriffe of the CouÃÑ ty. Notwith≈øtanding in truth, the Church, par≈øonage or vicarage hou≈øe, had within the ≈øame, no manner of vi laica at all: but was onely quietly and peaceably po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, by the late derived ≈øpirituall per≈øon, and his poore family.

And that this manner of a po≈ø≈øes≈øion of a Church, by a ≈øpirituall per≈øon and his family, by the law of the Kingdome, is not to be holden vis laica, is playnly iu≈øtified, by a late judgment given by the Kings Iu≈øtices, touching the po≈ø≈øes≈øion of the Church of Newton Valencoe in the Dioce≈ø≈øe of Winton. For where as a ≈øpirituall per≈øon po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øame Church, by vertue of the Kings writ de vi laica removenda, was removed out of his po≈ø≈øes≈øion, and another ≈øpirituall per≈øon put in po≈ø≈øes≈øioÃÑ of the ≈øame church; the ≈øpirituall per≈øon di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, upon the matter heard and examined, before the Kings Iu≈øtices, that he was a mere ≈øpirituall per≈øon, and that his Church was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed onely by him≈øelfe, and his dome≈øtikes, was by an other of the Kings writs re≈øtored into, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øame Church; and which Church unto this day, he peaceably holdeth and injoyeth.

A 4 grevance of the ≈øilenced Mini≈øters, is that (ther beyng a Canon made in the la≈øt Synod, that no iudge ad quem ≈øhall grant any Inhibition to the judge a quo, Bi≈øhop of Chiche≈øter & Salisbury unle≈ø≈øe he fir≈øt ≈øee the originall appeale) ≈øundry Ordinaryes upon appeales made before them, haue taken order with their Regi≈øters and Notaryes, not to deliver to the partyes appellant, any noate or copy of any act or ≈øentence, made or given before them. Where upon not onely the party appellant is wronged, but the Notary al≈øo upon refu≈øall of graÃÑ ting to the party appellant (demaunding and tendring to the Notary his fee) a publike in≈øtrument of the publike Acts and Records of the Court, cannot but incurre the infamy of corruption and perjury: in as much as he beyng a publike Notary, is ≈øworne faithfully to execute the office of a publik Notary; the execution of part of which office, con≈øi≈øteth (he being requyred thereunto) in his te≈øtimony and delivery of the publike acts made in his pre≈øence.

A fith inju≈øtice or rather nullity is, becau≈øe ≈øundry ≈øentences of deprivation haue been given a Iudicibus non ≈øuis, namely by ≈øuch Ordinaryes, who≈øe power and juri≈ødiction Eccle≈øia≈øticall at the time of giving their ≈øenteÃÑces, was ≈øu≈øpended, ≈øhut up and clo≈øed, by the Archbi≈øhop of Canterburyes Commis≈øion and his Archiepi≈øcopall vi≈øitation.

A 6 grevance or rather a nullity is, becau≈øe the whole power and juri≈ødiction Eccle≈øia≈øticall, touching cau≈øes criminall, without exception or re≈øervation of the examination and definition of the crimes of Mini≈øters, by ≈øundry Dioce≈øans under their ≈øeale at armes, before that tyme was committed in ≈øolidum for terme of life & yeares not expired unto their principall Commi≈ø≈øaryes, Officialls, or vicars generall: wherupon it con≈øequently followeth, the
≈øame Dioce≈øans having no power by the Kinges Eccle≈øia≈øticall lawes, to re≈øume at their plea≈øure their ≈øayd Eccle≈øia≈øticall juri≈ødiction, that the ≈øentences given by the ≈øayde Dioce≈øans, in the≈øe ca≈øes are ≈øentences voyd and of none effect in the law, as being given a Iudicibus iurisdictione in ea parte carentibus.
A 7 grevance or rather nullity is, that ≈øentences haue been given nullo Iuris ordine ≈øervato: but omni iuris ordine ≈øpreto et neglecto.

An 8 inju≈øtice is, becau≈øe ≈øome acts and ≈øentences haue been made and given in ≈øome private chamber of ≈øome common Inne or Taverne, and not in publico et competente foro, in any publike or competent ≈øeate, of Eccle≈øia≈øticall ju≈øtice. As M. Vinall and M. Warren, in the Dioce≈ø≈øe of Chiche≈øter were deprived, in a common Taverne, viz. at the ≈øigne of the Ounce and Ivy bu≈øh in Green≈øteed.

The 9 inju≈øtice is, becau≈øe ≈øome ≈øentences, given by ≈øome Eccle≈øia≈øticall judges, for not u≈øe of rites and Ceremonyes, or not ob≈øerving of the booke of Common prayer, haue not been given according to the tenor of and effect of the ≈øtatute of the fir≈øt of our late Queene, vpon inqui≈øition, information, or accu≈øation, but only upon proces ex mero officio. A thing if not directly, yet by con≈øequence repugnant to the ≈øayd ≈øtatute; and therefore unwarrantable by the ≈øayd ≈øtatute. And therefore it is to be noted, that this marginall note (the Eccle≈øia≈øticall judge may proceed ex officio) in pag 37. and this pareÃÑthe≈øis (which they may doe ex officio) in≈øerted in the body of the ≈øtatute pag 42. is but a begging of the que≈øtion.Certain Mini≈øters in the Dioces of Oxford & Lichfeld etc.

An other inju≈øtice again≈øt ≈øome Mini≈øters hath been coÃÑ mitted by ≈øome ordinaries, for that they haue deprived them for none other cau≈øe, then only for not ≈øub≈øcribing
to the 3 articles, mentioned in the 36. Canon. And this wrong hath been openly in Parliament acknowledged, to be a wrong by the Archbi≈øhop him≈øelfe, and by the Iudges and advocats of his owne Courts.

The≈øe and many ≈øuch like thinges being thus, may it not be truely ≈øayd, that the Mini≈øters pleaded for are unju≈øtly oppre≈ø≈øed? And being ≈øo oppre≈ø≈øed and without releefe any other way, haue they not ju≈øt cau≈øe to ≈øupplicat to the High Court of Parliament? And hath not the ≈øayd High Court great rea≈øon, yea is it not bound to finde remedy, and to releeue them?

The an≈øwer concernyng the per≈øon of him who is ≈øayd abundantly to haue proved the unlawfulnes of the proceedings again≈øt the deprived mini≈øters, that he is no iudge nor any good Civilian or common lawyer, what rea≈øon haue you to be ≈øo re≈øolut heerin? He may be a judge, a good Civilian, or coÃÑmon lawyer for ought you knowe, though you ≈øeeme never ≈øo doubtles therof. But what is this an≈øwer to the poynt in que≈øtion? Seeing it mattereth not, what the per≈øon of the probator be, if his proofes be ≈øufficient? And yet how meane ≈øo ever you thinke him, or his learning to be (if he be the party whom I ayme at) I ≈øhall doe no wrong (as I ≈øuppo≈øe to the cheefe≈øt judge, and be≈øt approved Civilian, of the now Archbi≈øhop of Canterburyes courts, if (without flattering the party) I ≈øhall affirme that he was a ≈øtudent and an advocate, and a Iudge, yea, I may (as I thinke) ≈øay more, a reader of and a director in the practi≈øe of the civill law about 30 yeares pa≈ø≈øed, to ≈øoÃÑe that be now Doctors of the ≈øame law.

But to let the per≈øon and learnyng of the probator pa≈ø≈øe, I re≈øolutely and directly an≈øwer to the an≈øwerers 3. Queres (the ≈øame being partly fraught with equivocations,
and partly childi≈øh and ab≈øurd,) that the one ≈øorte can receaue no re≈øolute an≈øwer, before he haue re≈øolved his intrin≈øecall and mentall ≈øen≈øe and under≈øtanding, and that the other without que≈øtion, is a que≈øtion que≈øtionles. His fir≈øt Quere then being this, namely, Quere. 1 whether the Church under Chri≈øtian godly Magi≈øtrats, hath any tribunall proper unto it ≈øelfe, for the decyding of controver≈øies, and puni≈øhing of ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhall refu≈øe the ordinances therof? Unto this Quere, when he ≈øhall di≈øtingui≈øh and make his ≈øo many equivocations (conteyned in the Quere) pre≈øpicuous and playne,Equivocations. to the under≈øtanding of every ≈øimple & playne meanyng man, I ≈øhall (God willing) make him a ≈øimple, playne, re≈øolute, & direct an≈øwer. In the meane time let him under≈øtand, fir≈øt that we may ju≈øtly doubt, what he meaneth by the word Church: and namely, whether he meane the vniver≈øall Church, or a Nationall, a Provinciall, a Dioce≈øaÃÑ, an Archidiaconall, a Decanall, a Capitular, or la≈øtly a Parochiall Church. For all men (as u≈øually and commonly we ≈øpeake) doe vnder≈øtand, that every of the≈øe Churches, hath her proper name, after which ≈øhe is ≈øo called: as namly the Church di≈øper≈øed throughout the world, is called the univer≈øall Church, the Church within England is commonly called the Nationall Church of England; the Church within the Province of Canterbury, the Provinciall Church of Canterbury, the Church of the Dioce≈ø≈øe of London, the Dioce≈øan Church of London, etc. And la≈øtly the Church of great S. Ellens in London, the Parochiall Church of S. Ellens in London. And therefore I craue a re≈øolute and direct an≈øwer, of what onely per≈øons you meane that the univer≈øall, this Nationall, Provinciall, Dioce≈øan, Archidiaconall, Decanall, Capitular, and Parochiall Church con≈øi≈øteth? Who onely be the Chri≈øtian godly Magi≈øtrats, under whom every one of the≈øe
Churches liveth? Whether the ≈øame chri≈øtian godly Magi≈øtrates may per≈øonally be pre≈øent, giue their expre≈ø≈øe con≈øents, and haue their deci≈øive voyces, to & in making all and every decrees of every of the≈øe Churches? What is the tribunall proper to it ≈øelfe, of every of the≈øe Churches? What onely manner of controver≈øies, by every of the≈øe Churches may be decided? What onely kind of ordinances, every of the≈øe Churches may decree? What only kind of ≈øubject, and with what onely kind of puni≈øhment, and none other, every of the≈øe Churches may puni≈øh the refu≈øers of every their ordinances?

Our ≈øecond mayne ≈øcruple, touching this fir≈øt Quere, ari≈øeth from the≈øe words (vnder Chri≈øtian godly Magi≈øtrats) For if by the≈øe words (under Chri≈øtian godly Magi≈øtrats) he under≈øtand that every of the≈øe Churches, livyng under the obey≈øance of ≈øuch Magi≈øtrats, hath a tribunall proper unto it ≈øelfe, immediatly derived to the ≈øame by the holy law of God, wholly ≈øecluded from the Chri≈øtian godly Magi≈øtrats pre≈øence (as was the Sanctuary divided from the Court) and wherinto the chri≈øtian godly Magi≈øtrats may no more at this day enter, or no more giue their con≈øents and deci≈øiue voyces, in making the ordinances therof, then it was lawfull in times pa≈øt for the Kings of Iuda to enter into the holy place, and to burne incen≈øe at the Altar: then mu≈øt we frame him one kinde of reply: but if he ≈øhall informe us, his mentall vnder≈øtanding to be thus, namely that the Chri≈øtian godly Magi≈øtrats, haue none other power, by law divine or human, but only to a≈ø≈øemble every of the ≈øayd Churches, to ratifie the ordinances of every of the ≈øayd Churches, or hath onely power to commaund the ≈øame ordinances to be put in execution under them, then unto this an≈øwer we mu≈øt ≈øhape him
an other manner of reply. Notwith≈øtanding, in the meaÃÑe tyme this he mu≈øt under≈øtand generally, that in right (though not alwayes in po≈ø≈øes≈øion & practi≈øe) the church beyng di≈øtingui≈øhed from the common wealth, hath the ≈øame power under a Chri≈øtian, and under an Infidell Magi≈øtrat.
div.q: Quere. 2 G. Powel2 Quere. Whether ≈øo many judiciall acts of deprivation of Bi≈øhops from their benefices ≈øince the conque≈øt, to the time of Magna Charta, and ≈øince that to this age, were ever held to be contrary to the lawes of this Kingdome?
div.p: To dance after your Pipe, (I will not ≈øay, what a fooli≈øh and ridiculous que≈øtion,Reply. but) what an od tune is this? For can a man dance after a pipe, before the Pipe be ≈øtriken up? So could acts done before Magna Charta, and other lawes ≈øince made, be ≈øayd to be contrary to them? This is as much, as one ≈øhould aske, whether Adam not Circumci≈øing Cain and Abell, did contrary to the law given for Circumci≈øion, to Abraham many yeares after? Or whither I≈øhmael per≈øecuted I≈øaack, before I≈øack was borne? Or whether ≈øtealing of hor≈øes an hundred yeares pa≈øt, were puni≈øhable with death, before any law made for death in that behalfe? One thing cannot be ≈øayd contrary to an other, that is not, neyther ever was extant in rerum natura. The Second part of this Quere, whether ≈øince the granting of Magna Charta unto this age, the judiciall acts of deprivation of Bi≈øhops etc: were ever held to be contrary to the law of this kingdome, and Magna Charta, we ≈øhall an≈øwer (if God permit) more plentifully anone.
div.q: Quere. 3 G. Powel 3 Quere. Whether any Iudge of this Realme, or any cheife officer lerned in the lawes, be of opinion, that ≈øuch ≈øentences of deprivation, as haue lately pa≈ø≈øed in due forme, in any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Court, be contrary to any, much le≈ø≈øe to many ≈øtatuts.
div.p:
Reply.Though it were a ≈øufficient an≈øwer to bid him goe
looke, and him≈øelfe to aske the opinion of every judge & learned officer, yet will I not altogether yeld him ≈øo ≈øhort and cutted an an≈øwer. And though it be a principle in Philo≈øophy, that forma dat e≈ø≈øe rei, yet to the beyng of every thing there mu≈øt be matter, to which the forme giveth being. And therefore in this ca≈øe, be≈øides due forme, there mu≈øt be al≈øo due matter, in≈øerted in due ≈øentences. Wherupon I craue a re≈øolute and direct an≈øwer, whether by tho≈øe words (pa≈ø≈øed in due forme) he meane pa≈ø≈øed for matter and forme, in due forme? Or whether he meane, pa≈ø≈øed without due matter in due forme onely? For if he meane by pa≈ø≈øed, (for matter and forme,) in due forme, then is his que≈øtion (without que≈øtion) either a fooli≈øh que≈øtion, or no que≈øtion at all. For who would que≈øtion, whether any Iudge or learned officer, could doubt, that a ≈øentence pa≈ø≈øed for matter, and forme in due forme, were a ≈øentence contrary to any, much le≈ø≈øe to many ≈øtatuts? As though there were any Statuts ≈øo ridiculous and ab≈øurd? On the other ≈øide, if he meane by pa≈ø≈øed in due forme, only due forme without due matter, then we an≈øwer that the ≈øame ≈øentence may be unju≈øt, for want of due matter, and yet be ju≈øt by rea≈øon of due forme. And ≈øo on the other parte, we affirme, that a ≈øentence may be iu≈øt, by rea≈øon of due matter, and yet unju≈øt by rea≈øon of an undue forme. How many ≈øentences therefore of deprivation ≈øoever, as haue been lately given without due and ju≈øt matter, or without due and iu≈øt forme, we an≈øwer ≈øo many not to haue pa≈ø≈øed in due matter and forme, and ≈øo contrary to ≈øome lawes or ≈øtatuts. But were this que≈øtion wholly graÃÑ ted, what ea≈øe and advantage can the opinion of any iudg or learned officer yeeld to tho≈øe Iudiciall acts of deprivation (wherupon the controver≈øie is grounded) which are
not pa≈ø≈øed in any due forme of any law, or Statute Eccle≈øia≈øticall what≈øoever?

Furthermore touching this que≈øtion, if the Prelats did intend that all their ≈øenteÃÑces ≈øhould be according to law, wherfore did they make a Canon again≈øt the ordinary pro≈øecution of appeales? Yea, what needed ≈øuch a Canon? What benefite is there to any appellant by his appeale, from a ju≈øt ≈øentence? Or what danger to the Iudge a quo by ≈øuch appeales? The whole danger is to the appellant him≈øelfe. For the ≈øentence beyng ju≈øt, he ≈øhall be ≈øure to get nothing, neither the Iudge a quo to lo≈øe any thing by the appeale.
div.q: G. Powel.VVho having but halfe an eye, doth not ≈øee, but that (by pleading Magna Charta cap. 29:) they would not onely weaken, but al≈øo ≈øubvert and utterly overthrow all jurisdiction Eccle≈øia≈øticall?
div.p: Doth every one that de≈øireth limitation of Eccle≈øia≈øticall jurisdiction,Reply. and laboreth to re≈øtrayne it from all communion of forreyne lawes, ≈øeeke the ≈øubver≈øion therof? If al≈øo the lawes Eccle≈øia≈øticall, be the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall lawes, and the jurisdiction Eccle≈øia≈øticall, the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall jurisdiction, then is this place of Magna Charta, ≈øo farre from ≈øubverting the jurisdiction or law Eccle≈øia≈øticall, as that by that place, the ≈øame law and jurisdiction is up held, and more throughly e≈øtabli≈øhed. That the law & jurisdiction Eccle≈øia≈øtical ever hath been, and yet is accounted the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall law and juridiction ≈øhall be ≈øhewed anone.
div.q: G. PowelThe ≈øentences and graue determinations whereof (that is of Eccle≈øia≈øticall jurisdiction) haue never yet in any age or Country, been ≈øubmitted to popular triall, by the judgment of Peeres etc:
div.p:
ReplyAll ≈øent ces of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts, are not ≈øo graue but that ≈øome are ≈øomtymes repealed by Higher courts, and ≈øometymes revoked by them≈øelues. Sometyme al≈øo
they meddle with matters not belonging unto them, and therfore by ordinary cour≈øe of Commmon law, they are prohibited to proceed. Finally in ≈øome ca≈øe the Bi≈øhop giveth not In≈øtitution to a benefice, untill by a Iury of 12. men (whereof 6. are to be of the Clergy, and 6 of the Layity) the controver≈øie de iure patronatus be decided. Yea ≈øometyme the Bi≈øhop having in≈øtituted a clarke, is forced by writ from the common law, to admit of another clark pre≈øented by another Patrone, and ≈øo to di≈øplace him whom before he had in≈øtituted.
div.q: G. PowelThe place of Magna Charta, cannot be under≈øtood of Eccle≈øia≈øticall jurisdiction, or the practi≈øe thereof, e≈øpecially if we con≈øider the end why this law was made, and the tyme when:
div.p: The Prelats ≈øhould make ≈øure worke indeed,Reply. if they could make, that no lawes were again≈øt their power. TheÃÑ might they take upon them without controlment, what they would under coloure of Eccle≈øia≈øticall iurisdiction: as indeed they doe now pretily beginne to doe.
div.q: G. PowelThe end was, that the Kings of this Realme, might not challenge an infinit and ab≈øolute power, (as ≈øome Kings el≈øe where did, and yet doe) without judgment and lawfull proceedings, to take away any mans liberty, life, Country, goods, or lands.
div.p: Then belike the Kings Maje≈øtie is re≈øtrayned by Magna Charta, but the Prelacy is not.Reply. Is not this good ≈øtuffe? The King ≈øhall weare the Crowne, but the Prelats will beare the ≈øword. Whether now doe they that are fal≈øely called Puritans, or the Prelats mo≈øt encroch upon the Royall authoritye?
div.q: G. PowelIt was made at ≈øuch time, as the Kings thought Eccle≈øia≈øticall jurisdiction, no more in right then in fact, to belong to the Crowne. Therfore the words haue no relation to Eccle≈øia≈øticall jurisdiction.
div.p:
This is utterly fal≈øe:Reply yea the fal≈øhood therof is evident by the te≈øtimony of that worthy and renowned Lawyer S. Edward Cooke, in the booke alleadged by the an≈øwerer.
For he ≈øayth expre≈øely, that as in temporall cau≈øes, the King by the mouth of Iudges in his Courts of Iu≈øtice, doth iudge the ≈øame by the temporall lawes of England; lib. de jure regis Eccle. fol: 8 ≈øo in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall etc. (the connu≈øance wherof doth not belong to the common lawes of England) the ≈øame are to be iudged and determyned, by Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudges, according to the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall lawes, etc.

fol. 39And againe, ob≈øerue good reader, (≈øayth S. Edward Cooke) ≈øeeyng that the determination of here≈øies etc. belongeth not to the Common law, how nece≈ø≈øary it was for admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice, that his Maie≈øties progenitors Kings of this Realme, did by publike authority authorize Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts under theÃÑ, to determyne tho≈øe great and important cau≈øes, etc. by the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall lawes. The jurisdiction therfore, Courts, and lawes Eccle≈øia≈øticall, in the opinion of the Kings progenitors were thought & held to be their own Kingly lawes, Courts, and jurisdiction. The ≈øame is further proved by the ≈øayd S. Edward Cooke: fol. 9 by the pre≈øident of Renulphus, in di≈øcharging and exempting the Mona≈øtery and Abbot of Abinden, from the jurisdiction of the Bi≈øhops and granting al≈øo to the ≈øaide Abbot Eccle≈øia≈øticall jurisdiction etc: by the pre≈øident of William the fir≈øt,fol 10.11: who made inpropriatioÃÑ of Churches with cure, to Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øons etc. and by divers pre≈øidents of other Kings ≈øince the conque≈øt.

That which in this parte of the an≈øwer, is afterward added of the nece≈ø≈øary re≈øtitution of the right of Eccle≈øia≈øticall jurisdiction, to the Crowne is al≈øo confuted by the ≈øame S. Edward Cooke, who plainely ≈øaith, that though there had been no ≈øuch law of re≈øtitution made, yet it was re≈øolved by all the Iudges, that the Kings and Queenes of EnglaÃÑd for the tyme being, by the auncient prerogatiue law of England, may make ≈øuch a Commi≈øion etc. And therfore by the auncient
lawes of this Realme, this kingdome of England is and ab≈øolute Empire, and Monarchy, con≈øi≈øting of one head, which is the King, and of a body politike, &c. Al≈øo that the Kingly head of this body politike is furni≈øhed with plenary power. &c. to render iu≈øtice and right, to every part and member of this body. Thus farre S. Edward Cooke. From all which it followeth, that the re≈øtitution of the auncient right, how≈øoever lawfully made (as being made by the whole body of the kingdome) was notwith≈øtaÃÑding not nece≈ø≈øarily made, as though without it, the King or Queene, for the tyme being, could not haue u≈øed their auncient right.

That which followeth in the 2. 3. and 4. branches of this 4 an≈øwer to the con≈øequence of this 8 Argument, doth not belong to the matter, becau≈øe it doth nothing ju≈øtifie the proceedings of the Bi≈øhops or other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudges, in depriving of the Mini≈øters pleaded for, in ≈øuch manner and for ≈øuch cau≈øes, as for which they haue depriveded them. The que≈øtion is not whether jurisdiction Eccle≈øia≈øticall by the lawes of the land doth be long (under the King) unto the ordinaryes: nor whether the Ordinaryes in the exerci≈øe of the Kings jurisdiction Eccle≈øiia≈øticall, and Con≈øi≈øtoriall trialls, ought to proceed by vertue of Peeres, etc: but whether ≈øome Ordinaryes, exerci≈øing the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall jurisdiction, haue proceeded in their Eccle≈øia≈øticall Con≈øi≈øtories, again≈øt ≈øome Mini≈øters, without authority of the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall law: & therfore in that re≈øpect, contrary to Magna Charta, which requyreth nothing to be doone without the Kings law.

Further,De jure Regis Eccle≈øi. fol. 9 although we grant (as S. Edw. Cooke in≈øtructeth us) all lawes Eccle≈øia≈øticall derived from other (which by and with a generall con≈øent are approved and allowed here) to be aptly and rightly called the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall
lawes of England: yet I deny that all lawes Eccle≈øia≈øticall, derived by the Kings progenitors, either before or ≈øince the Conque≈øt from others, are now in this age our Soveraigne Lord King Iames his Eccle≈øia≈øticall lawes: and therefore how≈øoever many judiciall Acts of deprivation, of Bi≈øhops & Prei≈øts, from their benefices &c. according to the Eccle≈øia≈øticall law, which is called ius Pontificium, & which was derived, by the Kings Progenitors, from the Bi≈øhops of Rome, either before, or ≈øince the Conque≈øt, unto Magna Charta, and ≈øince that, to the 25 of King Henry the eyght, were never, all held, to be contrary, but were ever all held, to be agreable to the lawes of this kingdome: yet notwith≈øtanding, I affirme that all Iudiciall Acts and ≈øentences,25. Hen. 8 cap. 17 (how many ≈øoever, of deprivation of Mini≈øters, from their benefices) had made and given, by the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudges, ≈øince the 25. of King Henry the 8. onely according, or onely by force, and vertue of the ≈øayd ius Pontificium, or Bi≈øhop of Rome his law, (the ≈øentences given in the time of Queene Mary excepted) are, and ought to be holden, not to be had, made & given, by the lawes of this kingdome, or by the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall law: And why? Even becau≈øe the whole ius Pontificium, or Bi≈øhop of Romes law was altogether (excepting the tyme of Queene Mary) abrogated, adnulled, and made voyd, by an Act of Parlament; and con≈øequently is but a meere Alien, Forraine and ≈øtraunge law, and no municipall law of England, and therefore not the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øticall law.

Wherefore our Soveraigne Lord King Iames, by this graunt of Magna Charta made by his progenitors, beyng obliged, to ≈øuffer no Free man of the Realme, to be taken or impri≈øoned, or di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øed of his Frrehold, or liberties, &c. Nor to pa≈ø≈øe upon him nor condemne him, but by
lawfull judgment of his Peeres, or by the law of the land. We agayne a≈ø≈øume from this ≈øtatute of the great Charter, that ≈øundry ≈øentences of deprivation of Mini≈øters, from their benefices, for cau≈øes before ≈øpecified, are unlawfull; becau≈øe ≈øuch Mini≈øters haue been condemned, and judgment hath been pa≈ø≈øed upon them, without lawfull judgment of their Peeres, or law Eccle≈øia≈øticall of the land. For heere we mu≈øt giue the an≈øwerer to witt, by the≈øe words, (or law of the land,) that all the Kings lawes, of what nature or quality ≈øoever, whether Eccle≈øia≈øticall or temporall, and not only the lawes temporall, (as he in≈øinuateth) are included. As therefore no temporall Free man of the Realme, may be condemned, pa≈ø≈øed upon, or di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øed of his liberty, and freehold, &c. in a temporall cau≈øe, and in a temporall Court, without lawfull judgment of his Peeres, or temporall law of the land. Even ≈øo likewi≈øe, no Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øon, (beyng a freeman of the Realme) may be condemned, pa≈ø≈øed upon, or di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øed of his liberty, or frehold, but by lawfull Eccle≈øia≈øticall judgement, according to the law Eccle≈øia≈øticall of the land. And heereupon we graunt, if the King haue any law Eccle≈øia≈øticall of the laÃÑd, for the deprivation of a Mini≈øter, from his liberty and frehold, for not ≈øub≈øcription, perjurie, contempt of Canonical (≈øo called obedience, omis≈øion of Rites, and Ceremonyes, not preci≈øe ob≈øervation of the booke of Common prayer &c. Then we graunt, that the Ordinaryes (being the Kings Iudges Eccle≈øia≈øticall) may rightly depriue a Mini≈øter from his benefice, for the≈øe offences.

And yet ≈øtill we deny, and ≈øhall be able to mainteyne, that ≈øundry ≈øentences of deprivation, made and given, by ≈øundry Ordinaries, again≈øt ≈øvndry Mini≈øters, be either unju≈øt or unlawfull; or no ≈øentences at all, for the rea≈øons and
cau≈øes before ≈øpecified.

It is therefore erroniou≈øly alleadged, that that which was done by jurisdiction Eccle≈øia≈øticall, when Magna Charta was granted, was not at that tyme taken to be done by the King, or by his authority, and that the lawes which Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudges practi≈øed, were not then held, to be the lawes of the land, or the Kings lawes. For the Kings progenitors, did both thinke and held, that jurisdiction Eccle≈øia≈øticall did in right belong unto their Crowe, and therefore in fact, by right of their crownes, did they both exerci≈øe, and commaund to be exerci≈øed, in their Kingly names, their Kingly right, authority and jurisdiction Eccle≈øia≈øticall within their Realmes. For how could tho≈øe Kings, haue commaunded, and how could their ≈øubjectes haue obeyed, if the Kings them≈øelues, had thought, and held, that the Ecele≈øia≈øticall courts, lawes or jurisdiction, were not in right, no more then in fact, at that tyme belonging unto the Crowne as the an≈øwerer, vaynly, and childi≈øhly fancyeth? Which fancy al≈øo ≈øeemeth ≈øufficieÃÑtly confuted by the very title of S. Edward Cooks booke, de iure regis Eccle≈øia≈øtico. For how could the Kings before and after the Conque≈øt unto Magna Charta have been ju≈øtly intituled to Kingly right of Eccle≈øia≈øticall juri≈ødiction, if the Kings had no Kingly Eccle≈øia≈øticall right, or juri≈ødiction at all.
div.q: G. Powel.Breifely, the lawfullnes of they deprivation, of the refractary Mini≈øters. is a plaine ca≈øe adjudged, in open Court, as appeareth in S. Edward Cookes Report part 5 in Cawdries ca≈øe according to a Statute of I. Elizab. cap 2. &c.
div.p: It is a mo≈øt playne and cleere ca≈øe, that neither the ca≈øe of Cawdrie, Reply. is the ca≈øe of ≈øundry the late deprived Mini≈øters; nor that the ca≈øe of ≈øundry the late deprived Mini≈øters, is the ca≈øe of Cawdrie.

Cawdrie was deprived, not by his Ordinarie, but by the Queenes Eccle≈øia≈øticall high Commis≈øioners; not for not ≈øub≈øcribing to the 3 Articles; not for the not u≈øe of rits and Ceremonyes; not, for the not exact,S. Edward Cook de jure regis eccl. Cawdries ca≈øe fol. 3 and preci≈øe ob≈øervation, of the booke of Common prayer: But as well, for that he had preached again≈øt, and depraved the ≈øaid book, as al≈øo for that he refu≈øed to celebrate divine ≈øervice, according to the ≈øayd booke.

Agayne, in his cau≈øe, it being found before the High Commis≈øioners, that he had uttered verba convitio≈øa and contumelio≈øa, convitious, and contumelious words,looke ≈øent again≈øt Caw. again≈øt the boke of Common prayer; the ca≈øe was not, whither his fact were puni≈øhable by the Statute, (for of that no man then doubted;) but whether his depravation, and preaching again≈øt the booke of Common prayer, beyng the fir≈øt offence committed by him again≈øt the Statute; he was puni≈øhable by tenor of the ≈øtatute, for the ≈øame his fir≈øt offence, by depravatioÃÑ, yea or no? La≈øtly Cawdries offence was puni≈øhable as well before the Queenes Iu≈øtices by impri≈øonment, and lo≈ø≈øe of one whole yeares profites, of his ≈øpirituall promotions, as by deprivation before his Ordinary. None of all which things, were within the coÃÑ pa≈ø≈ø, of ≈øundry the late deprived Mini≈øters. For non of theÃÑ ever preached again≈øt the booke, nor depraved the ≈øame. They never refu≈øed to ob≈øerue the ≈øame booke, according to the proeme of the booke & tenor of the ≈øtatute. They were ≈øo farr from claymyng any immunitie, from being depraved, for their fir≈øt offence, as that they ≈øtood and yet doe ≈øtand, upon their innocencyes, not to haue committed any offence at all, again≈øt the ≈øtatute puni≈øhable with deprivation, by the ≈øtatute they alleadge, that they were not puni≈øhable before the Kings Iu≈øtices by the ≈øtatute,
for the≈øe facts which they were charged by their Ordinaries to haue committed again≈øt the ≈øtatute, and for which they were deprived. La≈øtly, ≈øome of them were deprived not for any fact done, committed, or perpetrated: but for not promis≈øing heereafter, to ob≈øerue the whole booke. And what an uncon≈øiderate part therefore is it, to avowe the lawfulnes of the deprivation of all the late ≈øilenced Mini≈øters, to be a playne ca≈øe adjudged in open Court; when neither their ca≈øe, nor any like ca≈øe to ≈øom of theirs, was ever yet brought or argued before the Kings Iu≈øtices in any of the Kings open courts at all.

Touching the ≈øtatut alleadged, 1. Elizabeth, it helpeth nowhitt at all the late deprivations of ≈øundry Mini≈øters, Fir≈øt, becau≈øe ≈øuch Mini≈øters as haue been deprived onely for not conformyng them≈øelues, to the u≈øe of the booke provided by the pari≈øhioners cannot truly be charged to haue refu≈øed the booke commaunded by the ≈øtatute. Becau≈øe the ≈øame booke was never provided for them. Secondly, the ≈øtatute puni≈øheth not every refu≈øer, but wilfull and ob≈øtinate refu≈øers. They then that upon con≈øcience onely of Gods word, doe refu≈øe to ob≈øerue al things conteyned in the booke, cannot be iu≈øtly called ob≈øtinate refu≈øers, till their groundes out of the word, be by the word removed. Canon again≈øt confuting of any publike doctrine (how hereticall or dangerous ≈øo ever) before the Bishop be made acquainted with the ≈øaid doctrine; is mo≈øt prejudiciall to the ≈øalvation of the hearers of ≈øuch erroneous teaching. For the ≈øoules of men beyng by nature as capable of any errors, as their bodyes are of any infectious di≈øea≈øe; and the Bi≈øhop of the ≈øame Dioce≈ø≈øe, ≈øometime perhaps dwelling or beynge an hundred myles from the Church, wherein ≈øuch errors were delivered; and the life of man being mo≈øt uncertaine; and Bi≈øhops them≈øelues
being ≈øometime erroneous, and therefore not very ha≈øtie to haue errors confuted: may not many a ≈øoule be infected with ≈øuch error, yea, and dye in them, before any remedy can be had again≈øt them?

This ≈øhall ≈øuffice for a ta≈øt of the contrariety of divers Canons, to Gods word. If I ≈øhould perticularly runne over other, that haue like coÃÑtrariety; this volume would much exceed, both my owne purpo≈øe, and al≈øo the likyng of all readers.

Before I proceed to the Canons repugnant to the lawes of the land; let me here interlace one rea≈øon in a word generally to proue, both the Canons and al≈øo the booke of Common prayer (now impo≈øed upon Mini≈øters,) not yet to be e≈øtabli≈øhed by law, and ≈øo con≈øequently all the proceedings of the Prelats again≈øt the ≈øaid Mini≈øters for not ≈øub≈øcribyng, ob≈øerving the booke, conformity etc, to be with out law, and a gain≈øt law. This one rea≈øon, is from the late Bill of the Bishops pre≈øented to the Parliament for the e≈øtabli≈øhing both of the booke of Common prayer, and al≈øo of their Canons. For if the ≈øaid booke and Canons were already good in law; what needed any new ≈øtatute to e≈øtabli≈øh them? If they ≈øay that abundans cautela non nocet, plentifull caution is not hurtfull, they mu≈øt al≈øo remember, that they haue likewi≈øe learned, fru≈øtra fit per plura, quod fieri pote≈øt per pauciora: It is in vayne to doe that by many thinges, which may be done by fewe.
Now to the Canons repugnant to the law.

We decree and appoynt (≈øaith the Synod) that no iudge, ad quem, shall admitt or allow any his or their appeales (≈øpeaking as they call them of ob≈øtinate and factious appellants) unle≈ø≈øe he haue fir≈øt ≈øeene the originall appeale. But the King (≈øay I) is a iudge ad quem. Ergo, the King (≈øaith this Synod) may
not admitt or allow any appeale etc. The liberty, and franchi≈øe then of the Kings will, and grace, after this unwonted manner, (by a Synodall decree onely) beyng thus blemi≈øhed, impeched, and re≈øtrayned; what dignity, preheminence, ≈øuperiority, or prerogatiue, hath the Kings grace, when the King him≈øelfe is chardged, not to grant any inhibition out of his Court of Chauncery, but conditionally and upon an unle≈ø≈øe etc.

And if by this Canon, the Kings will and grace, receiue let, hinderance, and prejudice; what ≈øhould we thinke, but that this Canon al≈øo tendeth, to the weakenyng of the Kings arme and power? For how can his power be ≈øtroÃÑg, and his arme able to help, when his grace is bound, and his will, unable to will?

And then agayne, if the≈øe two mayne pillars of his Maje≈øties prerogatiue Royall (namely his grace and his power) be thus ≈øhaken by this Canon, mu≈øt it not nece≈ø≈øarily follow, that the Lords and Commons in Parliament, are prejudiced therby? For the rights & prerogatiues, of the Kings Crowne, by the lawes of the Realme, be not inve≈øted, and appropried, unto the Kings per≈øon, onely in regard of his Maje≈øties owne Royall e≈øtate; but al≈øo for the good condition, and pre≈øervation of his body Politicke, which is the Common wealth. Which body al≈øo for the ju≈øt, and nece≈ø≈øary defence both of the head (which is the King) and of it ≈øelfe, hath ≈øuch a proper clayme, and intere≈øt, in, and to the grace, and power of the head, as the le≈øt jote of the power and grace of the head, may not be blemi≈øhed to the prejudice of the body, without con≈øent of the body. viz: of the Lords & Commons in Parliament, who are the very image, and true repre≈øentiue body of the Realme: yea and thus much in effect, haue the Kings
progenitors, and the Aunce≈øtors of our Nobles, and CoÃÑ mons agreed upon in Parliament; when by their authority and con≈øent, it was forbidden, that any thing ≈øhould be attempted, which ≈øhould tend, to the blemi≈øhyng of the Kings prerogatiue, or to the prejudice of his Lords & Commons. And when al≈øo, by common con≈øent,Acts & Monuments 4: Ed. 3 pag 422. 424: it was enacted in effect, that neither King Iohn, nor any other King, could bring his Realme and people in thraledome, and ≈øubjection, but by con≈øent in Parliament.

Furthermore appeales beyng de iure naturali, and introduced into judgement ≈øeats, tam ob defen≈øionem et pre≈øidiuÃÑ innocentiae, quam ad deprimendam iniquitatem, et corrigendam imperitiam iudicis; as well for the defence and ≈øavegard of innocency, as for the depres≈øing of the iniquity, and correcting the unskilfulnes of a Iudge, as they haue been evermore allowed by the lawes, & cu≈øtoÃÑes of the Realme, ≈øo haue they been ≈øuffered, as freely to be pro≈øecuted, as interpo≈øed. For otherwi≈øe, how ≈øhould either innocency be protected, or the inju≈øtice of a judge reformed, in ca≈øe an appeale being interpo≈øed, might not be pro≈øecuted, fru≈øtra (≈øaith S. Edward Cooke) expectatur eventus, de jure Reg Eccle≈ø. cuius effectus nullus ≈øequitur.

And according unto this naturall equity, hath it been ≈øpecially provided by a Statute of the realme, that the Kings ≈øubjects, being greived, ≈øhould not only haue libertie, to make, but al≈øo, to take, haue, u≈øe, and pro≈øecute all manner of appeales, after ≈øuch manner, forme, and condition, as is limited, for appeales, to be had, and pro≈øecuted. And for lacke of Iu≈øtice many Courts of the Archbishops of this Realme, it is lawfull for the partie greived, to appeale to the Kinges Maje≈øtie in his Court of Chauncery. And upon every ≈øuch appeale, a Commis≈øion (≈øaith the
Statute) ≈øhalbe directed under the great Seale, to ≈øuch per≈øons, as ≈øhalbe named by the Kings Highnes, to heare and definitivly determine ≈øuch appeales, with the cau≈øes, and all circum≈øtances. It is therefore apparant, that this Canon, is contrary or repugnant to this Statute. For this Canon, and this ≈øtatute thus repugnantly providing, and working divers repugnant effects, the ≈øtatute ≈øimply, admitting the u≈øe and pro≈øecution of all manner of appeales, the Canon not admittyng but conditionally the u≈øe and pro≈øecution of ≈øome appeales; can not ≈øtand together.

Agayne, ≈øome inferiour Ordinaryes having libertie, to take the bridle in their owne teeth, & to lay the reynes loo≈øe, on their owne neckes, may in tyme (beyng proudly pampred) wax wanton in their judgement ≈øeates; when they ≈øhall ≈øtand in no awe, of having, the nullitie or injquity of their proce≈ø≈ø and ≈øentences, weyed in the ballance of any ≈øuperiour Iudge. By rea≈øon whereof, this Canon, can not but proue exceeding onerovs to the ≈øubject.

For let a man or woman, dwelling at Michaels Mount, be but once judicially, (though perhaps wrongfully) cited by the name of a factious or ob≈øtinat per≈øon, & coÃÑtemner of ceremonyes, and from ≈øuch wrongfull citations, let his, or her appeale, made to the Kings Maje≈øtie in his Court of Chauncery (if it be froÃÑ the Archbishop,) or unto the Archbishop (if it be from the Dioce≈øan) be never ≈øo ju≈øt, & equal, thereis no remedy in this ca≈øe, before his, or hirs appeale, be admitted or allowed, but the ≈øame man or woman (by the letter of this Canon) mu≈øt per≈øonally appeare, in the Archbishops Con≈øi≈øtory, if the appeale be by the Archbishop, and if the appeale be to the King in the Kings Court of Chauncery, though the ≈øame ≈øhould be at Barwicke. Yea, and though the party appellant be never ≈øo poore, aged,
weake, and impotent. Nay not only per≈øonall appearaÃÑce, but per≈øonall ≈øub≈øcription al≈øo, by this Canon is requyred, to the Kings Supremacie, to the Articles of Religion, to the booke of Homilies, to the booke of Common prayer, and to the booke of Con≈øecrating Bi≈øhops, be the party appellant, never ≈øo ≈øimple a laborer, or never ≈øo ≈øilly a ≈øpiÃÑ≈øter.

The 37. Canon di≈øauthori≈øeth every Mini≈øter by what authority ≈øo ever he be admitted, to preach, or to read a Lecture in any place within the Realme, unle≈ø≈øe he be licenced, either by the Archbi≈øhop, or by the Bishop of the Dioce≈ø≈ø, or by one of the two Univer≈øities under their hands and ≈øeale. Let the King then under his broad ≈øeale, graunt licence to any of his Chapleines to preach within his owne chapple, this licenc by this Canon, is of no value; then the which what can be more derogatory, to the Soveraigne dignity of the King in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall?

Unto the mould of this Canon, agreeth the 47. Canon, (before meÃÑtioÃÑed) which coÃÑcludeth, that no Mini≈øter not liceÃÑ ≈øed a Preacher, under the hand & ≈øeale of the Bishop of the Dioce≈ø≈ø, or Archbishop of the Province, or under the ≈øeale of one of the Vniver≈øities, ≈øhall take upon him to expound, in his owne cure any ≈øcripture, or matter of doctrine, but ≈øhall onely ≈øtudy to read playnely, and aptly, without glo≈øing or addyng, the Homilies already ≈øet forth, or heerafter to be published by lawfull authority. The King then by this Canon, may not licence, a Mini≈øter to preach or to expound any ≈øcripture, no not in his own cure, no though the mini≈øters Cure, be the Kings owne hou≈øhold, or the hou≈øhould of the Prince, or any other of the Kings children. Nay by the≈øe two Canons and the Canon of ≈øub≈øcription it is evident, that the Prelats intended, that every Scotish Mini≈øter havyng renounced the Hierachie, and embraced the ≈øingle
forme of Goverment in Scotland, ≈øhould be barred from preaching at any time before the King in England, unle≈ø≈ø he ≈øhould ≈øub≈øcribe to the Hierarchy of England. For with out a licence may none preach, and without ≈øub≈øcription may none be licenced.

And not onely is this 47. Canon, derogatorie to the Kings prerogatiue, but it is al≈øo repugnant, to other the Kings lawes and ≈øtatuts. For whereby that ≈øtatute, made again≈øt Lolardy, and Here≈øie,, it was enacted, that none ≈øhould pre≈øume to Preach openly, or privily, without the licence of the Dioce≈øan, fir≈øt requyred & obtayned, yet by the ≈øame Act, Curats in their owne Churches, and Par≈øons priviledged were excepted, and by the Provinciall Con≈øtitutions, confirmed and ratified by Parliament, it is provided thus: We e≈øtablish, that no ≈øecular, or regular, not authori≈øed by written law, or protected by ≈øpeciall priviledg, to preach the word of God, may take upon him the preaching or exerci≈øe of the ≈øame word, within any Church, or without any Church, unle≈ø≈ø fir≈øt he pre≈øent and ≈øubmit him≈øelfe, to the examination of the Dioce≈øan etc: But concernyng aperpetuall Curate, we under≈øtand ≈øuch a one, by law and right to be ≈øent to the place, and people of his Cure. And that we may under≈øtand whom the Canon meaneth, to be a perpetuall Curate the glo≈ø≈ø ≈øheweth us, that a Bishop in his Dioce≈ø≈ø, a Par≈øon and Vicar in his Parish, and every other Per≈øon intituled, to any benefice whereunto apper teyneth cure of ≈øoules, is to be under≈øtood to be a perpetuall Curate, and that he may preach in his owne Cure, without the Bi≈øhops licence.

Moreover by the booke of ordering Bi≈øhops, Mini≈øters, and Deacons, every one made a Mini≈øter, promi≈øeth that he will giue all faithfull diligence alwayes, to mini≈øter the doctrine etc: as the Lord hath commanded etc: ≈øo that he will
teach the people committed to his cure and chardg, withall dilligence to keepe and ob≈øerue the ≈øame. But how can a Mini≈øter in≈øtruct and teach the people committed to his chardge, according to his publicke vowe, if (as it is ≈øayd in this Canon) he ≈øhall not take upon him to expound in his owne Cure, any ≈øcripture or matter of doctrine at all, but ≈øhall onely ≈øtudy to read plainely and aptly, (without glo≈øing or adding) the Homilies etc?

La≈øtly, the wordes of the Bi≈øhops in≈øtitution are the≈øe. Teque rectorem eiu≈ødem, ac de, et ineadem in≈øtituimus canonice, et inve≈øtimus, cum ≈øuis iuribus, et pertinentiis univer≈øis, curamque et regimen animarum prochianorum ibidem in Domino coÃÑ mittimus per-pre≈øentes. And we (≈øpeaking of a Clarke to be in≈øtituted into a benefice) Canonically in≈øtitute thee rector of the ≈øame Church, and of,Cure & goverment by law ought to go together in a mini≈øter and in the ≈øame doe inve≈øt thee, withall her rights & appertinances; and by the≈øe pre≈øents, we in the Lord commit unto thee both the cure and goverment, of the ≈øoules of the Pari≈øhioners in that place. The Clearke then in≈øtituted into a benefice, by the≈øe wordes of the Bi≈øhops in≈øtitution, by the booke of ordering of Bi≈øhops, Mini≈øters, and Deacons, and by the Provinciall Con≈øtitutions, having not a private, but a publicke office, of cure and regiment of ≈øoules, committed unto him; how can it ≈øeeme rea≈øonable, that he ≈øhould be countermanded by rea≈øon of a Provinciall decree not coÃÑ firmed by Act of Parliament, not to excerci≈øe the ≈øame his publicke office, without a Bi≈øhops licence? For what if the Bi≈øhops refu≈øe to grant him a licence? Or what if the Bi≈øhops and his officers ≈øee, for graunting, writing, & ≈øealyng his licence be greater then the poore Mini≈øter is able to disbur≈øt, is it rea≈øon that his chardg by this meaÃÑes ≈øhould be left unin≈øtructed? Nay is it not, as if a Sergiant
at law, called to the barr of the Common pleas, by the Kings writ, ≈øolemly created a Sergiant, and publickly admitted to the ≈øame barr, ≈øhould afterward be forbidden by the cheife Iu≈øtice of that Court, to pleade at that barr, without licence otteyned, under his hand and ≈øeale? Or is it not, as if a Doctor of Phi≈øicke, ≈øolemnely created in the Vniver≈øity, and publickly admited to practi≈øe artem medica, ≈øhould notwith≈øtanding, without a new faculty from the Doctor of the Chayre be inhibited, to mini≈øter any Pill, or Portion, to any pacient?

The 53. Canon, before al≈øo mentioned, viz. again≈øt publicke oppo≈øition between preachers, is not only repugnaÃÑt to the doctrine oflevit 5.1 2 Tim. 4.2: holy Scripture, & coÃÑtrary to the practis of the2. Chron. 18.7 Ierem. 27.9 & 28:7 Acts 13.10. Galat. 2:11
Prophets & Apo≈øtles, but al≈øo cro≈ø≈øeth the Mini≈øters vow ≈øolemly made at his ordination. Who≈øe promi≈øe is that he wilbe ready, with all faithfull diligence, to bani≈øh, & driue away, all erroneous, and ≈øtrang doctrin contrary to Gods word, and to u≈øe both publicke, and private motions, and exhortations, as well to the ≈øicke as to the whole within his cure. But upon occa≈øion given, by any fal≈øe Prophet, publickly broaching fal≈øe doctrine, in a Mini≈øters chardg, how ≈øhall the Mini≈øter with all faithfull dilligence drive away the ≈øame fal≈øe doctrine, and publickely teach the truth, if he may not teach, admoni≈øh, or exhort his people, without a licence fir≈øt obtayned from the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈ø? For what if the Bi≈øhop be upon an emba≈ø≈øadg in Denmarke? Or what if the Bishop him≈øelf be of the ≈øame judgment with the fal≈øe teacher?

The 91. Canon entituled Parish Clearks to be cho≈øen by the Mini≈øters, is contrary and regugnant to the cu≈øtomes of the Realme, in many Pari≈øhes of the Realme. And in this regard, this Canon hath been blowen to peeces, at the barr
of the Common Pleas, by the opinion of the whole beÃÑch in Hylarie terme la≈øt: when upon a writt of prohibition, procured by certayne Pari≈øhioners, in the Countie of Hertford, the Iudges denyed a con≈øultation, to the Mini≈øter of the ≈øame Pari≈øh, who had convented the Pari≈øhioners, before the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudg, for gayn≈øaying his election of the pari≈øh clearke; which by vertue of this Canon, he had declared in the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Court, to belong unto him≈øelfe a lone.

The 77. Canon entituled, none to teach ≈øchole without licence, is repugnant to a ≈øtatute made the fir≈øt Ses≈øion of this Parliament in divers poyntse. Fir≈øt the ≈øtatute permitteth a≈øcholema≈øter to teach, in any publicke free graÃÑmer ≈øchole, without any licence of the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈ø; or Ordinary of the place: but this Canon commaundeth, that none teach publicke ≈øchole, but ≈øuch as ≈øhalbe licen≈øed by the one; or by the other. Secondly, the ≈øtatute permitteth any per≈øon, in any Noble mans or Noble womans; gentle mans or geÃÑtlewomaÃÑs hou≈øe, being not recu≈øants, to teach without any licence of etc: but this Canon, commaundeth that no man ≈øhal teach in privat hou≈øe, but by licence etc. Thirdly, the ≈øtatute permitteth not any per≈øon to be a≈øcholema≈øter by any other licence, theÃÑ by the Archbishop Bi≈øhop, or guardian of the ≈øpiritualties. But this Canon permitteth a ≈øcholema≈øter to teach, if he be allowed by an Ordinarie of the place a lone. Which many tymes, and in many places, is neither Archbishop, nor Bi≈øhop, nor guardian of the ≈øpiritualties.

La≈øtly, this Canon commaundeth, that none teach in publicke ≈øchole, or private hou≈øe, unle≈ø≈ø he fir≈øt ≈øub≈øcribe, to the fir≈øt and third articles, mencioned in the 36. Canon ≈øimply, and to the two fir≈øt clau≈øes of the ≈øecond article,
wheras the ≈øtatute requyreth no manner of ≈øub≈øcription at all.

All the≈øe things before written con≈øidered, we may ≈øafly affirme concernyng many of the ≈øaid late Canons, that they be not to be put in execution within the Realme, unle≈ø≈ø they ≈øhall be confirmed by Act of Parliament: yea that we may al≈øo truely ≈øpeake this in generalitie: that eiall the Churcwardens and ≈øyde men throughout England ≈øworne to pre≈øent all offences committed again≈øt the ≈øaid Canons, mu≈øt be fal≈øely perjured; or el≈øe that there is not one Mini≈øter which ≈øhall exerci≈øe his mini≈øteriall functioÃÑ, nor any one man, or woman, which ≈øhall u≈øually come to common prayer, and divine ≈øervice, but they mu≈øt ≈øtand continually at the Ordinaries mercy, for one offence or other. For the thinges commaunded, or forbidden, beyng innumerable, and impos≈øible at all tymes to be kept, into what a ≈øervitude the≈øe Canons haue brought both Mini≈øters and people, and what an exces≈øiue chardg, is layd up on the pur≈øe of every per≈øon be he bond or be he free, be he yong, or be he old, for citations, Excommunications, ab≈øolutions, and dimis≈øions, licences, faculties, and di≈øpeÃÑ ≈øations, Who havyng but halfe an eye ≈øeeth not? Nay, that many, in many places, haue already borne the Yoke, and felt the burden of the≈øe Canons, cannot be denyed. Agayne, how≈øoever at the petition of the Prelats, his Maje≈øtie hath been plea≈øed generally to allow, ratifie and coÃÑ firme, the booke of Canons, under the broad ≈øeale of England; yet may no loyall and hone≈øt ≈øubject heereupon inferr, that his Maje≈øtie intended by the generall wordes of his confirmation, to authorize any perticular matter, devi≈øed and decreed, by the Synod, contrary to the holy ≈øcriptures, hurtfull to the rights, prerogatives, and dignities, of
his Highnes Crowne; repugnant to any lawes, ≈øtatuts, or cu≈øtomes of the Realme, prejudiciall to his Lords & commons in Parliament, or onerous to his people. The contents then of ≈øondry the late Canons, in as much as the ≈øame be contrary to the holy ≈øcriptures, tend to the blemi≈øhing of the liberty and franchi≈øe of the Kings will, grace, & power, be coÃÑtrariant, or regugnant, to the lawes, ≈øtatuts, and cu≈øtomes of the Realme, be prejudiciall to the Lords, and Commons in Parliament, without who≈øe con≈øent, no new bindyng law, ought to be made, or be ≈øuch, as may become very onerous to the people; it is a playne ca≈øe, that every of the Kings liege & faithfull ≈øubjects, ought to defend the Kings right, Honor and dignity again≈øt all ≈øuch Canons.

For heerby it ≈øeemeth that as all other the wi≈øe≈øt and be≈øt Princes that ever haue been, haue in ≈øome things at ≈øome tymes erred, ≈øo we without offence (I hope) may ≈øay, that the King al≈øo veritate tacita, or fal≈øitate exre≈ø≈øa, was unawares ≈øomewhat mi≈øtaken in his graunt. In regard whereof, ≈øuch Canons, by the lawes, ≈øtatuts, and cu≈øtomes of his kingdome be meerely voyd, and of none effect to all con≈øtructions & purpo≈øes: whereupon al≈øo, that nece≈ø≈øarily followeth, that the ≈øame can receive no beyng, by his, Maje≈øties confirmation, Quod omnino, non e≈øt, confirmari non pote≈øt.

argument.p:
God hath promi≈øed to recompence the lea≈øt kindnes ≈øhewed to his ≈øervants, e≈øpecially to the Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell. And the ≈øame God is not unrighteous to forget etc: but faithfull, and hath alwayes performed his promi≈øe, as appeareth by divers examples. Heb. 6:10 and 10.23: Ergo: In this regard the High Court of Parliament ought the more to help and releeue the Mini≈øters pleaded for, and the people
depending upon them.

div.head: Marginall notes.
div.q: G. Powela Mini≈øters are to be rewarded as they be ≈øuch, and in their office: but not as they be Schi≈ømatikes, and di≈øturbers of the peace of the Church.
div.p: Thereis a ≈øecret contradiction in the fir≈øt parte of this an≈øwer.Reply. For as a Mayor ovt of his office is no Mayor, ≈øo a Mini≈øter out of his mini≈øtery is no Mini≈øter. See the an≈øwerer at large. Secondly, Mini≈øters violently thru≈øt out without ju≈øt cau≈øe, are not to be blamed. Touching di≈øturbance, we ≈øay that not we, but the Prelats that plead for humane and Romi≈øh Ceremonyes (much hurtfull and nothing profitable,) are they that trouble the Church. For the Church would otherwi≈øe be quyet inough.
div.q: G. Powelb Arcadian wi≈ødome. The place Math. 11.11. is to be under≈øtood not in regard of the office, but in re≈øpect of the cleare knowledg they ≈øhould haue of Chri≈øt, after his re≈øurrection.
div.p: The fir≈øt part of this note beyng but a ≈øcorne I leaue to ≈øcorners. The other divinity of this note, is very deepe and profound.Reply. How ≈øhall I ≈øound the bottome of it? Doth Chri≈øt ≈øpeake of Iohn, in re≈øpect of his knowledge, or of his office? Did the people goe out into the wildernes unto Iohn, in re≈øpect of his knowledge, or in re≈øpect of his office, to be bapti≈øed of him? Math. 3.6.7 Doth Chri≈øt al≈øo aske whether the knowledge,Math 21.25 or the bapti≈øme, (that is the mini≈øtery) of Iohn were froÃÑ heaven or of men? Heerby it is manife≈øt that Chri≈øt compareth Iohn with the Prophets in re≈øpect of office, not in re≈øpect of knowledge. Therefore al≈øo in the ≈øame re≈øpect he compareth the lea≈øt in the kingdom of heaven with him, and preferreth the lea≈øt Mini≈øter of the go≈øpell for his mini≈øteryes ≈øake as much before Iohn, as he had before preferred Iohn before the Prophets.

La≈øtly, the mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell is greater then the
knowledge of the go≈øpell, becau≈øe it is both the end for which God giveth more knowledge to ≈øome then to other, and al≈øo the cau≈øe that worketh knowledge in other. If therfore the lea≈øt in the kingdome of heaven, be greater theÃÑ Iohn Bapti≈øt in re≈øpect of knowledg, which is the lea≈øt, then much more is the lea≈øt mini≈øter of the go≈øpell greater then Iohn Bapti≈øt, in re≈øpect of his mini≈øtery which is the greater. The note with (c) is not worth a Cee (as they ≈øpeake at Oxford) of ≈øingle beere.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 9. Argument.
div.q: G. PowelHe doth any kindnes to a Mini≈øter, as he is a mini≈øter, ≈øhall haue reward. But if a Mini≈øter doe otherwi≈øe then he ought (as the≈øe refractaries doe) what kindnes then ought ≈øuch to haue?
div.p: What a multitude of conformable Mini≈øters are quite overthrowne by this Argument?Reply. For doe not many of them otherwi≈øe then they ought? Yea, doe not more of them otherwi≈øe, then all thes now in que≈øtion? Is not this ≈øo to ≈øtand in a gap, as that the gap is troden downe, and a dore opened, for all men to deny all duety to all Mini≈øters? For who doth not otherwi≈øe, theÃÑ he ought to doe?
div.q: G. PowelLet the refractary Mini≈øters duetifully ≈øerue God and his Church, in their diligent and humble obeydience, in the worke of their vocation. Then let them ≈øupplicat for kindnes etc.
div.p:
What is that dilligent and humble obedience etc?Reply. To put on a Surplice, to make a vani≈øhing Cro≈ø≈ø, to read ≈øervice, to acknowledge the Prelats to haue power to make ordinances again≈øt Gods word etc. How ≈øhall they ≈øupplicat? With an 100. or 200. in a bagge. Then perhaps if they ari≈øe betymes, and ryde a pa≈øe, they ≈øhall haue a payre of benefices; an Archdeconry etc: yea liberty al≈øo to goe whither they will, & never to come at any of their benefices, but only in gathering time or if they lie at one of their benefices they ≈øhall haue leaue I to ≈øu≈øpeÃÑd them≈øelues from
preaching as long as the li≈øt: yea to do what el≈øe they will without controllment, ≈øo it be not again≈øt conformity. Notwith≈øtanding the Canon for halfe yeares re≈øidence at either of their livinges, they haue many quirkes to avoyd the danger therof.

div.head: THE 10. ARGVMENT.

p.hi: The Lord hath forbidden all wrong to any of his ≈øervants, e≈øpecially to Mini≈øters. He threateneth al≈øo to revenge the lea≈øt iniury done unto them:

and performeth that which he hath threatned. Neither doth he account them onely guiltie of the former fault, that doe his people any hurt, but tho≈øe al≈øo that doe not, help in their need. Ergo The high Court of Parliament, ought to take the pre≈øent opportunitie for releeving the Mini≈øters mole≈øted.

div.p: The marginall notes of this Argument conteyne nothing but a vayne repetition of matters before noted and an≈øwered; they conteyne nothing, but that we are Schi≈ømatiks, fal≈øe prophets etc: cruell, in for≈øaking our charges for litle or nothing etc. I doe therfore di≈ømi≈ø≈øe them, with admiration, as of the notaryes barrenes and folly, ≈øo al≈øo of the virtue of Cro≈ø≈ø and Surplice. As the Ephe≈øians cryed out of their Diana,Acts 19.28: Great is Diana of the Ephe≈øians; ≈øo ≈øay I, great are Cro≈ø≈ø and Surplice of the Conformitans. The u≈øe of them, maketh men Gods, Prophets, true prophets, peaceable men, faithfull Mini≈øters: but the refu≈øall of them makes men ≈øchi≈ømaticall, cruell, ≈øuper≈øtitious, fal≈øe prophets etc. Who would not be in loue with them, wherein there is ≈øuch excellent virtue? How many may more truely ≈øacrifice to them;Habba. 1:16 then ≈øome ≈øometymes are ≈øayd to haue ≈øacrificed to their nets?

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 10. Argument.
div.q: G. PowelIt is an ungratfull, yea an ungracious parte of the≈øe ≈øupplicants, to taxe the Honorable a≈ø≈øembly, or any Magi≈øtrate in this land ≈øo undutifully and unchri≈øtiantly, for unju≈øt, cruell and mercile≈ø≈øe dealyng.
div.p: Who doth ≈øo taxe them?Reply Doth every one that admoni≈øh other of that which God forbiddeth or threatneth, taxe them whom he doth ≈øo admoni≈øh of tho≈øe faultes that are forbidden? Your ≈øelfe haue taxed them indeede before, of matters nothing be≈øeemyng you: yea, and the Prelats doe dayly taxe (if not al≈øo threathen to excommunicate them) for dealyng ≈øo much for us: for oppo≈øing them≈øelues ≈øo much to the Prelacy: for doeyng ≈øo much as they haue doone again≈øt non re≈øidency, the di≈øorders of the high Commis≈øion, the abu≈øe of citations, the horrible abu≈øe of the great cen≈øure of the Church, Excommunication etc: yea for dealing at all in the matters of religion: yea, haue they not more ≈øtoutly then wi≈øely ≈øent out their Inhibition again≈øt them in that behalfe? Thus they may doe what they li≈øt,P≈øal: 12 as though their tongues were their owne, and there were no Lord over them: but we poore men oppre≈ø≈øed by them, may not humbly petition to the Parliament, but that we are pre≈øently exclaymed of, as ungratefull and ungracious, & as undutifully and unchri≈øtiantly taxeyng them for uniu≈øt, cruell and merciles dealyng. Wherefore doe they thus charge us? Becau≈øe they feare that we will lay the ≈øame thinges to their charge. But though they doe thus e≈øteeme of our petition, yet we hope it is better accepted of the Honorable Courte, unto which it was directed.

Wheras in the re≈øt of the an≈øwer to this 10. ArgumeÃÑt, he ≈øayth the refractary Mini≈øters (as he calleth them) were never proceeded again≈øt for preachyng the go≈øpell, or for appertune & ≈øober executyng their Mini≈øtery, this is utterly untrue, for ≈øome haue been mole≈øted for preachyng any thinge tendyng again≈øt the pre≈øent Hierarchy, or any other corruptions: ≈øome al≈øo for confuting the Popi≈øh doctrine of
other, though they haue doone it never ≈øo ≈øoberly: and ≈øome for other matters, which are poyntes of the go≈øpell as well as other.

argument.p: Pharao in the great Egiptian famine, at his owne co≈øt provided for all his Idolatrous prie≈øts, Gen: 47:22 that they might not ≈øell their lands. The Monks, and Fryars in Popery (yet in the twylight of the go≈øpell) at the di≈ø≈øolution of the Abbyes, were provided for, duryng their life tyme. Ergo, The high Court of Parliament, in this cleare light of the go≈øpell, ought much more to provide that the mini≈øters of the go≈øpell; may not be turned out a beggyng with their wiues and children, as they are; when all other haue their fill.

div.head: The Marginall Notes.
div.q:
G. Powele VVhere ≈øuper≈øtition fitteth Iudge, there neyther nature, nor rea≈øon may dare to plead the cau≈øe. Alas, it is very lamentable, that ≈øome men (I know not for what carnall re≈øpects) had rather curry favour with other, and beholding to other men, theÃÑ con≈øcionably liue „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eir owne. They ≈øhould well con≈øider the ≈øaying of the Apo≈øt 1: Tim. 5.8.
div.p:
Reply.In divine matters, neither ≈øuper≈øtition mu≈øt ≈øit Iudge, neyther mu≈øt things be pleaded by nature or rea≈øon, but all mu≈øt be done by the word of God, the ≈øtore hou≈øe of divinity. They are ≈øuper≈øtitious, that ≈øtryue more for reteyning and practi≈øing of humane Ceremonyes in the wor≈øhip of God, (be the preten≈øe what it will) then they regard the truth of God. The (an≈øwerer as a very pitifull man) cryeth out, Alas it is lamentable etc. But one of the≈øe poore Mini≈øters, yea many of them by rea≈øon of their trobles, may come ten-tymes to ≈øome of his great Ma≈øters hou≈øes, and not be offred once, to drinke of a cupe: but the truth is, they haue forgotten Apo≈øtolicall ho≈øpitality, and they haue learned Lordly Epi≈øcopall ho≈øtility. Further marke here his contradiction, or oblivion. Before in
his con≈øideration of the preface to the Arguments, he hath expre≈øly charged them with divers particular carnall re≈øpects, etc. Now he ≈øayth,contradictioÃÑ that he knoweth not for what carnall re≈øpects they curry favour etc. As for currying of favour; it belongeth rather to ≈øome hungry trencher chaplines, then to tho≈øe again≈øt whom he writeth. Yea,2 Sam. 16 13 2 Sam: 19 18 as Shimei that cur≈øed David when his kingdome was ≈øomwhat doubtfull, yet at his ≈øafe returne and ree≈øtabli≈øhing of the Crowne unto him, was as forward as any other, by creepyng and crouchyng, by flattering and fawnyng to curry favour agayne with David, ≈øo it is well if there haue been no ≈øuch curryers of favor among the Prelats. The place of Timothy is abu≈øed. It might in like ≈øort haue been applyed to all the Martyrs. We mu≈øt not provide for our familyes by doyng any thing again≈øt Gods word. That we had rather liue of our owne, then of other mens, is manife≈øt in that we doe ≈øo earne≈øtly ≈øue to be re≈øtored to our places, the rather that we may not be chargable to other.
div.q: G. Powelb Alas let them haue pity upon them≈øelues, and leaue their quarreling, and they ≈øhall not be neglected.
div.p: This is ≈øpoken more like an Archbi≈øhop that had power to preferre other,Reply. then like a young chapline that needed and wayted for preferment him≈øelfe. I know not, who may more ju≈øtly be charged with quarrelling, then they that beate and buffet their fellow ≈øervants: yea then they that ≈ømite Chri≈øts Sy≈øter, his loue, his Doue, his undefiled, yea, not only ≈ømite her, but al≈øo wouÃÑd her, and take her vayle from her. We would gladly liue in peace, (with holines) but we cannot be ≈øuffered.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 11. Argument.
div.q: G. PowelThe Argument doth not follow, becau≈øe of the dis≈øimilitude in the in≈øtances, or examples:
div.p:
The Argument doth follow the better,Reply. becau≈øe of the
≈øimilitude of in≈øtances (as the an≈øwerer ≈øpeaketh) or rather becau≈øe it is a minore ad maius, from the le≈ø≈øe to the greater. This inequality of examples, rather ≈øtrenghtneth then weakeneth the Argument and the cau≈øe. But let us ≈øee his dis≈øimilitudes.
div.q: G. Poweli Pharao thought his prie≈øts to profe≈ø≈øe true religion, and diligently to obey him etc: But refractary Mini≈øters, though profes≈øing true religion, yet doe ob≈øtinatly (beyng blynded with ≈øuper≈øtition) refu≈øe to ≈øerue God etc:
div.p: Reply.As Pharao was in error touchyng the religion & obedience of his Prie≈øts, ≈øo are our Prelats touching our refractarine≈ø≈ø and ≈øuper≈øtition,The obedience of the mole≈øted mini≈øters to his Maje≈øtie: as good as the be≈øt Conformitans: as hath been ≈øheewed. Our obedience to his Maje≈øtie is as good, as of the be≈øt of their ≈øyde. That mans obedience to a Mayor of a towne or to any other inferior officer of a Prince, is alwayes the be≈øt, that is mo≈øt agreable to the plea≈øure of the Prince him≈øelfe. In like manner, that obedience is be≈øt unto Princes, that doth be≈øt agree with the plea≈øure of the Prince of Princes, and King of Kings. To obey the inferior without due regard of the ≈øuperiors plea≈øure, is but flattery and fawnyng, not good obedience. So to obey Princes, without due regard to our dutie to God. For it is more prejudiciall and hurtfull, then beneficiall or profitable to ≈øuch Princes. See the words of Samuell to the I≈øraelits. 1 Sam. 12.15. & 25: & the example of Ioab in numbring the people by the commaundement of David, whereupon followed an exceeding plague.

Touching the ≈øerving of God and his Church, in the faith full and diligent function and exerci≈øe of the Mini≈øtery; we are unju≈øtly charged to refu≈øe it, for we humbly and earne≈øtly de≈øire it, aboue all maintenance: and for this de≈øire we are thru≈øt out of our livyng.
div.q: G. Powel2 The Monks and Fryars, were put out again≈øt their wills for Sodomi, here≈øie, Idolatry etc: The refractary Mini≈øters are willingly deprived for ob≈øtinate ≈øuper≈øtition, in refu≈øing ≈øincerely to Preach the go≈øpell, not beyng conformable to the Chri≈øtian lawes of our Church, and Magi≈øtrat:
div.p: The more ju≈øtly, that Monks and Fryars were put out,Reply. the ≈øtronger is the Argument for us to be provided for, that are put out unju≈øtly: without objection of any ≈øuch foule crymes to us, as for which they were put out. Yet it is fal≈øe, that they were put out for here≈øie or Idolatry; though they were heretikes and Idolaters. For they were ≈øuffered ≈øtill in their here≈øie & Idolatry, as well after their putting out as before. Neither al≈øo are we willingly, deprived, any othewi≈øe then Marriners, willingly throwe their goods over boord into the ≈øea,Acts 27.38: to ≈øave their liues and the ≈øhip the better. Of ≈øuper≈øtition I haue ≈øpoken often; this now I ad, that many account carefulnes to keep a good con≈øcience in ≈ømale matters as well as in great, to be ≈øuper≈øtition. And in the meane tyme, them≈øelues care neither for great nor ≈ømal matters, any further theÃÑ there are lawes of man in that behalfe. As for ≈øuper≈øtition indeed, we are ≈øilenced and deprived becau≈øe we will not yeeld to humaÃÑ Ceremonyes, that haue been and are ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly abu≈øed in the wor≈øhip of God, and of Idols, among≈øt the Papi≈øts, what≈øoever they are among≈øt us. It is al≈øo as fal≈øe, that we refu≈øe to be conformable to Chri≈øtian lawes.
div.q: G. Powel Monks and Fryars could not haue kept their places, by ≈øubmitting them≈øelues: But the≈øe may by conformyng them≈øelues: &c.
div.p:
I know no condition of ≈øubmis≈øion offered to Monks etc: Touching the re≈øt, we thanke you for nothing.Reply. This is the curte≈øie of Prelats, to make us pay decre for our lyvings, even to buye them with ≈øinnyng again≈øt God, (as ≈øome of them are ≈øayd to doe,) with Symony, and otherwi≈øe. But we dare not accept them at the price. The re≈øt
haue been often an≈øwered. I haue not ≈øuch ley≈øure, to u≈øe tautologies as the an≈øwerer ≈øeemeth to haue had at the writing of his an≈øwer, as though he were connyng a le≈ø≈øon by heart, in feare of beating for forgetting the ≈øame.

argument.p: Iames 5.6 Apoc. 5:8: Ezra 6:10 Cene≈ø: 20:7 The prayers of all the godly are much to be e≈øteemed. E≈øpecially of the Mini≈øters of the word. Ergo In this behalfe the Mini≈øters now troubled, are the more to be re≈øpected.

div.head: Marginall notes.
div.q: G. Powela True: if they continue diligent in their vocation: But beyng meÃÑ bers, rent and cut from the body of the Church of God in this land, they are un≈øerviceable for the ≈øame:
div.p: What man? Haue you unchri≈øtened us? Are we now Heathen and infidells agayne? It may be you will ≈øay we are wor≈øe; Reply. lib: de Adiaphoris: yea you haue already called us Apes. Before al≈øo in a note we haue been ≈øecretly compared to ≈øwyne. But how then doe you call us your brethren? He is certaynly of a ≈øtrange ≈øtocke, that hath Schi≈ømatikes, fal≈øs prophets, heathens and infidells, Apes and ≈øwyne to his brethren. But it were good that ≈øome of the Prelats that made the Canons and doe execute the ≈øame, did con≈øider, in what danger they are by the ≈øtatute of Excommingment, for making and executing Canons contrary to former laws, and ≈øtatuts of this kingdome. Heere agayne behold, the admirable efficacy of conformity, as that wherein con≈øi≈øteth the life of the Church, and wherby men are members, yea Angels of the Church in England: & without which, men are not ≈øo much as members thereof.
div.q: G. Powelb Are they faithfull that fall from their rule of obedience?
div.p:
Reply.So long as we keepe our ≈øelues to Gods word, we fall not from our rule or obedience. For we acknowledge no other rule or obedience. Luther left the rules and obedience
of Monks: ≈øo many other left other rules of Popery. Yet, I hope you will not deny theÃÑ to haue been faithfull, or call them ≈øchi≈ømatikes. As for your rule and obedience of Conformity in ≈øome perticulars, many of us haue not fallen from them: Fir≈øt becau≈øe we never yelded to them. 2 Becau≈øe to leaue Conformity, is not to fall, that is to goe downward; but to ari≈øe, that is to goe upward. Bittter rootes ≈øpring up, that is, come out of the earth froÃÑ beneath.Heb: 12:15 prov. 15:24 Iames 1.17.
But the way of life is on high, and every good and perfect gift commeth from aboue. They that haue left conformity, are more a≈øhamed and greived for having been Conformable, then for leavyng it, though they pay ≈øweetly for it.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 12. Argument.
div.q: G. Powel1 Neither are the prayers of Schi≈ømatiks much to be regarded: 2 Neither will the Honorable court of ParliameÃÑt, altogether neglect the refractary mini≈øters: 3 Nether can the refractary mini≈øters in charity but pray for the high court, yea in ca≈øe, they did not ≈øatisfie their de≈øire:
div.p:
This an≈øwer con≈øi≈øteth of 3 parts, according as I haue noted the ≈øame. Concernyng the fir≈øt,Reply. it is not much to be denyed if men be ≈øchi≈ømatikes indeed, and not only in name. Therefore touchyng that and the ≈øecond, neither the an≈øwerer nor all the Prelats in the world: ≈øhall ever proue us ≈øchi≈ømatikes and refractaryes, as they unju≈øtly terme us. For the third, albeit the High Court of Parliament would doe nothing in our behalfe, yet we will ≈øay with Samuell,
1 Samuell 12:13 Gene≈ø: 20:7 Ezra: 6:10 God forbid that we ≈øhould ≈øinne again≈øt the Lord and cea≈øe praying for them. Notwith≈øtanding it cannot be denyed, but that the more ju≈øtice and kindnes we ≈øhall receiue from them or by them, either at this Ses≈øion or at any other heerafter, the more we ≈øhould be both bound and quickened to pray for them. But the zeale of the Parliament, in doeyng ≈øo much all ready for us as they haue doone, is worthy our remeÃÑbrance whil≈øt we liue. Though
it haue not that ≈øucce≈ø≈øe pre≈øently, that we haue de≈øired, yet we know not what it may haue in tyme, upon further con≈øideration thereof by his mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øty, and by his wi≈øe and mo≈øt Honorable Coun≈øell. No ≈øeed groweth pre≈øently: yea the be≈øt ≈øeed lyeth longe≈øt in ground (for the mo≈øt part) before it appeare, e≈øpecially before it yeeld fruit agayne. That that is doone al≈øo, ≈øhall be a good evidence for us, and for the equity of our cau≈øe, as al≈øo again≈øt the Prelats, to all po≈øteritie; what≈øoever reproches, and other indignityes in the meane time we ≈øu≈øteyne eyther by their ≈øpeeches, or by their vnju≈øt writyng (vpon record) again≈øt us.Contradiction or coÃÑtrarietie. But here is further to be noted, the contradiction or at the lea≈øt the contrariety of this an≈øwerer, even in this very part of his an≈øwer. For in the fir≈øt parte therof he ≈øayth, the prayers of Schi≈ømatikes are not much to be regarded. Where his meaning by comparyng the≈øe words with other his termes of being rent & cut of froÃÑ the Church, ob≈øtinat, wilfull etc: mu≈øt needes be, that our prayers are of no regard. In the third parte notwith≈øtanding, he ≈øayth that we ought to pray for the Parliament, though they ≈øhould doe nothing for us accordyng to our de≈øire. Ought we to doe that which is of no regard, of no u≈øe, of no benefite, to no purpo≈øe?math. 12:23 Shall not we giue account of every idle word, much more of every idle prayer? Yea are not the prayers of all ob≈øtinat, wilfull, impudent, ≈øchi≈ømaticall and ≈øeditious per≈øons, and of all lyers, and fal≈øe Prophets (≈øuch as he hath often called vs to be) abominatioÃÑ to the Lord?prov: 15:8 How then are we bound to pray for the Parliament, or for any other? Are we bound to doe that tnat is ≈øinne, and wherof we ≈øhall giue an account?
div.q: 2 If they had ≈øtill made con≈øcience of their duety in their Mini≈øtery,Reply. their prayers had been much more effectuall.
div.p: Behold what con≈øcience the≈øe men make of ≈øub≈øcription, Cro≈ø≈ø, ≈øurplice, conformity,G. Powel and other perticular obedience; that make no con≈øcience of preachyng: yea not of commyng to their flockes once in a yeare; yea ≈øome not once in 3. or 4. yeares. Is it not ≈øtrange al≈øo, that ≈øurplice and cro≈ø≈ø ≈øhould ad ≈øuch efficacie to prayers? How merry then would it be with England, if all men in all places, were forced to were a red, blue, greene, white, or yellow cro≈ø≈ø, vpon their hats, ≈øleeues, or bre≈øts etc? And if every man, woman and child might never pray privatly, or publikely, but in a ≈øurplice? Further I pray God, that ≈øuch as make ≈øo light account of our prayers for them, doe not by their hard dealyngs with us, force us to cry for help from God again≈øt them, and then feele the virtue and efficacy of our prayers in this behalfe, to their greife. For ≈øhall not God aveng his elect, which cry day and night unto him, Luc: 10:7: yea though he ≈øuffer long for them? I tell you he will aveng them quickly. Let not this be lightly thought on. In the meane tyme al≈øo, how vile≈øoever our prayers are in their judgements; yet let this an≈øwerer & all other our greate≈øt adver≈øaryes under≈øtand, that they are not ≈øo in the ≈øen≈øe & feeling of tho≈øe mercyes, that they doe dayly enjoye, as well by our prayers, as by their owne. For our con≈øciences bearing witnes, our prayers are of faith, and in truth & loue, we doubt not, but that the King and whole kingdome, yea our greate≈øt adver≈øaryes doe dayly fare the better by them. And this I feare would too ≈øoone appeare, if they ≈øhould or could ≈øu≈øpend us from praying, as they haue doone from preaching.

div.head: The 13 Argument.

argument.p:
We mu≈øt pray the Lord of the harve≈øt, Math: 9:23:38: to thru≈øt forth laborers into the harve≈øt. God will not haue men onely to pray, but al≈øo
to u≈øe other meanes. Ergo The High Court of Parliament, mu≈øt be the more carefull, to provide what they may, that godly and paynfull Mini≈øters who≈øe labours God hath already ble≈ø≈øed, may not by head and ≈øholders, be thru≈øt out of the Church, as they are.

div.p: There is but one marginall note upon this Argument, which hath been often an≈øwered.

So al≈øo hath all his other an≈øwer to the ≈øaid Argument touching the ≈øowyng of the tares of ≈øedition, ≈øchi≈øme, faction, and di≈øturbing of the peace. All which doe rather be long to them that teach that a true ju≈øtifiyng faith may be lo≈øt, that there is no certeinty of Salvation, that plead for ignorance and an ignorant Mini≈øtery: (the mother of rebellion and trea≈øon, and all other ≈øinnes again≈øt God & man) and other ≈øuch like things.
