argument.p: Luc: 9:26 In the time of per≈øecution, men ought not to be a≈øhamed of the word of Chri≈øt, but to confe≈ø≈øe and ≈øpeake for the ≈øame. Ergo. They ought much more ≈øo to doe in the tyme of peace, in a kingdome, and to a King and State profes≈øing the go≈øpell.

div.head: Marginall notes.
div.q: G. Powela As if that Di≈øciplinarian giddines, were Gods word.
div.p:
Reply.Though you take your plea≈øure of us, yet take heed, take heed, you bla≈øpheme not the ordinances of Chri≈øt. Such certainly are litle better theÃÑ mad men, who impute giddines to the Di≈øcipline of Chri≈øt, commaunded to be kept without ≈øpot and unrebukeable untill his appearing. 1 Tim: 6:13 It is no newe thing for them that ≈øtands for Gods truth to be accounted mad men, 2 King 9, 11 Acts: 26.24 Luc: 15:17:
or be≈øides them≈øelues, and in the≈øe dayes, Prote≈øtants ≈øcared out of their wits. But let them that now offend this way, and e≈øpecially that account Gods ordinances to be giddines, let them (I ≈øay) repent and come to
them≈øelues, le≈øt the Lord ≈øtrike them with a farre wor≈øe ≈øpirit of giddines then yet they haue, which will not be ca≈øt out by any meanes, no, not by prayer and fa≈øting.
div.q: G. Powelb Here againe the Supplicants confe≈ø≈øe that we profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt and his word. Why doe they exclame then?
div.p: If you ≈øo call it, we do exclame as we doe,Reply that we may profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt and his word more ≈øincerely, without any traditions of men in Gods wor≈øhip. The Churches of Ephe≈øus, Pergamus and Thyatira, profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øt and his word and had many excellent things in them; yet our Saviour him≈øelfe exclameth, and calleth them to reformation of the few thinges ami≈ø≈øe with them. So did Paule to the Churches of Corinth and Galatia.
div.q: G. Powelc Feare and weaknes for≈øooth, becau≈øe they will not partake with Schi≈ømatikes.
div.p: Let ≈øcoffers and mockers take heede, Reply. P≈øal. 2.4 prov: 1:26 that he that dwelleth in the heaven laugh not: yea that the Lord haue them not in deri≈øion: yea lea≈øt he laugh at their de≈øtruction, and mocke when their feare commeth etc.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 14. Argument.
div.q: G. PowelThe argument followeth not: for refractary Mini≈øters are neither Chri≈øt, nor his word, as hath been declared before.
div.p: It hath indeed been ≈øayd before: but by whom, when,Reply. or where hath it been declared and proved? Which of us hath ever ≈øayde that we are Chri≈øt or his word? As the Church is called Chri≈øt. 1. Cor. 12.12. ≈øo both the Mini≈øters & all true beleevers are the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt. La≈øtly, they that ≈øtriue again≈øt humane Ceremonyes in Gods wor≈øhip, and for the ordinances onely of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, doe ≈øtriue al≈øo for Chri≈øt and his word.

div.head: THE 15. ARGVMENT.

argument.p:
As the Parliament hath had a godly care of ≈øeverity, for the better converting of the Papi≈øts, ≈øo likewi≈øe there ought to be the
like godly care for their good in≈øtruction by ≈øuch able Mini≈øters, as again≈øt whom they may haue no iu≈øt exception. Ergo.

p.hi: In this re≈øpect the Parliament ought to doe the more; for the liberty of the Mini≈øters ≈øu≈øpended etc.

div.p: I defferr the reply to all the marginall notes, to the further an≈øwer following.
div.q: G. PowelAs if there were not able Mini≈øters inough, in both Vniver≈øities & in other partes of the kingdome (if competent mayntenance might be procured for them) for every Congregation, without the ≈ømall hand full of ≈øchi≈ømaticall Mini≈øters.
div.p: ReplyPart of this hath been an≈øwered before: yet to help the an≈øwerers memory (if it be weake) I tell him agayne, that if we had tentymes as many more, as there are, either in the univer≈øities, or el≈øe where, there would be u≈øe of them all. The Lords harve≈øt is great: the day is farr ≈øpent: the laborers that are, are ≈øome ≈øo weake, ≈øome ≈øuch loyterers, and ≈øome ≈øo unskilfull, that they make no cleane worke, but leaue as much behind them, as they gather and carry before them.

Be≈øides is it a ≈ømall matter, for the Mini≈øter to be acquainted with the people, and the people with the Mini≈øter? As likewi≈øe for the Mini≈øter to affect the people, and the people the Mini≈øter? Agayne, are all fit to teach & to governe the people, that are learned and good ≈øchollers in the Vniver≈øity? It hath been ju≈øtly blamed by learned wryters of our ≈øide, that ≈øome Papi≈øts haue bla≈øphemou≈øly called the ≈øcriptures a no≈øe of waxe, & a ≈øhipmans ho≈øe. But now would God, it were not ≈øo made in open pulpit, by ≈øome great ≈øchollers, that are accounted great divines. Yea, it is lameÃÑ table, that in ≈øome great places (if not in the greate≈øt) men preach of the ≈øcriptures; and yet never interpret the ≈øcripture wherof they preach: yea that indeed ≈øo hammer the ≈øcripture, as though it were a peece of mettall, the which
they might worke or ca≈øt: into what forme them≈øelues be≈øt liked: who al≈øo make the Pulpite a place rather to ≈øheew their owne witt, wherby to win credit and pray≈øe to them≈øelues, (perhaps al≈øo to get a Bi≈øhopprike in the end) then faithfully to deliver the me≈ø≈øage of God, wherby to glorifie God, and either to winne ≈øoules unto him, or to confirme and further in godlines, tho≈øe that are already wonne. La≈øtly, who rather playe with the ≈øcripture as if it were ≈øome gue gawe, then wi≈øely handle the ≈øame.

As for competent maintenance, I remember what one (that hath now turned his coate, and every where almo≈øt chafeth at vs like a Cooke, I remember (I ≈øay) what he once an≈øwered a Bi≈øhop being asked, where he would haue ≈øufficient maintenance for preachers in every Congregation: A good thong (quoth he) might be cut out of your hyde. As al≈øo what Iohn Bapti≈øt ≈øayd unto the people,Luc: 3:11
He that hath two coates, let him part with him that hath none. So ≈øay I, that for the better mayntenance of the go≈øpell where there were neede; there might be many a good ≈øhare had out of the ≈øurperfluity of tho≈øe, that maintayne their wiues in ≈øattin and dammaske gownes, velvet kirtles, cheynes etc: that bring up their children like the children of Noble men, that fat them≈øelues and theirs, and ≈øtarue the Lords people: and who after their great abundance Preach not ≈øo much in 4 yeares, as they did before, in one.
div.q: G. PowelSuppo≈øe there were not able Mini≈øters inough for this purpo≈øe: Haue not the refractary Mini≈øters, then greater rea≈øon to joyne with their brethren in preaching the go≈øpell, confuting the Papi≈øts etc: then ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly to quarrell about cro≈ø≈ø and ≈øurplice, and to for≈øake their nece≈ø≈øary vocation?
div.p:
Nay.Reply, Haue not the Prelats the more rea≈øon to ≈øuffer
us ≈øtill in the worke of the Mini≈øtery with them? We are all willing, ≈øo farre to joyne with any in preaching the Go≈øpell, as we may doe nothing again≈øt the Go≈øpell, to craze the peace of our owne con≈øcience. The an≈øwerer often charging us with ≈øuper≈øtition, coÃÑvinceth them that ≈øay that we doe not that which we doe of con≈øcience. For if we be ≈øuper≈øtitious in not yeelding to cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øurplice, etc: then are they to us meere matters of coÃÑ≈øcience. For ≈øuper≈øtition is not in words, but hath her ≈øeate in the con≈øcience.

argument.p:
Ephe≈ø: 2:14 15:
As Chri≈øt Ie≈øus to make peace betwixt Iewes and Gentils, tooke away the Ceremonyes ordayned by God him≈øelfe, becau≈øe they had been a partition wall betwixt the ≈øayd Iewes & Gentils: and in≈øtituted no other in their places: ≈øo the Ceremonyes & other thinges now in que≈øtion, having been the meanes of much debate among≈øt us, wherby the buildyng of the Church hath been greatly hindred, and the enimyes thereof ≈øtrenghtned; they ought in this re≈øpect to be removed. Ergo.

p.hi: The Mini≈øters now mole≈øted for the ≈øayd thinges inque≈øtion, ought to be ≈øpoken for and releeved, and that by the Parliament, becau≈øe none may doe it better.

div.head: The Marginall Notes.
div.q: G. Powela Hence appeareth what things they be, that the refractaryes are offended with, why then doe they pretend, the go≈øpell of Chri≈øt, reconciliation with God etc: Ad populum phaleras:
div.p:
Reply.The≈øe things being repugnant to the purity and ≈øincerity of ihe go≈øpell, under which God will not be wor≈øhipped in any ≈øuch Ceremoniall ≈øorte,Iohn: 4:23: but in ≈øpirit and truth; Being al≈øo ≈øuch, as for which the Mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell is re≈øtrayned (upon the liberty wherof dependeth the ≈øalvation of the people and their reconciliation with God)
There is no cau≈øe, why ≈øuch ≈øcoffing and frumping outcryes ≈øhould be made again≈øt us, as here & el≈øe where are made. Yea, though the mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell, were not for the≈øe thinges re≈øtrayned, yet being urged in the wor≈øhip of God, they are unlawfull: and men ≈øtanding again≈øt them, and in all humility de≈øiryng them to be removed by lawfull authority, may well be ≈øayd to ≈øtand in Gods cau≈øe, and to plead for God.
div.q: G. Powelc O, Martin was an mode≈øt man.
div.p: Thanks be to God,Reply that you haue no other then Martin to upbrayd vs with: who was unknowne what he was, and who≈øe writing was never approved by us: and who al≈øo though he je≈øted at ≈øome manners of your ≈øide, yet never wrote ≈øo bitterly as many of you now doe.
div.q: G. Poweld They will offend, and yet will not be told of it.
div.p: You haue not proved us to offend,Reply. in tho≈øe thinges wherein you impute mo≈øt offence unto us. If we doe offend, we are more then told of it: yea our puni≈øhment is greater then our offence, becau≈øe it is greater both then the law appoynteth, and al≈øo then the puni≈øhment of other who≈øe offences are greater.
div.q: G. Powele Heat of contention may carry men further then were expedient. But are the refractaryes mylder in this kind? Witnes all their Pamphlets and libels written again≈øt us.
div.p:
The fir≈øt parte of this note is plentifully ju≈øtified, not onely by the booke Scoti≈øh Genevating, Reply. by the mo≈øt ≈øcurrilous booke of The picture of a Puritan, and by the an≈øwerers owne booke De Adiaphoris, but al≈øo by this pre≈øeÃÑt an≈øwer, injoyned and allowed by authority: wherein (for ought I know) there are more rayling, ≈øcoffing, and untrue ≈øpeeches, then are in all the bookes here unju≈øtly termed pamphlets and libells. If any notwith≈øtanding of us doe offeÃÑd in this kind, they are not iu≈øtified by the re≈øt: yet this is
not to be forgotten, that they that be the loo≈øers, and goe away with the blowes, may be the better borne withall, in their words.
div.q: G. Powelf A di≈øgracefull terme. But doe they acknowledge them≈øelues non conformitans and ≈øchi≈ømaticall?
div.p: Reply.If the word conformitan be a di≈øgracfull terme, is ther not di≈øgrace in Conformity and being conformed? For are not the≈øe words Conformed, conformity, and conformitans coniugata? Why then are we urged to conforme? Eyther therfore you ju≈øtifie vs in not conforming our ≈øelues (for who would di≈øgrace him≈øelfe?) or el≈øe you doe ill to ≈øay, we call you by a di≈øgracefull name, when we call you conformitans.
div.q: G. Powelg Suam ≈øcabiem affricant.
div.p: Reply.It needeth no an≈øwer. All men know and dayly heare, how they galle us in every ≈øermon, and how litle we deale with them.
div.q: G. Powelh A malicious lye. There are fewe or none in the Church of England, ≈øo ignorant and ≈øo ≈øcandalous in the Mini≈øtery, as here the ≈øuppliants in≈øinuat: and if any ≈øuch be among≈øt us, ≈øure I am that (upon complaint and intimation otherwi≈øe) they are ≈øeverely cen≈øured and puni≈øhed for it. Yet I mu≈øt giue them to under≈øtand, that ≈øcandalous Mini≈øters for life, are more tolerable in the Church, then ≈øuch as be factious, Schi≈ømaticall, or ≈øcandalous for doctrine, and phanaticall conceits. Plus enim nocent doctrinae ≈øcandala, quam morum delictae.
div.p:
Reply.Neither malicious, nor lye. All men, good & bade doe too well knowe, too many both ignorant and ≈øcandalous to be in the Mini≈øtery. If it might plea≈øe his mo≈øt excelleÃÑt Maje≈øtie, or his mo≈øt Honorable Councell, to ≈øend out Commis≈øions into all Countryes, and to appoynt indifferent Commis≈øioners (neither Bi≈øhops nor any other Prelaticall per≈øons, becau≈øe ≈øuch are partyes, but religious Noble men and gentlemen) to inquyre of this matter, the truth would much better appeare to the everla≈øting
reproch, of all tho≈øe that doe ≈øo ju≈øtifie the pre≈øent ≈øtate of the Mini≈øtery. For the re≈øt of the former note, who knoweth not, that one lewd per≈øon (how ba≈øe and abject ≈øoever) may, and dayly doth procure & worke more trouble to a good Mini≈øter, and doth more ea≈øily prevaile to his ejection, then twentie good men (though of never ≈øo good credit) yea, then ≈øomtymes the whole Pari≈øh be≈øids (though never ≈øo great) can doe for the good and peace, of the be≈øt Mini≈øter? That al≈øo for a man, not to were a ≈øurplice, or make a cro≈ø≈ø in the ayre (or I cannot tell wher or how) etc: ≈øhould be le≈ø≈øe tolerable, then many great ≈øinnes expre≈øly forbidden by God him≈øelf, is very ≈øtrang, yea lamentable, yea fearefull to thinke: much more to ≈øpeake and write: mo≈øt of all to print, for all the world, yea for all po≈øterity to behold. E≈øpecially, that a learned man, a divine and Mini≈øter of the word ≈øhould ≈øo thinke, ≈øpeake, write, and publi≈øh. If this be not to preferre the authority of mortall and frayle man, before the authority of the immortall and mo≈øt mighty God,Mar. 7:13: yea to make the word of God of no authority by traditions which men haue ordeyned, I know not what is. As for fal≈øe doctrine, or phanaticall conceits, which of you all, can ju≈øtly charge us with them, as many conformitans may be with divers poynts of Popery, with toyes in the pulpit (more fit for a ≈øtage, then for Mo≈øes chayre) with fooli≈øh allegoryes, and with ≈øuch pleading for Ceremonyes, as that the people are not onely not edified, but al≈øo corrupted and infected: yea & the minds of tho≈øe that are judicious, and haue any ta≈øt of goodnes, exceedingly wounded? The like commis≈øion, that before I ≈øpake of, would ≈øheew the trueth of the≈øe things al≈øo.
div.q: G. Poweli An impudent and lowd lye.
div.p: What an exclamation and accu≈øation is this, upon the Printers fault, in ≈øetting Conformitans for unconformitans? If mallice had not over≈øwayed rea≈øon, he might ea≈øily haue ≈øeen it to be ≈øo, by the ≈øcope of the author. I haue al≈øo ≈øeene (and ≈øo many other) divers copyes corrected heerin, with the authors owne hand.

The notes with (k) l) and m) are often an≈øwered. The Greeke word of the next note, the Printer for want of Greeke letters, was fayne to omit. For which rea≈øon al≈øo all the fallacies in the end of every an≈øwer, are left out: the re≈øt of the note followeth.
div.q: G. Poweln The tyme of the old Te≈øtament beyng expired, Chri≈øt aboli≈øhed the Ceremoniall law, and ordeyned the New Te≈øtament: what will they conclude from hence?
div.p: ReplyThat no Ceremonyes being in≈øtituted by God him≈øelfe ≈øince the death of Chri≈øt whereby the former were abrogated, God is therfore now to be wor≈øhipped in ≈øpirit & truth; and that no man or Church what≈øoever hath power to ordeyne Ceremonyes for the wor≈øhip of God.
div.q: G. Powelo VVhat? Not any? No Sacraments? No other Ceremonyes?
div.p:
ReplyNot any. No Sacraments. No other Ceremonyes. For the Sacraments that now are, were ordayned before Chri≈øts ≈øufferings, and before the abrogation of the Ceremoniall law upon his Cro≈ø≈ø. The≈øe words goe teach all Nations, Colo≈ø: 2:14: math. 28:19 Rom. 3.2: P≈øal. 1 47.19:26 baptis≈øing them etc. doe but ratifie and confirme that which was before in≈øtituted: as al≈øo make for the commucating of the word and Sacraments to the Gentils, which before had been peculiar to the Iewes. All other things now in the Church for the goverment thereof, differing from tho≈øe that were under the law, were ordeyned by Chri≈øt (or at lea≈øt he had given commaundement for them to the Apo≈øtles) before his pas≈øion, and therefore before the abrogation of the Ceremonyes. For Chri≈øt commanded
his Apo≈øtles to teach onely ≈øuch things, as he had commaÃÑ ded them: Mat: 28:20: Ioh: 14:26. and the Holy Gho≈øt was onely to teach them althinges, and to bring althinges to their remembrance, which he (Chri≈øt him≈øelfe) had told them.
The (p) hath been an≈øwered in the marginall note with h) of the 5 Argument.
div.q: G. Powelq Fal≈øe. They are the bonds of ≈øociety, be≈øids other u≈øes for edificatioÃÑ.
div.p: Then, where there is no Cro≈ø≈øe and ≈øurplice,Reply. there is no ≈øociety; or at the lea≈øt but loo≈øe and weake ≈øociety. But perhaps he meaÃÑeth no Lordly Epi≈øcopall ≈øociety, becau≈øe no Ceremony, no Bi≈øhop. He may al≈øo meaÃÑe ≈øociety betwixt a Mini≈øter and his benefice. So ≈øome haue found it true. Touching the other u≈øes for edification, we de≈øire to ≈øee them.
div.q: G. Powelr If the ≈øupplicants reque≈øt were granted in the Ceremonyes, yet would the refractary Mini≈øters be re≈øtles ≈øtill, untill they had altogeather brought in their New Di≈øcipline: and (peradventure) more re≈øtles then, then ever they were before:
div.p: As the newes of Chri≈øt birth at the fir≈øt troubled all Ieru≈øalem, Reply. ≈øo it troubleth all Papall Prelats to thinke of Chri≈øts coÃÑmyng, in the Di≈øcipline that he hath ordeyned. The≈øe wordes, their Di≈øcipline and new Di≈øcipline, are but marginall Mathematicall fictions. None of us de≈øire any thing of our owne, but onely the ordinances of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus: which cannot be otherwi≈øe called newe, then his commandement for loving one another, Iohn 13.34 is called a new commandement.

This Di≈øcipline we haue never attempted to bring in, by any unduetifull meanes, but by all humble ≈øupplication to the ≈øupreame authority, to which we acknowledge the e≈øtabli≈øhment thereof to belong. Therefore, that we will be more re≈øtles eyther before or after the obteyning therof then becommeth us, is but his owne imagination, froÃÑ
the experience (perhaps) of the re≈øtle≈ønes of ≈øome Prelats, till they be Bi≈øhops, and afterward till they come to be Archbi≈øhops. Yea theÃÑ al≈øo, till they get ≈øome further honor, yea till they haue ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed all tho≈øe, that they think doe any wayes di≈ølike of ≈øuch places. If it might plea≈øe his Maje≈øtie and the other States of this Kingdome, but to permit it in ≈øome places where it might be mo≈øt conveniently, it ≈øhould much more clearely appeare, both how we would content our ≈øelues with all humble thanks to his Maje≈øtie and to the other States in that behalfe: and al≈øo how much better this would agree with all Civill Magi≈øtracy, then their pre≈øent Hierarchicall and Eccle≈øia≈øticall goverment doth: yea how farre more beneficiall it would be to the Common wealth: and finally how untrue many other imputations are, whereby it is commonly di≈øgraced. If any ≈øhould abu≈øe the ≈øame, or him≈øelfe in the execution therof, we never denyed, but that ≈øuch offenders ≈øhould be ≈øubject to the cen≈øure of his Maje≈øtie, or of any his inferior officers.
div.q: G. Powels Sound and ≈øolid peace, will never be wrought, but by recalling the refractary Mini≈øters from Schi≈øme and faction unto perfect obedieÃÑce.
div.p:
Reply.You mu≈øt fir≈øt proue us to be in a ≈øchi≈øme and faction. In the meane time, ≈øound and ≈øolid peace would a thow≈øand tymes better be made by removing all humane Ceremonyes, by a more free preaching of the go≈øpell of peace: If all Mini≈øters ≈øhould conforme them≈øelues, yet if the go≈øpell ≈øhould be ≈øincerely preached, (though never any word ≈øhould be ≈øpoken again≈øt the Ceremonyes, and other thinges in controver≈øie particularly) certeynly, the Ceremonyes and other matters now in que≈øtion, would be as odious, and in as great di≈øgrace as now they are. It is therefore a vayne thing to labor for peace, without removing
of tho≈øe thinges. Touching obedience it can never be perfect to man, where it is not ≈øound towardes God. The e≈øtabli≈øhing of Gods ordinances, will teach & worke perfect obedience unto men, to whom obedience is due.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 16. Argument.
div.q: G. Powel1 If the que≈øtion be but ≈øub≈øcription, cro≈ø≈ø etc: wherefore then, haue they maynly cryed out that it was the cau≈øe of God etc:
div.p: All this is often an≈øwered.Reply The lea≈øt tran≈øgres≈øion of Gods word, and the lea≈øt obedience to Gods word, is the cau≈øe of God, as well as the greate≈øt. I wonder the an≈øwerer was not a≈øhamed, ≈øo often to repeate the ≈øame things.
div.q: G. Powel2 VVe hold not Sub≈øcription Ceremonyes, etc. ab≈øolutly nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation, nor to be impo≈øed upon every Church (for why ≈øhould not other Churches u≈øe their liberty?) Yea our Church hath power to alter the≈øe particulars, yet we know ≈øome ordinances nece≈ø≈øary for gathering a≈ø≈øemblyes, e≈øtabli≈øhing of a Church, and be as it were bonds and links of ≈øociety.
div.p: How doth the fir≈øt poynt of this an≈øwer agree with that that ≈øome of the great Prelats hold,Reply that their authority is Apo≈øtolicall, and the Ceremonyes matters of order and decency? Are not thinges Apo≈øtolicall and decent, common to all Churches? Or may our Church, alter that that is Apo≈øtolicall? Or why ≈øhould the≈øe ceremonyes, be more nece≈ø≈øary for our Church, then for other Churches? Or not decent for other Churches, and yet decent for ours? If al≈øo Eccle≈øia≈øticall juri≈ødiction, be in ve≈øted into the crowne, except the King and with him the officers of the crowne, be only the Church; our Church hath no power to alter them, having no Eccle≈øia≈øticall iurisdiction re≈øident in it ≈øelfe. The latter part of this an≈øwer is needles, our a≈ø≈øemblyes beyng already gathered. What a fooli≈øh & gro≈ø≈ø ab≈øurditie al≈øo is it, to in≈øinuate that an invi≈øible cro≈ø≈ø, or a ≈ømocki≈øh ≈øurplice, ≈øhould be of any effecacy for gathering of a≈ø≈øemblyes?
div.q: G. Powel3 Yea the≈øe particulars, Sub≈øcription, Ceremonyes etc, being jmpo≈øed by the Church and commaunded by the Magi≈øtrate, are nece≈ø≈øary to be ob≈øerved under payne of ≈øinne, ≈øeeing he that re≈øi≈øteth authority, re≈øi≈øteth the ordinance of God.
div.p: ReplyWhat if they be commanded onely by the Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrate, not jmpo≈øed by the Church? Or jmpo≈øed by the Church onely, the Magi≈øtrat beyng an infidell, or a per≈øecuter of the Church? Can payne of ≈øinne al≈øo be without payne of damnation? Are not tho≈øe things that are to be obyed,contradictioÃÑ under payne of damnation, nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation? Hence al≈øo it followeth, that things once commauÃÑded by the Church or Magi≈øtrat (e≈øpecially by both) are as holy, as the jmmediate commandements of God. The particular inconveniences and ab≈øurdities heerof are infinit. What al≈øo is heere ≈øayd, that was not wont to be ≈øayd by the Papi≈øts again≈øt the Martyrs?
div.q: G. Powel4 That they are thinges indifferent etc. and may be u≈øed without ≈øinne we haue proved in a booke De Adiaphoris.
div.p:
Reply.Alas M. Powell, make not ≈øuch account of your booke De Adiaphoris, then which, there never came more ≈øimple ≈øtuffe from any man reputed learned. You had neede to recant your bla≈øphemous poynt therein, again≈øt the authority of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus for making lawes in his Church. Uerily you might as well haue denyed him to be a King, and a redeemer. To the 5 part of this an≈øwer unto this 16. Argument, reply hath often been made. That thes things are become bones of contention, is onely the fault of the Prelats, that ≈øtriue with might and maine for them. They acknowledge that they haue power to alter and remoue them, and the ≈øee great rea≈øon ≈øo to doe: neither can they giue any rea≈øons but childi≈øh for continuance of them, and yet to the great di≈øhonor of God, and to the greefe of thow≈øands of the godly, they reteyne them. For our
parts, if we were not troubled for them, we would be ≈øo farre from contending about them, that we would never aske after them, neither would we care if we never ≈øaw them.

div.head: THE 17. ARGVMENT.

argument.p: God hath lately vi≈øited us with a fearefull pe≈øtilence, which yet is not cea≈ø≈øed: and the end of all his cha≈øti≈øements is, P≈øal. 94:12: Heb. 12:19. Revel: 3:19 Levi: 26:18 Iohn 5:14: P≈øal: 193: P≈øa: 116:12 to make us all the better by them. Yea to make us more Zealous: which if we doe not, he threateneth wor≈øe thinges unto us. God hath al≈øo lately mightely delivered us, from the greate≈øt danger, that ever any people were in: to this end al≈øo that we might pray≈øe him the more: and that all E≈øtates may more ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øult and deliberate, what to giue unto the Lord for all his benefites. 2 Chron: 32 25: And this is the more to be con≈øidered, becau≈øe the Lord tooke the unthankfulnes of Hezekia in a ≈ømall matter for his health, very unkindly. This our former deliverance al≈øo was the greater, becau≈øe it was wrought without the meanes of our prayers. Ergo

p.hi: The High Court of Parliament, ought to be the more Zealous for the go≈øpell etc: the rather now, becau≈øe they know not (at lea≈øt many of them) whither ever they ≈øhall haue the like opportunitie agayne or no. Yea that ≈øo al≈øo, their thankfulnes may be as publik and renouned, as our deliverance: Yea, their zeale mu≈øt be the more again≈øt all Popery (in re≈øpect of our danger by the Papi≈øt) for the rooting out of every ≈øtump thereof, that their ≈øoules may haue the more comfort, e≈øpecially in death: and that their memory may be the more honorable, with all po≈øterity.

div.p: This is the generall ≈øub≈øtance of the 17. Argument, though amplified by many perticular places, examples of ≈øcripture. Now let us ≈øee what is ≈øayd again≈øt the ≈øame, in the notes, and in the Further an≈øwer.

div.head: Marginall notes.
div.q: G. Powela The mi≈øtake the ends, as tho≈øe Gentiles did, who affirmed they were plagued, becau≈øe of the Chri≈øtians contempt of their Gods.
div.p: Reply.Nay, you haue forgotten your Logike, in mi≈øtaking the end for the efficient cau≈øe. The Gentils did not affirme them≈øelues plagued, to the end the Chri≈øtians might contemne their Gods, but becau≈øe they thought they had contemned their Gods. This error is in all the an≈øwer following. For the author tooke not upon him, to particularize the ≈øinnes for which God had vi≈øited the land, but onely to ≈øhew what the Lord looked for from us, both by his works of Iu≈øtice, and al≈øo by his workes of mercy and goodnes among≈øt us. Therefore the notary and an≈øwerer in all that followeth, ≈øitteth be≈øides the cu≈øhion. Agayne, what doth this note el≈øe import, but a ≈øoothing up of theÃÑ ≈øelues and of all other in their ≈øinnes, that they may not enter into perticular examination and judging of them≈øelues? When as euery man, and every ≈øtate ≈øhould perticularly cen≈øure and judge him≈øelfe and his ≈øinnes, to haue had a ≈øtroke in provoking the wrath of God ≈øo again≈øt us. And therefore happy had it been for the Prelats, if they had ≈ømitten them≈øelues upon the bre≈øts, for their hard dealing with the Church, in re≈øtraynyng the Lords ≈øervants, that would haue given every one in the Lords hou≈øhould, his portion in due ≈øea≈øon. So happy al≈øo were it, if every other ≈øtate and per≈øon, would doe the like touching their perticular ≈øinnes.

The ≈øecond note with (b) is nothing: becau≈øe the ≈øchi≈øme is not yet proved again≈øt us. Though we deny not, but that for our ≈øinnes, the Lord hath vi≈øited this land as well as for the ≈øinnes of other, yet not for any ≈øchi≈øme of ours. The like I ≈øay for the like cau≈øe, of the note with (c) And though it behoveth the Parliament, e≈øpecially, to con≈øider of the workes of God, (as repre≈øenting the body
of the land,) yet I wi≈øh all other likewi≈øe to con≈øider of the ≈øame.
div.q: G. Powela I will not de≈øcant of the Suppliants meanyng, in alleaging this example. The wi≈øe may con≈øider it.
div.p: So the wi≈øe may con≈øider, how fooli≈øh malice is,Reply for want of matter from words, to wrangle with a mans meaning, The example is good and holy. The Bee will gather hony, out of a ≈øtinkyng weede: but the Spyder ≈øucketh deadly poy≈øon, out of the fayre≈øt and ≈øweete≈øt flower. The flatterer careth not what he ≈øay again≈øt one, ≈øo that he may plea≈øe another.
div.q: G. Powele To wit by ≈øetling the ≈øtate thereof, again≈øt hereticall Papi≈øts, and ≈øchi≈ømaticall refractarves.
div.p: I grant this;Reply it beyng under≈øtood of ≈øuch ≈øchi≈ømaticall refractaryes, as in part rent them≈øelues, both from the Apo≈øtolicall doctrine, and al≈øo from the auncient Apo≈øtolicall Churches, as likwi≈øe froÃÑ all other Churches throughly in doctrine reformed: and ≈øo ≈øtand in medio, betwixt ≈øuch Churches, and the Romi≈øh Synagogues. Who al≈øo beyng admoni≈øhed thereof, in duetifull manner by their brethren; yea by ≈øome ≈øpeciall works of Gods loving ≈øeverity, doe per≈øi≈øt in their ≈øayd ≈øchi≈øme, in a mo≈øt refractary manner.
div.q: G. Powelf As if no good could come unto the Church, but the re≈øtitution of ≈øchi≈ømaticall Mini≈øters, which is indeed no good.
div.p:
Reply.Let the reader be plea≈øed to ≈øee, whereupon this note is gathered, and he ≈øhall ≈øee, that there is no ground therof. The author onely asketh a que≈øtion upon former promi≈øes, whether ≈øuch and ≈øuch thinges con≈øidered, the Parliament would di≈ø≈øolue their meeting without doeyng any further matter in that behalfe (that is for the Mini≈øters pleaded for) then they had donne. He doth not ≈øay, without doyng any good, but any further matter, in≈øinuating
thereby, that they had done ≈øomething allready: agayne he ≈øpeaketh not of all cau≈øes, but only ≈øayth, in that behalfe. But this is the an≈øwerers ≈øophi≈øtry,Sophi≈øtry. often detected. How≈øoever he ≈øay no good hath been done by Mini≈øters whoÃÑ he calleth refractary, yet thow≈øands that feare God can te≈øtifie, that the Church hath received more good by ≈øuch Mini≈øters, then ever it hath or will by any Papall Prelats, careles Non-re≈øidents, trencher chaplins and idle bellyes, that ≈øeeke their owne, and not the thinges that are Ie≈øus Chri≈øts, and who are noted, in all publike meetings for reformation of abu≈øes, more to hinder then to further all good motions again≈øt the Papi≈øts, again≈øt ≈øwearing, & for the religious ob≈øervation of the Saboths etc, then common Chri≈øtians, at the lea≈øt then tho≈øe, that they doe contemptuou≈øly call laye per≈øons.
div.q: G. Powelg What godlines is there, in wilfull and malicious confronting the Magi≈øtrat, in repinyng at their brethren, and ≈øuper≈øtitous for ≈øakinge their callings, flockes and all to the vndoyng of them≈øelues, their wiues children, and frends?
div.p:
Reply.None at all. But who doe more comfront the Magi≈øtrat in all kingdomes, then Papall Prelats, that hold their owne juri≈ødiction to be iure divino by Gods law, and that therefore deny all Eccle≈øia≈øticall iuri≈ødiction to be ab≈øolutly inve≈øted into the crowne of tho≈øe kingdomes where they liue, that take upon them to deale withovt law, be≈øides law, and directly contrary to law, and that many wayes oppre≈ø≈øe the Magi≈øtrats ≈øubjects at their plea≈øure? As for us, I haue ≈øayd before, I ≈øay agayne, and it is publi≈øhed to all the world in the booke intituled, A prote≈øtation of the Kings Supremacy, that we are ≈øo farr from confronting the Magi≈øtrat, that we attribute much more unto him, then all rhe Prelats doe. Touching repinyng at brethren, I know none guiltie heerof, except wi≈øhing that Chri≈øt Ie≈øus
may haue his owne, the Church her owne, the Magi≈øtrate his owne, the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, and the ≈øubjects of the Magi≈øtrat their owne, yea every Byrd to haue her owne feathers, I know none (I ≈øay) to repine, except wi≈øhing of the≈øe things, and that every mortall man would content him≈øelfe with his owne, be to repine. The re≈øt of this note hath been an≈øwered.
div.q: G. Powelh A calumnious cen≈øure.
div.p: What?Reply To ≈øay that vnworthy per≈øons are thru≈øt out into ≈øome of their places that are deprived? A man need not to a≈øcend into an high mountaine, or to ryde many myles out of London for proofe therof.
The next note with (b) after (h) and before (a, (as though the Notary had forgotten his alphabet) is often an≈øwered. The next note al≈øo with (a(after b) is not worthy of an≈øwer.
div.q: G. Powell VVe mu≈øt wi≈øely di≈øtingui≈øh between ≈øuch things as are proper to the Papicy, and what they haue by v≈øurpation, but are proper to the true Church of God.
div.p: Are Coapes, Surplices and Cro≈ø≈øe etc: Reply. proper to the true Church of God? If they be not, why is this noted upon the authors petition in this Argument, for removing of Popi≈øh ornaments? If they be, then either it is no Church, or an imperfect Church, that wanteth them.
div.q: G. Powelm Proper thereunto.
div.p:
Are no appurtinances of Romi≈øh religion to be hated,Reply. but ≈øuch as proper thereunto? This is wonderfull. For what appurtinances are there of Romi≈øh religion, which agree not either with Iudai≈øme, or Pagani≈øme? We are therfore to abhorre what≈øoever appurtinance of Romi≈øh religion, whereof there is no nece≈ø≈øary u≈øe in the ≈øervice of God, and which were better aboli≈øhed, then reteyned. Thus much to the marginall notes, of this 17 Argument.
In the re≈øt of the an≈øwer he dealeth deceitfully, racking divers particular examples, applyed by the author, only for amplyficaton and illu≈øtration of this generall Argument, or of ≈øome perticular branch thereof, racking (I ≈øay) ≈øuch perticular examples, and applying them to the maine conclu≈øion and petition, as intended by the author for a ≈øeverall Argument to confirme the ≈øame. Wheras in like manner, he might haue done the like with divers other perticulars in this generall Argument comprehended. But let us ≈øee what he ≈øayth.

div.head: Further an≈øwer to the 17. Argument.
div.q: G. PowelIn this Argument the Suppliants doe certeynly very worthily & chri≈øtianly di≈øcour≈øe, as of ≈øundry other things, ≈øo e≈øpecially concerning the Lords great mercyes etc.
div.p:
In the≈øe words, let the contrariety of the an≈øwerer, to almo≈øt in his whole an≈øwer written,Reply. be ob≈øerved. For he being a ≈øcholler, his words mu≈øt be ≈øchollerly interpreted. Becau≈øe therfore we are not to doubt, but that the an≈øwerer remeÃÑbreth, as well what he hath learned in the Ethicks, as in the Elenchs of Ari≈øtotle, may it plea≈øe the reader to vnder≈øtand, or (rather) to remember, that Ari≈øtotle in his ≈øayd Ethnicks, maketh great difference, betwixt bonum & bene, good and well: iu≈øtum and iu≈øte, that which is iu≈øt, and ju≈øtly. For he teacheth, that good & ju≈øt things may be done, by evill and uju≈øt men, which haue not the habit eyther generally of goodnes, or perticularly of Iu≈øtice: but he ≈øayth, that only good and ju≈øt men, which haue the habit of goodnes and ju≈øtice,Marc: 6:20: can doe things well and iu≈øtly. And this di≈øtinction is agreable to holy writ. For Herod is ≈øaide to haue done many thinges; viz. that were in them≈øelues good: the like may be ≈øayd of Saule and divers other. But certaine it is, that evil men can doe any good or ju≈øt thiÃÑg,
well and iu≈øtly. This commeth onely from the ≈øpirit of regeneration, and from a true faith wrought thereby, without which it is impos≈øible to plea≈øe God. For as much therfore,Heb: 11:6. as this an≈øwerer doth here te≈øtifie generally of the Supplicants, that they doe di≈øcour≈øe in this Argument not onely of many worthy and Chri≈øtian poyntes, but al≈øo worthily, and Chri≈øtianly, yea very worthily and Chri≈øtianly: contraritie yea al≈øo for as much as he ≈øetteth this downe for a certeynty, ≈øaying certeynly, how doth this, or can this agre, with all the reproch full termes before given by him unto them, of Schi≈ømatiks Refractaryes, wilfull contenders with the Magi≈øtrate, pre≈øumptuous cen≈øurers, wilfull and malicious confronters of the Magi≈øtrat, boa≈øters, lyars, impudent, blind and ignorant per≈øons, fal≈øe Prophets, fowers of ≈øedition, di≈øturbers of the Church etc? For can it be ≈øayd of ≈øuch men, and that for a certeynty, that they di≈øcour≈øe very worthily and Chri≈øtianly of ≈øundry things? Let it not be ≈øayd, that to di≈øcour≈øe, is but a matter of wordes. For their is the ≈øame rea≈øon of words and works. No man can ≈øay well and rightly that Ie≈øus is the Lord,
1 Cor: 12:3. but by the Holy Gho≈øt. Though an evill man therfore may ≈øpeake many good and Chri≈øtian things, yet onely good men, ≈øpeake good and Chri≈øtian things, well and chri≈øtianly.
div.q: G. PowelDoth God plague us, becau≈øe of the proceedinges again≈øt the refractary Mini≈øters? And not rather for our horrible ≈øinnes of ≈øecurity, pride, unthankfulnes etc: This is certeyne: and the re≈øt unproved:
div.p:
I haue told you,Reply of your mi≈øtaking your Logike before. The author di≈øputeth not perticularly of the ≈øinnes that moved the Lord to vi≈øite vs etc: but of the generall end wherfore he did both correct us, but al≈øo magnifie his mercy towards us. The which he applied to the particular poynt of favor for the Mini≈øters mole≈øted. Notwith≈øtanding, to an≈øwer your que≈øtion, though it cannot be denyed, that for other ≈øinnes the Lord hath ≈øo heavily
≈øcourged us, yet why ≈øhould the ≈øuppres≈øing of the Mini≈øtery of the go≈øpell be concluded? Was, not to receiue and heare the Di≈øciples of our Saviour, which were ≈øent out by two & two but for a time to prepare men for the go≈øpell, ≈øo great a ≈øinne, that our Saviour pronounceth, that it ≈øhould be ea≈øier for Sodom and Gonorrha in the day of iudgement then for ≈øuch a City, Mat. 10:14.15:
as ≈øhould not ≈øo receyue and heare his Di≈øciples, and ≈øhall the ≈øilencyng, and depriving of ≈øo many Mini≈øters ≈øetled in perticular Congregations, and all ready ble≈ø≈øed in their labors, be accounted no ≈øinne? Yea not onely the ≈øilencyng of them etc: but al≈øo, providyng that they ≈øhall haue no other meanes whereby to maynteyne them≈øelues, their wiues and children? God open your eyes to ≈øee, and moue your hearts ≈øo to coÃÑ≈øider hereof, that yee may not flatter your ≈øelues, but ≈øee your ≈øinne herein. Yea, becau≈øe your ≈øelfe ≈øpeake of unthankfulnes, as one ≈øpeciall ≈øinne provokyng Gods indignation, what greater unthankfullnes can there be, then ≈øo to intreate his ≈øervants, whom he hath ≈øo graced and ble≈ø≈øed? Iudge your ≈øelues yee Reverend Fathers (that are principall actors in this matter) that yee may not be iudged of the Lord. 1 Cor: 11.31 Take heed (I humbly be≈øeech you, in the feare of God) take heed (I ≈øay) in time, lea≈øt fire breake forth froÃÑ the Lord, and there be none to quench the ≈øame. In the de≈øtruction of Ieru≈øalem by Nebuchadnetzer, 2 Chron: 36 16: and the carying of the people away captiue to Babell: and in the la≈øt de≈øolation of the ≈øame City by the Romans, the like mi≈øu≈øing of the Lords Prophets is ≈øet downe as one principall cau≈øe therof.Mat: 21.35:23:37: And who I be≈øeech you, in ≈øuch mi≈øu≈øage of the Lords me≈ø≈øengers, had alwayes a principall hand? Had not the Prie≈øts of the Lord, that ≈øhould haue done the contrary? Serch the ≈øcriptures, and ≈øee if they bare not witnes in this behalfe.
If God once ≈øet things in order before you, P≈øal: 50.12: ≈øhall it be ≈øufficient to pleade, that the Mini≈øters of his word, again≈øt whom yee haue ≈øo proceeded, were Schi≈ømatikes, refractaryes etc. Alas, alas this wilbe but a weake plea. Yee haue herd before, that the Prophets were ≈øo termed.

La≈øtly, concernyng the particular ≈øinnes by you mentioned and other the like, from whence doe they more proceede, then froÃÑ the re≈øtraint of the word, by the Preaching wherof, they would be eyther repre≈ø≈øed or re≈øtrayned? If the libertie and free pa≈ø≈øage of the go≈øpell, worke an holy feare, humility, and duetifull thankfulnes, yea, if the preaching of the word, doe re≈øtrayne the mo≈øt wicked and reprobate them≈øelues, that they bite in their lips, hold their hands, and refrayne from many ≈øinnes, which otherwi≈øe they would commit, (as it cannot be denyed) doe not ≈øecurity, pride, unthankfulnes, & all other ≈øinnes come from the re≈øtraint of the word?

The an≈øwer to the Second ≈øuppo≈øed Argument, in this 17 conteyned, hath in part been an≈øwered before, becau≈øe it hath been proved, that we are no Schi≈ømaticall Mini≈øters. Touching the re≈øt of the ≈øayd an≈øwer, we deny not but that there are other meanes wherby that Honorable Court, may te≈øtifie their thankefulnes, yet this hindreth not, but that this may al≈øo be one: yea if it be granted that there are other, then by vertue of relation, this al≈øo mu≈øt be granted to be one. Yea, if mercy to the ≈øoule, be more then mercy to the body (as the ≈øoule is better then the body: and the mi≈øery of the ≈øoule greater then of the body; and cruelty to the ≈øoule wor≈øe then to the body) then it followeth that this is a ≈øpeciall & principall meanes, wherby to te≈øtifie their thankfulnes.

His an≈øwer to the third ≈øuppo≈øed argument in the 17
Argument hath al≈øo been an≈øwered. The ≈øame I ≈øay of his an≈øwer to the 5 ≈øuppo≈øed argument. Onely therin the an≈øwerers cen≈øure of the Parliament if they ≈øhould re≈øtore us, is to be ob≈øerved, viz. that they ≈øhall not onely attract guilt and remor≈øe of Con≈øcience, but al≈øo preiudice their Honorable age, and make their names reprochfull to all po≈øterity. This toucheth not only the Lords of the upper hou≈øe, and body of the Commons in the Netherhou≈øe, but al≈øo his mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øtie, without who≈øe Princely authoritie nothing can be done by the other. Let all Prelats that pleade more ≈øtoutly for ≈øuper≈øtitious Romi≈øh raggs, then they doe duly regard Gods holy ordinances, let ≈øuch Prelats rather take heede, that ≈øuch things as are here threatned to the Parliament by the an≈øwerer, doe not be fall unto them.

Whereas the an≈øwerer, in his an≈øwer to the ‚Ä¢ 4 ≈øuppo≈øed Argument betwixt the third and the fir≈øt, reckoneth us up (in the bitternes of his ≈øpirit) with all Schi≈ømatikes, Heretikes, Papi≈øts, Athi≈øts, murtherers, theues, cutpur≈øes, etc: therin he ≈øheeweth his brotherly loue and kindnes towards us,E≈øa: 53:12 Mar: 15:27. and how well he ≈øpareth us. But ≈øith Chri≈øt Ie≈øus was couÃÑted among the wicked; yea crucified betwixt two theeues. yea, and had al≈øo a murderer preferred before him; why ≈øhould we his ≈øervants, wretched men, and great ≈øinners be greeved or a≈øhamed, thus to be reckoÃÑed with ≈øuch vile per≈øons?2 Tim 2.12 Iohn 17.24 Yea rather we may the more comfort our ≈øelues, becau≈øe if we ≈øuffer with him, we are the better a≈ø≈øured that we ≈øhall reigne with him, who hath prayed the Father, that we may be with him, even where he is, to behold his glory.
div.q: G. Powel For Si≈øerae was a ≈øpeciall enimy of the children of I≈ørael,Iudges 4.2:The in≈øtance of Iaeel is altogether different, and Church of God, but the ornaments the Supplicants ≈øpeake of, are the good creatures of God, having no hurt at all in them.
div.p: Was not Si≈øera al≈øo the creature of God,Reply. and in that re≈øpect may it not be ≈øayd, that he had no evill in him? And is not the Pope al≈øo an enimy to the people and Church of God, as well as Sy≈øera was? Yea is he not much more, in as much as he is enimy to their ≈øpirituall ≈øtate, and everla≈øting ≈øalvation? Moreover, touching the ornaments of Popery mentioned in the Argument, doe we ≈øpeake of them as they were the creatures of God, or as they were and are ≈øtill by many Papi≈øts abu≈øed to Idolatry? What doth the an≈øwerer ≈øay for them, that might not haue been ≈øayd for the covering of the images of ≈øilver, I≈øa. 30:22 which the Iewes (that ≈øhould truely repent of Idolatry) were to pollute, that is to account as thinges polluted; and for the rich ornaments of the images of gold, which al≈øo they were to ca≈øt away as a men≈øtrous cloth, Sophi≈øtry. and (with great di≈ødayne) to ≈øay unto it, get thee hence. What fallacy this is, the an≈øwerer knoweth.
div.q: G. PowelNeyther were the Popi≈øh Prie≈øts, ever decked with our ornameÃÑts, neither are they now. Neither, were our ornaments ever wor≈øhipped, or abu≈øed to Idolatry, eyther are they yet. Neyther, if they had been, is it ab≈øolutly nece≈ø≈øary to de≈øtroy the ≈øub≈øtance of them etc, but only to take away the abu≈øe, and to re≈øtore the right u≈øe. The rea≈øons are ≈øheewed chap 11 De adiap horis.
div.p:
Are you ≈øure, their is never a Surplice now in England, Reply that was abu≈øed to Idolatry publikely in Queene Maryes time, or ≈øecretly ≈øithens that tyme? If it be true of ≈øurplices, are you ≈øure it is true of all Coapes? Nay rather, I ≈øcar≈øe thinke, that there is not any Coape now, that was not in the time of Popery. Be≈øides, haue you forgotten the di≈øtinction of idem ≈øpecie, and idem numero? Ahas ≈øent not the ≈øame Alter to Ieru≈øalem, that was at Dama≈øcus, 2 Kings 16:10: but onely commanded the like thereof to be made. By this rea≈øon al≈øo we may erect new images in Churches, (as ≈øome all
ready are in ≈øome places) and ≈øay that the≈øe images were never wor≈øhipped or abu≈øed.Exceter Here therfore behold agaiÃÑe your ≈øophi≈øtry.Sophi≈øtry. Touchyng the ≈øub≈øtance of things abu≈øed to Idolatry, we urge not the de≈øtroying thereof, neyther doe we deny the re≈øtoring of them to any good civill, or naturall u≈øe from which they were fir≈øt taken and imployed to Idolatry. But we deny that we ought to haue any ≈øuch honorable u≈øe, as to haue any place in the ≈øervice of God,Deut 12.31 who expre≈øly forbiddeth to be ≈øo wor≈øhipped. I under≈øtand this of ≈øuch thinges as God hath not commanded, or wherof there is no nece≈ø≈øary u≈øe. Such are the ornaments in que≈øtion. The objections again≈øt this are plentifully an≈øwered in other books. The 11. chapiter of your booke wherunto you referre us, is not worth the reading of a learned man. It conteyneth objections of your owne making not of ours. Which of us, was ever ≈øo mad, as to ≈øay, que ad Dei gloriam fiunt, iis colitur Deus. For are not the dutyes of the ≈øecond table performed for the glory of God? Is God wor≈øhipped by them? This is to confound both the tables. Who ever al≈øo ≈øaide, Quicquid fit ex fide et Deo placet, what≈øoever is done of faith, and plea≈øeth God, is the wor≈øhip of God? So our eating, drinking, and what≈øoever el≈øe we doe, ≈øhall be the wor≈øhip of God. I wonder you blu≈øhed not to impute ≈øuch thinges unto us, and to ca≈øt your owne ≈øhame upon us.

The third objection indeede in that chapter, touching the propo≈øition, is in part (yet not wholly) ours. But your an≈øwer thereunto maketh more for us then again≈øt us, as a child that hath well learned the principles of religion might ea≈øily ≈øhew. But I for beare an≈øwer of them, and leaue them to other to ≈øhew your childi≈øh weaknes there in, and in that whole booke. By the ≈øight wherof I praye
God you may ≈øee, what it is to write again≈øt the truth. In other things you haue written well, and we thanke God for your paynes: but in the≈øe cau≈øes your arguments are like fagots of thornes full of prickes without ≈øub≈øtance, bound with bonds of ≈øtrawe, which by the fire of Gods truth, are quickly burnt up, though for a time they fill agreat roome, and ≈øeeme to make a great blaze: yea they are like to ignis fatuus, which terrifieth ≈øimple men, as if it were a ≈øpirit, but is in truth, but a litle fire of certeyne ≈ølymie exhalations: at the mo≈øt they are but like a Comet or blazing ≈øtarr, which though it ≈øeeme to ignorant men, to be aboue in the ≈øtarrie heavens, with the fixed ≈øtarres, yet for all that is but in the highe≈øt region of the ayre, and at the la≈øt is di≈ø≈øolved into winds.

Thus much for reply to the 17. Argument: yea to all. For to the conclu≈øion of all (which the Notary & an≈øwerer unaptly call a di≈øtinct Argument) their is nothing an≈øwered requyring any further reply, then hath been already made. This therefore ≈øhall ≈øuffice, for defence of the former Arguments. In the an≈øwer whereof, though (perhaps) there be the more ≈øcoffes, reproches, cavils, bitter ≈øpeeches, and uncharitable collections, to haue provoked us unto the like, that thereby ≈øome further advantage might haue been mini≈øtred unto them, again≈øt our cau≈øe and again≈øt our ≈øelues: yet as the author of the argumeÃÑts, u≈øed not any ≈øuch word to provoke them, ≈øo I thought good to walke in the like ≈øtepes of mode≈øtie, that the defence of the Arguments might be the more ≈øuitable to the Arguments theÃÑ≈øelues: that the author of them might haue no cau≈øe ju≈øtly to blame me, for di≈øgracing his work and the cau≈øe it ≈øelfe by a contrary cour≈øe: and that the mindes of the Prelats may rather be molified towards vs.
then any thing more exa≈øperated again≈øt us. If it fall out otherwi≈øe, and that our mildnes doe ≈øtill increa≈øe their rigor, God (I hope) ≈øhall giue us patience, to indure what≈øoever he ≈øhall ≈øuffer them to doe unto us: together al≈øo with ≈øuch comfort, as all the world ≈øhall not be able to take away from us. For we are ≈øo throughly per≈øwaded, from the evidence of Gods truth, revealed in his word: and ≈øealed up in our hearts by his ≈øpirit, the cau≈øe wherein we ≈øtand, to be the cau≈øe of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, that we ≈øay with Paule, Acts 21.13: we are ready, not to be bound onely, (neither onely to loo≈øe our livings) but al≈øo (herein) to dye for the name of the Lord Ie≈øus. I ≈øpeake not this ≈øeditiou≈øly (and therfore let no man ≈øo wre≈øt my words) but I ≈øpeake, with that mind, and in that manner, that Paule ≈øpake the former words, to ≈øignifie our readines, for ≈øuffering any thing, which the Prelats ≈øhall do unto us: not for doyng any thing to re≈øi≈øt them. Some of theÃÑ harpe much vpon this ≈øtring, (as appereth by wre≈øting of our words in mo≈øt malicious manner in the former an≈øwer again≈øt us) yea, they ≈øeeme al≈øo to thinke long, for ≈øome law or other of this land to be wre≈øted again≈øt us, to make ≈øome of us examples unto other, by ≈øheading of our bloud; but if they ≈øhould ≈øo fare prevaile (which I hope they ≈øhall never doe, in the dayes of gracious and mercifull King Iames, nor in the dayes of any of his mo≈øt Royall bloud) let them remember the words of Ieremy in the like ca≈øe,Ieremy 26:14:15 to the Prie≈øts and Prophets that ≈øought his bloud, As for me, be hold I am in your hands, doe with me as you thinke good and right. But know you for certeyne, that if ye put me to death, ye ≈øhall ≈øurely bring innocent bloud upon your ≈øelues, and upon this Citie, and upon the inhabitants thereof: etc. For of a truth the Lord hath ≈øent me to ≈øpeake all the≈øe wordes unto you. Yea, let them not onely remember
tho≈øe words, but ≈øo al≈øo take admonition by them, that in the pre≈øence of God, they be not guiltie of high trea≈øon again≈øt our mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Soveraigne, again≈øt his Royall i≈ø≈øue, and again≈øt the whole land, by provoking the Lord, to inflict ≈øuch judgments upon all, as the wordes before mentioned doe in≈øinuat. We are in their handes,2 Chron: 24 22: ready without any re≈øi≈øtance meekely to ≈øuffer any thing: but he that judgeth righteous iudgment, though he ≈øit in the heavens, will looke upon it, and one day (as Zechariah in the like ca≈øe ≈øayd) will requyre it: as indeed then he did.

Not with≈øtanding, I am ≈øo farre from Prophecying or wi≈øhyng any judgment to the whole land, (though I cannot but feare it) that I doe, and will earne≈øtly pray,Ioel 2.17 Gen, 18, 26 ≈øpare (this) thy people √¥ Lord, and giue not (this part of) thyne heritage into reproch etc. Yea, I doe the more hope of mercy in ≈øparyng us yet a while longer, becau≈øe of the great multitude of the righteous in the land: and becau≈øe perticularly of many that haue been and yet are (under Chri≈øt) dre≈ø≈øers of this the Lords vineyard, that day and night (whiles many Prelats eate and drinke, and take their ea≈øe and plea≈øure) doe pray the Lord of this his vineyard, to let it yet alone, Luk. 13:8 and to ≈øpare it a while longer. But for all this, who≈øoever ≈øhall procure the bloud of the meane≈øt of us to be ≈øhead, (under what≈øoever pretence) let them know that ≈øuch bloud, ≈øhall cry louder in the eares of the Lord of Ho≈øts, for vengeance upon the procurers therof, then ever we haue cryed in the eares, either of our mo≈øt gracious Soveraigne (whom God long pre≈øerue in per≈øon, and in vprightnes of heart) or of the High Court of Parliament for Iu≈øtice. If their ≈øhall be iudgment merciles, to him that sheweth no mercy, what ≈øhall the portion be of the cruell & bloud thir≈øty?Iames 2:13: Pro: 21:13 Verely, though they cry, yet the Lord shall not heare them.

As al≈øo they that put the Martyrs to death, mi≈ø≈øed of their purpo≈øe, ≈øo ≈øhall all bloud thir≈øty and ambitious Papall Prelats.Epi≈øt: 243. Sanguis martirum, ≈øemen Eccle≈øie. The bloud of Martyrs is the ≈øeed of the Church: and foecundi (≈øaith Calvin) ≈øunt martyrum cineres. The very ashes of Martyrs are fruitfull. The truth may be oppre≈ø≈øed, but it cannot be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed: yea the more it is oppre≈ø≈øed, the more it ≈øhall bud forth & ≈øpring. If one of us in this cau≈øe ≈øhould be put to death (though perhaps under colour of ≈øome other offence, by perverting of words, wre≈øting of law or otherwi≈øe) yet for that on, the Lord can ray≈øe up ten: yea, there is nothing that hath made, or doth make the cau≈øe of Papall Prelats more odious, and the reformation de≈øired, more gracious and honorable (even with ≈øome that before the con≈øideration of that which I now ≈øay, were of another minde) then the unju≈øt, and e≈øpecially the unmercifull proceedings of ≈øuch Papall Prelats, again≈øt the ≈øeekers of reformation.Philip: 1:28 Therfore in this ca≈øe (as the Apo≈øtle exhorteth the Philippians) we doe in nothing feare our adver≈øaries, becau≈øe as to be our adver≈øaryes in ≈øuch re≈øpects, is to them a token of perdition, (if they repent not) ≈øo al≈øo, to be hated and per≈øecuted by the Prelats, is a like token to us of ≈øalvation, and that of God. But beyng ≈øo confident, why doe we conceale our names to our writings? Becau≈øe as Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, notwith≈øtanding all his heavenly fortitude without any defect, did for all that, oft tymes hide and with drawe him≈øelfe, from the furie and rage of the Prie≈øts, Scribes, and Phari≈øes, till his appoynted time was come, ≈øo doe we by this meanes, hyde our ≈øelues from the violence of ≈øome of our Prelats.

To your conclu≈øion I will an≈øwer litle, becau≈øe it hath litle, that hath not been an≈øwered before. Wheras you ≈øay
that wordes are to be numbred to ≈øo great ≈øtates, I an≈øwer that words are not onely to be numbred, but al≈øo for the quality, truth, mode≈øty, ≈øincerity, and equity of them to be weighed and con≈øidered; which if you had doone, your whole labor had ben ≈øpared. If you did greiue in your ≈øoule, to heare us complayne of our povertie, why doe you by bitter rayling, fal≈øe accu≈øations, and mo≈øt unju≈øt & vnrea≈øonable wre≈øting of your antigoni≈øts words again≈øt all other Mini≈øters of his ≈øorte, ad affliction to our affliction: doe you not know, that by this circum≈øtance, David amplyfied his coÃÑ playnts and deprecations again≈øt his adver≈øaryes? Is this to iudge wi≈øely of the poore? P≈øal. 69 and 109.16 P≈øal. 41.1. Whereas you wi≈øh us to be a shamed of our feeding on shales, and huskes at other mens treÃÑthers, you mi≈øtake your marke. For this belongeth not to us, but to trencher chaplins, that gape after dead mens ≈øhoes, or liue in mi≈øerable hope of the livings of their brethren better then them≈øelues, to be unju≈øtly deprived: and that in the meane time wayte at their Ma≈øters table, till they haue ≈øayd grace, and then ≈øit down (if there be any rooÃÑe) at the nether end, after all the meate ≈øerved in. Who al≈øo are glad of ij s. vj d. or five ≈øhillings for examinyng ≈øome clarke pre≈øented, to a benefice, or that (which is wor≈øe) do now and then take a brybe, for allowing one to be ≈øufficient for the Mini≈øtery, that is ≈øcar≈øe fit to be a Mini≈øters clarke, except onely to helpe on with the Surplice: who finally (for the mo≈øt part) are every tawny coates companion, to play at cards, tables (perhaps al≈øo at dyce) and at bowles etc: Yea ≈øometimes to drinke, quaffe, and all mo≈øt quid non. All your rea≈øons out of Arretius, again≈øt popular contributions (as you call them) and for ≈øet ≈øtipends and tythes I pa≈ø≈øe over with ≈øilence, becau≈øe the author of the arguments hath commenced no ≈øute again≈øt you in this
behalfe. Therefore I leaue you to fight herein, with your owne ≈øhadowe. Touching you M. Powell, as Iob ≈øayd to Eliphaz, Iob. 16.3 What maketh thee bold ≈øo to an≈øwer? Or as ≈øome other read it, what provoketh you ≈øo to an≈øwer? So truely I cannot but admire the bitternes, ≈øharpnes, and unrighteou≈ønes of your pen (according as before I haue di≈øcovered the ≈øaÃÑe) again≈øt one that hath u≈øed ≈øo great mildnes in all his Arguments. Notwith≈øtanding remembring the fall of Peter, and the meanes therof, viz. His beyng in the high Prie≈øts Hall, and not forgetting his gracious repentance afterward, te≈øtified by many a ≈øalt teare, I doe the more pity your pre≈øent ≈øtate, by coÃÑ≈øidering that provocation, which from other you haue had, ≈øo to write; and I doe the better al≈øo hope of your repentance. For though it be more advi≈øedly to write an whole booke, then on the ≈øodayne to ≈øpeake a fewe wordes, yet in other re≈øpects, I will not compare your fault in thus wryting to the fall of Peter, as equall therunto: and if you had ≈øo fallen, yet would I not, neither might I, de≈øpaire of your ri≈øng. Only in unfained loue towards you, I do ≈øeriou≈øly exhort you, to take heed heerafter of any ≈øuch ≈øervice. Be not to readie, be not to ready, to be coÃÑmanded ≈øuch a worke by any Prelat what≈øoever. You may perhaps haue ≈øome reward in the end of ≈øuch paynes: (≈øuch as men can be≈øtowe upon you) but looke more to that reward, that is in the right hand of the great ma≈øter of all rewards. Remember well, what Balaam a ≈øorcerer refu≈øed at the hands of King Balak, beyng ≈øent for by very honorable me≈ø≈øengers, to cur≈øe I≈ørael: yea, remember what a worthy an≈øwer he made, though him≈øelf were a mo≈øt unworthy man.NuÃÑb. 22.18 If Balack would giue me his hou≈øe full of ≈øilver and gold, I cannot goe beyond the word of the Lord my God, to doe le≈ø≈øe or more. Yea, remember (I ≈øay once
agayne) how con≈øtant he was in the ≈øayd an≈øwer.chap. 24.1 ‚Ä¢
For he repeated it afterward, when Balak was much provoked, becau≈øe he would not ≈øatisfie him in cur≈øing of the I≈øraelits, and threatned as much evill again≈øt him, as before he had promi≈øed and offred preferment. If ≈øuch a per≈øon made ≈øuch an an≈øwer to a King, and were ≈øo con≈øtant therein, ≈øhould the Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell be ≈øo ea≈øily commanded by le≈ø≈øe then Kings, to revile, and (in ≈øome ≈øorte) to cur≈øe, ≈øo many worthy Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, which haue been valiant captaynes of his armyes again≈øt Sathan him≈øelfe, and all his forces? What≈øoever you haue in this booke written again≈øt them, yet I appeale to your owne con≈øcience for the contrary: yea you haue expre≈øly before profe≈ø≈øed, that you hope they are the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, and in grace and favor with him. Looke therfore heerunto in time, before you be too much hardened again≈øt him.

Touching the cau≈øe al≈øo it ≈øelfe, beware, yea, I ≈øay agayne beware, you ≈øinne not for any worldly prefermeÃÑt, again≈øt your former knowledge. Pleade not better judgment now, then before you had.P≈øal. 4.4 Examine your owne heart (as it were) upon your bed, whether this plea be in≈øincerity, or only from regard and hope of ≈øome prelaticall advancment. The more knowledge, the more dangerous it is to fall away. A litle di≈øea≈øe is ofttymes the beginning of great ≈øicknes. Small hurtes al≈øo at the fir≈øt neglected, growe in the end to greevous and incurable ≈øores. Remember Lots wife. Luc. 17.32 Revel 2. ‚Ä¢ . Fynally remember from whence you are already fallen, and repent, and doe your fir≈øt works etc: and let not the precious promi≈øes made to them in the word, that indure to the end, be forgotteÃÑ. Wherof he that hath made them; make both you and me partaker, for his ≈øake in whom they are made: to whom be all pray≈øe and glory for evermore, Amen.
